reviews.review: Temple that is further away. This temple take quite some time and distance to reach. It similar to other temples in angkor archaeological park so if you do not have enough time, you can probably skip it

Temple in symmetry. A less visited temple, a little deeper in the jungle so as other authors have said (although not witnessed by ourselves), may be prone to officials trying to profiteer.The main features of this temple in my opinion and what make it worthy of note are the long, cool corridors with decorated lintels over imposing doors spanning towards all four points of the compass.Similar to Ta Phrom, it has ancient trees that have become inseperable from the temples fabric, entwined and reliant on each other for all eternity. Amongst some of the areas of collapse there's an impressive carving of Jayadevi, one of Jayavarman VI's sister-wives.Not to be missed.

Beware the local restaurants - bullies. . The temple itself is interesting whilst unremarkable in comparison to others in the Angkor archeological park. However the temple is not the reason for my review.I want to alert travellers to the abuse and intimidation we were faced with at nearby restaurants. The restaurants were at the East entrance to Preah Khan and YOU SHOULD NOT USE THEM UNDER ANY CIRCUMSTANCES.We sat down for lunch before visiting PK. We ordered 2 fantas and 2 fried rice explaining we were vegetarian. As we'd been temple trampling all morning I had quite an appetite and dug straight into mine. It wasn't too bad but as I was about to finish my plate my girlfriend unearthed a fried ant at the bottom of her plate. Totally revolted we both immediately dropped our cutlery.I took the plate to the lady who'd served it, explained and asked for the bill. She simply laughed and put the plate down on a nearby table, resuming her activity on her phone. I had intended to pay for my rice as I'd eaten a lot of it however as that was her attitude I asked how much the fantas were, gave her the 2 dollars and said I wouldn't pay for food with insects in. As the dishes were identical it was fair to assume my dish had also been contaminated so I wouldn't pay for that either. She immediately started screaming to a lady at a restaurant further along. It appears they are all one business. We got up and went to visit the temple. Once past the ticket check the lady who'd been called appeared behind screaming 'you pay, you pay.' I again explained my reasoning and walked away. She called after me that I was a bad person and I had 'lots of ants in my belly' confirming my suspicion about the contamination. On returning to our tuk tuk we were again chased by the same lady who assaulted my girlfriend by pushing her out of the way so she could stand in the way of our tuk tuk. Almost out of nowhere, she was joined by perhaps 8 or 10 other people, one of which was in a military-like uniform, all yelling 'you pay, you pay' at us. I again explained my reasoning for refusing to pay for contaminated food which was not only disgusting but had caused us to violate our beliefs and invited them to call the police to resolve the issue. Still, they wouldn't accept it and feeling threatened, we asked the poor tuk tuk driver who was caught in the middle of all this, to take us to our next temple. After the few minutes required to turn the tuk tuk around we departed to a torrent of abuse.Suspecting they may follow us to the next destination, it kind of soured what had been an otherwise wonderful day.

Ancient Temple In A Forested Habitat. Drove through Angkor Thom North Gate to Preah Khan Temple.12th century temple built dedicated to the King's father. Day Pass checkpoint at the entrance. Walked about 150 metres of tall shady trees before crossing the bridge (lined up with 2 rows of the Guardians) divided by a stream. Ahead will be the ancient temple. Inside the temple, lots of trees and vegetations grew messily in this habitat ; will be walking through lots of uneven grounds, up and down steps, etc before arriving at the magical lamp in the heart of it. Was really exhausted after visiting 5 major temples. Conquering this 6th temple really drained off one energy completely. A pair of comfortable shoes needed. Feet was so sore after this walk.

One of the Hot Spot. This is the place included in the travel package where is full of historical building.Please bring along a scarf or mask during hot season it is because surrounding by dusty walking distance towards the place.

It's worth a visit. When in SR, you just have to accept that it will all be temple tour. If you have 2 days to explore, you have to visit this one. You will just be amazed with the symmetry on this temple. You'll wonder how they built the almost perfect geometric windows and doors.

Nice temple but be careful with the guards. Guards aka policemen. They will be kind enough to show you the good parts of the temple but after they take your picture, they will ask for money. Be careful. We only had riel that time but he was insisting to give him dollars.

Should miss the beautiful place?. Preah khan is amazing one of temples beside Angkor Wat. There are many of huge tree and 3 ways of gates. You can imagine that at the previous time their architecture is very awesome. This temple also have the water system. I don't know exactly about it. But I will visit it again if I have another chances.
One of my favourite temples. Very long with many doors to walk through and at the centre you can see out north south east and west .. Really enjoyed this sire
One of our favourites. A beautiful small temple close to Angkor Thom with lovely carvings which are in good condition. Easy to get to in the Angkor area.
Good one!. It is the smallest one I did visit. It lead you to 4 ways. When you visit it, you feel you are in a jungle, it is so peaceful and ancient.

Temple in shape of a cross. This temple is built with four long halls intersecting in a central room. There is a different vibe here with the long halls and carving which are in good shape, less the stolen heads.
Wonderful. It is really amazing. It was a rainy (i mean rainy!) day when I was there. You will really like this place.

Police inside not so helping. We were shocked that the police inside the temple that suppose to provide the security do ask money from us after bring us round the temple without being asked to. For us this is quite embarrassing since for us, providing the security is what you should do, not chasing tourist and ask them some tips for the service that you not asked to do.
Another beautiful temple. Would recommend to combine this with other inner circle temples. You could spend up to 1 hr here and enjoy the architecture & history. Good for photography.

Great experience! But.. The place was great in general (we got great pictures) but beware of the police. They might offer to take your pictures for you and guide you to where the really great place was but after my friend tip him usd10. He called us again guiding us throughout the tour only to ask for a tip again and after we gave him the second time he asks for more. What nerve. Should have taken a picture of him.

Beautiful Temple. Great Architecture.. We were fortunate enough to visit this temple after a heavy rain and it was deserted. Gave us the opportunity to really enjoy this place without the crowds. The areas where the trees were taking over was spectacular.

Reminded me of the police who work part time as photographer. This was the first temple we visited in the morning and we spend quite a bit more time to take photos. There are layer after layer, frame after frame... it has the great effect on the photo that you are in a frame within many frames and you will look outstanding in red. When you were offered help by a police to take photos for you, just decline politely as after the photo session he was asking for tips for 3 persons and the fact that he was taking the photos while another person was following and we have no idea where was the third person!

Wonderful Temple! Watch out for the corrupt cops in the middle!. Another wonderful temple similar to the Bayon/Angkor Wat architecture. The reason I'm reviewing it is to warn tourists NOT to let the cops in the middle of the temple take their picture as they will ask for money afterwards! Just keep walking past them, pretend you don't understand and don't engage them in conversation. It will dampen your sightseeing experience if you're victimized. Good Luck and Have a great time here, it's beautiful!

Favorite. Preeah Khan is my favorite temple. Sometimes overlooked and many who visit Angkor Wat only one day, will skip this one, but you shouldn't. Preah Khan is big, beautiful, massive, have some trees growing in to walls like Ta Prohm but lot less crowded, very pleasant place to visit.

A bit further out and so worth it. This temple was a surprise - much bigger than it looks and ridiculously picturesque, it gives Ta Prohm a run for it's money. It's a bit further out from the basic temple circuit and it is so worth it.
Check out the outside walls of the naga-weilding god/demon entrance; there are people carved there.
one of the more less visited temples. there are a LOT of temples in SR, if you spend time there go to the ones farther out and drives away. Some absolutely wonderful temples and less crowded.

One of my favourite spots in the Angkor Wat complex. The ancient structures are incredible. I live for these kinds of travelling adventures. Cambodia was high on my list of places to visit in the world and the ancient temples of Siem Reap will not disappoint.

Love, love, love. Preah Khan is awesome, massive and somewhat confusing since it is a maze of corridors...but so worth the visit.There are lots of beautiful carvings in this fusion temple of Buddhism and Hinduism. A lot of it is in ruins, but for me that just adds to the loveliness. If you can spare 90 mins, then you should. It will be time well spent

flat temple at last. Preah Kahn is a large temple surrounded by a wall with four gates. Usually the tuk tuk will drop you in one gate and pick you up in another so that you don't have to walk the same distance again. It has just a ground level so not much step to climb. It has four main corridors that meet in the middle and several features in stone like fertility organs.Also police officers offer to give you history hints for a small tip!

Quieter than Ta Prohm - Beautiful with Great Photo Opportunities. This temple, like Ta Prohm has a number of trees growing from the ruins. It was still somewhat busy, but not to the extent Ta Prohm is. As with all of the temples, the bathrooms are pleasantly clean and well maintained, it is far hotter than you really anticipate and the best photos often require a bit of patience as you wait for people to move out of your shots.This temple should be included on most itineraries.

Another temple near Angkor Wat. Located close to Angkor Wat this is another temple. Be prepared to climb some stairs and walk. Careful while walking as you will be walking while looking at these magnificent structure and there is always a chance that you could slip and fall.
Angkor, Angkor. You cannot visit Angkor and not also includ Preah Khan! You have to regards this as part of the overall picture of Angkor.

Quite unique when compared with the rest. Do spend sometime reading the history and information available outside the temple before enter to get some idea of what you're looking at.Thanks to the low ceiling at some area particularly the entrance ways, my head was punished with a few bumps due to my carelessness. If you're 185cm like me, do watch out.Due to ruins and many path ways were block by fallen rocks and the narrow paths, this temple may feel more stuffy than the rest. Do take your time but be careful.
Another gem. Went here on Day 2, on our own and armed only with a Lonely Planet. Another lovely temple that is definitely less crowded than some of the others.

A must visit. Just as interesting as ta Prohm with some awesome trees to the rear. i enjoyed visiting this temple the most, make the effort and get there at dawn, come 8am its bedlam. The old nun was there giving out her blessings in the centre of the temple, brilliant place.

One of my favorites and we visited last. I did a two day tour - including morning zip line flight of the griffon - and my guide took me here last. It was hot - I was spent - and this place might have been my favorite. It was small but not too small. The temples and stones are crazy - this place would not be open in the US - it would have ropes around it - safety reasons. But in Cambodia - let 'er rip. And I got the best tree root shot of anywhere - and it wasn't crowded. Check it out.

Beautiful . Try to get here first thing, low season and you will have it to yourself. Great atmosphere, trees like at ta phrom. Interesting as Buddhist carvings are on, lots removed and replaced by Hindu things. A firm favourite of mine

As impressive as Ta Prohm – but without the crowds. This massive compound (56 ha) was once a palace-university. It did not benefit from the extensive renovations made at Ta Prohm, so you really have the feeling to explore new found ruins, with many sections absolutely deserted. The security guards do their job in a visitor-friendly manner, helping you find the best views, guiding you to hidden apsaras, taking pictures, showing you how to turn a hole in the ceiling above the central stupa into a flame in your hand. The variety and richness of sculptures still visible is way beyond what we could digest in a single 90mn visit.
Well worth a visit. Preah Khan is less crowded than Ta Prohm and well worth a visit, especially if you are looking for the 'trees growing out of ruins' photo shots.Really atmospheric.

Magical - A Better Version of Ta Prohm. This was one of the coolest temples I visited in Angkor - one of my favorites. It is epic in size and has a seemingly never-ending hall of doorways that lends a sort of haunted feeling and gives you the sense of being in a movie or a story. Unlike some of the other temples, there are no barriers or ropes to get in the way, so it feels incredibly authentic and is great for photo ops. The architecture is eclectic and stunning. There are some strangler fig trees here, taking over parts of the ruins just like at Ta Prohm, except this temple has a more remote feel to it.

A temple preserved under ruins. When you have seen the Tomb Raider Ta Prohm, Preah Khan is merely a recollection - temple ruined yet beautified by the mother nature. It is however better preserved and more constructively caredTips: Beware of police/ guards offering to take for you a snap or two photos. They are aiming for your dollars and expecting to be tipped handsomely - an experience that threw me off from the joly excitement in this beautiful forsaken temple

Least crowded but equally mesmerizing !. Literally translating into the "Royal Sword" this temple was built to honour king Jayavarman's father. There's quite a lot of walk but its worth it as its less crowded and with plenty of photogenic corridors . Tip : This temple is not covered by most of the single day temple tours. Hence you should specifically ask your driver/guide to take a detour towards Preah Khan after finishing Angkor Thom as its very close to Angkor Thom .
One of the best ruins in Angkor. I went to Preah Khan as part of the 'grand circuit' tour.I really enjoyed Preah Khan; its very original looking.

Great Place. I visited PK with a remork driver from the 7 Candles Guesthouse (another great place). I so enjoyed it as it was far from over-run by other temple-hoppers. It used to be the centre of a vast complex including a university and it seems much humbler now but very evocative. The four long corridors all lead to the centre with an elegant simplicity and to appreciate that (let alone photograph it) you really do need to get there when the corridors aren't blocked by other human beings toting cameras. There are a few well-preserved sculptures dotted about but the most astonishing things are the two trees that have run riot- one throttling a construction inside the temple wall, and the other slowly engulfing a section of the outside wall at the back.

Fabulous . This is the first temple you come to after visiting Angkor Wat and then Angkor Thom. It is more over grown than the first two and feels wilder, it was also much quieter but more tumbled down. It was much bigger than I initially expected and had an old stupa in the middle. I loved wandering around this temple it was truly beautiful. I did consider hiring a guide for the trip and I'm sure it would have been really useful to find out about the history and culture. However I decided against it as I just like to wander and soak up the atmosphere and if something catches my eye or I want to wander off in a particular direction I can just go. If you want to know about a particular building or carving you only need to wait a little while and someone will turn up with a guide and explain all about it. I quite liked catching snippets of information form different guides as I went around rather than having someone talking to me the whole time!!
magnificent. less known that angkor watt, less good condition but less tourists too. here you can still feel the soul of the temples, the silence of the jungle.

Dont be decived by its exteriors. thought this would be another little temple for us to spend 5 mins and go, but it turned out to be much larger than expected. walking through it was akin to a jungle hike with all the fallen stones and overgrown trees. the entire place was quiet and not overcrowded with tourists, which gave us enough time to walk around slowly and listen to our tour guide without having to camp and wait for a good spot for a picture

Great Mixture of Designs. This temple reminded me of both Bayon and Ta Prohm. It has a unique combination of features that makes it very interesting. Even though it was the last temple we saw, it was still as captivating as the first. It reminds me of why Siem Reap is such a great place to visit.

Peaceful and Amazing... I hadn't heard of this Temple before.. This site was very large with wonderful shaded and peaceful areas to roam and take beautiful photos..or just to sit in quiet and ponder.Compared to the major sites this one has far less people..Make sure you include a visit on your travels

the most important temple complex to be visited. we spent more time here to explore the temple complex/ many ancient structures r inside this complex.many sculptures showing praying Rishis are there. the hall of dancers is a 2 storey building /we can see a Linga inside the temple still but not worshipped/ transformation of Buddha temple in to Hindu temple is visible at many places/

Best of the rest . Not too many people visit this one and shame on them, since its location and architecture is indeed worth spending some time to come here. It has similar charm to more famous ta Prohm but without its crowds. All in all, the best one excluding all big ones like Angkor, Bayon or Taprohm.
Yet another Fascinating Place to Visit. Massive in scale and able to accommodate a large number of visitors without feeling crowded. Another experience in the grandeur of times past.

Probably my favorite temple in Angkor. I visited Preah Khan on my first day in Angkor while doing the Grand Circuit Tour. This temple might not be as big or as famous as Angkor Wat or Ta Prohm, but I must admit that I enjoyed it more than its more prominent neighbors. There seemto be less visitors here. Therefore, the temple is surrounded by quiet and mysterious aura. I really enjoyed that special atmosphere. Moreover, the temple features trees growing on stones and walls. Thus, it's kind of similar to Ta Prohm - just less crowded. All in all, I highly recommend visiting Preah Khan during your stay in Angkor.
Nice temple. This is also part of the tour package and is worth a visit. Again all temples have its unique features and this temple is not excluded. Guides are very useful and is highly recommended.
Excellent temple. Lovely tranquil atmosphere. We went when it wasn't too busy so had a nice leisurely stroll through the courtyards.

Serene, Less visitors but Quite Impressive. Visited the temple at around 3PM and I was not expecting grand from this because we originally planned to have a quick visit but we ended up staying for almost 2 hours This temple has trees like Ta Prohm which is comparable. The temple has human figures that resembles the guards. Some carvings on the walls and doors were quite well preserved. You'll see a linga (if I am not mistaken) at tte very middle of the temple. You might also notice that the area has lots of holes on the walls, as we were eves dropping with the Russians' guide , he said that there several glasses inside to reflect the light coming from the ceiling. Try to go around the nearby forested walls, it is also interesting how the trees are starting to devour the walls. Worth a visit.

Fantastic temple with Architectural valour. Its my first spot of my Angkor Day 2 in Tuk Tuk, the Temple is surrounded by dense giant trees, a small moat was buit arounded the temple, it was a pleasant visit for me in the morning hours . The temple has intricate carvings and the path way leading the temple is beautifully constructed . Most of the structures were fallen and become rumbles, the temple is built beautifully with carvings and deities and women Apsaras dancing sculptures, The place is so calm and a on the main entrance side small vendors were selling souveniers , paintings, and tour guide books post cards. The temple is being restored by the Apsara authority. The garuda Sculptures are carved and installed on the surrounded fortified walls on the both sides of the entrance gate . Huge giant roots and tress were grown over the structure. Ther s also a Mahal of elephants a two storied structure with steps and a minar type structure on the right side of the temple. Its a must visit place in Angkor Circuit List .
One of my favority temples. Maybe not as impressive as Bayon or Angkor Wat, it has its own personality and charm. You should not miss it, especially if you want to take gorgeous photos

Not a priority temple unless archeology buff. With all the other choices closer to town, I did not think this was worth the 1 hour drive.Only exception if you are an archeology buff, since this is the earliest temple, from 10th century, while others are 12-13th century

Small, peaceful place.. This very small structure is not so frequently visited as many of the other temples in the area. When we visited we were treated to the beginning of a thunder storm, which made the swampy scene along the wooden walkway leading to the temple seem rather eerie. The small temple is surrounded by a moat and you cannot get right into the temple itself. But the scene is a beautiful one, worth a short visit.

Nothing great in front of other places in Siem Reap. I didn't find anything special about this place in comparison to other great places in Siem Reap. In case, someone is in Siem Reap for long holiday, it is good to view it but if you are on short trip then this can be skipped.

Preah Khan- the King's Sword.. This temple was built in 1191 by King Jayavarman the 7th, after he defeated the Chams, today's Thailand, and it was dedicated to his father in the name of Abolakitashwar. Around 100,000 people used to live and work in this temple. There are three Hindu temples around this temple.

Nice mixed of Greek architecture into Hinduism . The highlight of this temple is its two storey Grecian pillars blending into the Hindu structure of design. It's huge and really like walking in a maze. You can find some interesting spots for photos. Less touristic then other temples so a great chill out.

My favourite after Angkor Wat. Although there are a lot left for me to see in the Angkor and nearby area, this is so far my favourite after Angkor Wat. I have visited among others Bayon, Baphuon, Ta Phrom and Ta Som.Preah Khan covers a large area, a lot of the structures are somewhat different in style, there are a lot of interesting engravings and other details, the embedded trees are possibly even cooler than in Ta Phrom, and you are free to walk around a lot, as it is mostly one storey.I didn't have a guide for this trip, and I guess it will be even better with one.

Beautifull temple without crowds of people. It was wonderull to wander around this overgrown temple and to find 'hidden' corridors. Be sure to look for the two sisters, these statues are difficult to find, you can ask an employee of the temple, he/she will show you
Superb. Another gem in this gem field part of the country. A nice drive out into the country which adds to the experience. Magnificent

Great Experience. This was the first place we visited in Siem Reap. Wonderful history and photos for memories. Our travel guide Siekong (calls himself Kingkong) was very knowledgeable so the visit was very good.

Small but not forgotten. A small temple but not forgotten as it offers peace and serenity. At this point, crowd is getting lesser due to it is not on a tour list and you might actually have a quality time viewing and appreciating the artwork.
My fav. Was definitely my favorite temple to visit. No crowd, a very personal experience. It was a very quiet day, spent some time speaking with the locals and quiet meditation.
Different architecture. It was one of the best historical temples I've ever seen. It has different architecture than the other temples in Siem Reap.

Preah Khan. Preah Khan or Presh Khan is interesting temple you should visit when you are going to Siem Reap. In the same road with this temple, you can visit another temples: Neak Pean, Ta Som, Mebon, and Preroup.

The place was good, the people were not. Beware of the Cambodia Police in the site, who will try their best to grab your camera, take some ugly photos for you (they don't even know how to use a camera!) and ask for tips!

So beautiful, well worth a visit. First temple on our itinerary, we did the grand circuit before taking on Angkar Thom the next day.
Preah Khan was my favourite temple on the Grand Circuit, not alot of foot traffic which was great in the heat.

Visit Preah Khan on day 2. Fantastic site!. I think I am just repeating what everyone has said before, this place is indescribable and a must see in a life time. Very hot and lot to walk to get plenty water and good running shoes.

One of the better temples on the Grand Circuit. This temple was amazing! A lot of good photo opportunities. Don't forget to take the picture of the giant bell in the middle of the temple. If you take it at a certain angle, it would look like a candle.

A must see. All of these places are amazing and mind blowing a must see if your in Siem Reap.
You won't be disappointed.

Interesting and not as packed. Another interesting monument to visit. Not as packed and the story of this place is quite touching. Essentially it was how a son chose to honour his father. Definitely worth visiting!

Yet Another Temple to See. By this stage of the hot day we were starting to get towards the end of what we could handle, but our driver told us we 'must' visit this temple. It was a short walk down to the temple, and we were glad we stopped. In some ways the temples are all so alike, but they all have their unique characteristics, and we enjoyed being able to look around this one in a little more peace and quiet. Beautiful and spectacular - worth the visit - even if you think enough is enough.
Majestic. This was a great temple to explore with fewer people. We enjoyed walking around and taking some good pictures with no people in them except the ones carved in!

staggeringly beautiful. We spent a full 9 days exploring the various temples and ruins in and around Siem Reap, and one was more beautiful than the last. Preah Khan was originally a Buddhist monastery that was transformed into a temple for Hindu worship. According to inscriptions found on the temple, the complex it was part of at one point housed hundreds of thousands of people. Experiencing this and the other temples of Angkor Wat brings one to keep appreciation of the genius of human kind, while at the same time recognizing that these beautiful temples were constructed with the blood, sweat and tears of many generations of laborers, perhaps even slaves.

Great spot to see the ruins without too much tourist traffic . It was definitely worth the ride by dirtbike from preah vihar. The ruins have relatively low traffic and you can explore the temples in the area without the usual distractions of vendors etc. There's not much information available about the history of the area so you may want to bring your own history book if you are so inclined.There's A small fee of 10USD per person.It's worth it if you manage to get to all the smaller sites in the area. Suggest downloading an offline map.

A maze of amazing sights. I found Preach Khan to be a special place. In one of the hallways it looked like I was starring in a mirror without a reflection back. I think anyone that loves adventure must come here and see what the Khmer peoples built before they learn about what they have endured. It is inspiring.

Underestimated temple. Dating back to 1191AD this stunning Buddhist city was also used as a university which held a capacity of over 1000 teachers.It was built on the site of a major battle between the Khmer and the Chams giving it the name 'lake of blood'.

Long Continuous Alleys might embrace your exploration that makes Preah Khan differ from the other temples.. Our last Temple visit for our First Day Angkor Archaeological Park experience was the Preah Khan. Long Continuous Alleys might embrace your exploration that makes Preah Khan differ from other the temples. A small Stupa (used as a place of meditation) is located inside and a good for photo-illusion; you might go there to know why. Temple is not that crowded. Please be reminded to bring plenty of water as always and your personalized Angkor Pass.

Magic place. I visited that place in the most hot day probably in the year. There was about 45C but even though I didn't spoil the pleasure of being there.
All you need is a good camera and lots of water to drink.

Awesome and Fantastic Place!. Don't miss any opportunity you have to see this incredible temple! My daughter and I spent a few hours roaming the open uncontrolled site peeking through passages and walking through in awe. The detail and carvings in the stone work are incredible and the scale / size of the temple is massive. You can really explore randomly and anywhere you want on this site. When we were there we were alone most of the time and there were no other tourists so it was that much more of an inspiring forgotten historical and cultural place.

Long Alleys, Grandest Entrance. Will always remember this temple for the majestic "Samudra-Manthan" tug-o-war of various gods and demons at display at the entrance. The long galleries inside this temple the King made for his father are unique and awe-inspiring. can't have enough of it!

Most Underrated Temple!. Preah Khan is one of the less popular temples, but it is a gem! I love that it is bigger and feels like you can get lost! There are often less people people at Preah Khan than other temples such as Ta Prohm. It has some of the large trees growing out of the temples that are sought after at Ta Prohm. Highly recommend Preah Khan for a really interesting, unique temple in the Angkor Archeological Park.

my favorite. This temple was my favorite out of all the ones I visited; it feels more like exploring rather than following a set path, you can even get out of the main route from some of the side doors and see some less restored ruins

Historical venue. It is a must for persons who are interested in history and wanting to see historical palces.This portion of Ankor Wart is beautiful . It is really amazing to see these structure were built by Tamil Nadu Chola Emperor of South India. Indian architectures can be widely seen Combodia . It was King Bhodhi Dharamn II, the Chola King who built it.
See my comments on Angkor Wat. See my comments on Angkor Wat. Investing a bit of time to read about these places prior to your visit will enhance your visit.

Gorgeous and varied unrestored temple. Preah Khan has been left in a semi-restored state, much like Ta Prohm, and is all the more lovely for it. This was one of the larger temples we visited, or perhaps it just felt like that because the fun of clamboring over the countless fallen stones made exploring every last nook and cranny all the more tempting.

Great discovery at the ruin, Pheah Khan. This 12th century is a flat temple with so many square galleries, not to far from Ta Prom Temple which featured in Tomb Raider.Observe numerous of huge trees grown on this beautiful temple.

Cool 12th century uni town . Cool to visit a 12th century Uni temple whose Dean was the queen and first post doctoral woman scholar in Cambodia!! Indiradevi the cool :)Made us wonder how it would have looked when fully functional , student monks mulling about , little oil lamps , sunbeams and moonbeams filtering in through the windows and falling on the hundreds of precious stones embedded in the walls. Hope someone discovers a working time machine and soon

not so well known but highly recommended.. This temple is tucked away from the rest, though nearby. A very serene setting, probably aided by the musical group playing traditional music just before the entrance. As one other reviewer mentioned, there are guards (or possible policemen?) who will take you around or tell you some interesting facts then ask for a tip. They are harmless but a slight blemish on an otherwise lovely experience.

Before you visit Angkor Wat. This is a great temple to visit before moving on to the Angkor Wat/Angkor Tom circuit. Pay special attention tot he fusion of Buddhism and Hinduism. Hiring a licensed guide adds real value to the visit.

My favourite temple in Siem Reap. To conclude a day's exploration, I highly recommend visiting one of the least crowded of the temples, Preah Khan. This temple formed a series of archways, leading up to where the King would sit. As it was common practice to bow to the King, the height of each archway becomes progressively lower, as if to help with simulating the bowing gesture. It's unique formation distinguishes it from the rest and although it is not too far from Angkor Wat, it tends to be one of the quietest attractions, meaning you can explore at your own uninterrupted leisure.

Small temple but interesting. Preah Khan temple is almost similar in architecture as Ta Phrom. It had lots of Buddhas but most of them have been broken due to vandalism. This is also the only temple with round columns. Just like Ta Phrom, the temple buildings have also been overrun by the jungle so you can see a lot of tree roots on top of the roofs. Lots of photo opportunities here so be sure to find time to visit.

So beautiful. i couldn't believe how amazing the temple is considering it's age i spent over an hour here and loved every minute i went early in the morning so i can only comment on this time to visit and i found it great.
Interesting and easy. Unlike Angkor Wat and many of the other big temples at Angkor, Preah Khan is on a single level and so much easier to get around while still having the same beautiful carvings
Some ruins, wish they could restore it.. walk through it and you are lost. Amazing place.One should spend sometime there to sit and watch the wonder happening around.

Fabulous Ruins. I have been to Angkor Wat twice and find the onverted Hindu temple fascinating.The whole site is huge.The weather is hot and sticky so the best times are sunrise and sunst.One of the wonders of the earth

Temple for the scholars. I was told that Preah Khan is a temple for the scholars. What makes it different with other temples:- There are four entrances, 1 for each cardinal direction. 3 of them are for peasants and 1 is for the king or noble persons. Each entrance have several gates. The gates for peasants are from smaller to larger, so when you enter the first gate, you will need to bow down a bit toward to the center of the temple. While the entrance for the king or peasant, the gates is from very large to large. The first gate is very large and you can get inside easily (no need to bow down on the way to the center to the temple).- At the center of the temple, there is a stupa. The walls that surrounding the stupa has a hole, so that if you position your camera correctly, you will get a picture of candle-like stupa. - Beware of the security guard in this temple - he approached me and told a few history of this temple and asked for money in return. - There's a library (I forgot on which cardinal direction) - so that's why it is believed this temple is for scholars. - This temple is much quieter than other temples. And it is awe inspiring. I loved to spend more time in this temple.

One of my favourite temples in Cambodia. Preah Khan was one of the larger temples that I've visited and it was so interesting to see that there are many doors and the pathway is so long from each gate that meet at the centre. It is amazing to think that people from so long ago built this temple and today it is still so beautiful.

Very nice. Nice temple, worth the visit, even if my favorites are Bayon and Ta Prohm. I took a one day guide, french spoken, worst it for the historical details. He was nice and accomodating. The one day tour is totally faisible by motorcycle taxi (and less expensive):Cheavannak2005@yahoo.com.
a very beautiful temple. I like this temple very much as it is the most beautiful temple of all temples that we visit. the tiny carving on the wall is very nice.

DON'T MISS IT!!!. One of the best temple at Angkor complex. Probably overshadowed by Ta Prohm or Bayon, but don't miss it. Its a lot quieter, less crowded and serene. Really wonderful. One of my favorite.

Beware of scam. At the centre of the whole structure, there are securities and other locals station there and help you take photos. They took some good photos with good angle, e.g. The candle. But they offered to take you more photos at side tracks, reject and go away. They held my iphone without giving it back to me, but they were not that aggressive as I didn't move far from the centre (other tourists could still hear). One guy asked for money for the taking the photos and I insisted I gave him USD 1 only.

Wonderful. This temple was amazing. It was really cool to see everything in person that you can see in pictures. However, it was really crowded and full of tour groups. If I could go again, I would try and go there very early in the morning, right when the temple opens.
Another great temple. One of the many great temples that one should visit on a tour to Siem Reap. Like all my other reviews have said, I highly recommend a tour guide to show you around this place.

Another of the gorgeous temples, and less crowded than some. It's the Wandering Yank here. Mrs. Yank and I spent 3 wonderful days touring the Angkor area. This was one of our favorites. For one thing, it was less crowded than the very popular Ta Prohm, yet it still has some of the same "Tomb Raider" ambience. Lots of beautiful carvings of course. Some of it is in ruins, but much of it is in more or less excellent condition.2 thumbs up!

Common temple with flat layout. A temple with flat layout, similar to other temples with the same style. Recommend to visit if no temple of this style has been visited. The Garuda outside the wall is interesting.
Awesome. I really liked this temple. It feels amazing and is truly beautiful. With less crowds you have fantastic opportunities for photos and is magical and calm.
Awesome place. One of the bigger temples to see near Ankgor wat, this was our last temple that we visited and we glad we did.
Preah Khan. Visited as part of the tour of the Angkor city, the main attraction here is the hall of dancers which is lines with exquisite bas reliefs of the apsaras.
Amazing temple. this temple was very nice one stay on Angkor wat area , It broken some but still good .Preah Khan is meaning Sword .

Roots & Hallways. Similar to Ta Prohm with the roots, but in better condition. Again, long hallways and interesting reliefs. Long walkway to the west gate over a moat with statuary/carvings on the bridge.
Interesting Temple. Another interesting temple history wise and amazing to see the structures and how long corridors line up, even after all these years.

First Temple in a 9 day stay. It's Daddy's House. This particular temple had a rather intense energy to it. As I later learned they all have a unique personality and vibe. If your into the paranormal or spiritual, this place can be a bit hostile. This may sound strange but my cell phone got jumped by a spirit. It road all the way home with me and the phone had to be thrown away and replaced 2 months after my return. It's not as crowded as some other places, so it's worth a visit. Just be careful with your electronics.

sunset not too amazing. came here during the day, and again at sunset. For similar structure I would prefer Bakong Temple (but Bakong is way further away!)We didn't have the luxury of time to queue for Phnom Bakheng for sunset (have to go at like 3:30pm during peak season..), so came here instead. Unfortunately it was a cloudy/foggy day, so no sunset. Nevertheless the sun would be setting on top of a bunch of trees (we only tried searching for a nice view on the west side of the temple). A nice surprise is watching the silhouette of the stone lions at sunset........(please keep it to yourself if you know what I mean).
Visit Angkor Wat first. Visit Angkor Wat first. If time is at a premium visit Angkor Wat first and then the smaller temples.

Prehistoric wonder. This temple was unique because of its decrepit nature. It's fabulous. The enormous stones that comprise the walls are about 1-4 feet long each and are tumbling into piles like a kid's pile of blocks. It's less "put together" than some other temples. There are a couple of other-worldly trees, like in most temples of Angkor, but these trees were prehistoric. As in dinosauric. We took countless photos near the dinosaur legs, dinosaur feet, etc. If you visit, which you should, you will instantly recognize the scaly skin and reptilic muscular structure that thickens into round feet (though trees). Please go, you'll see, and you won't regret it.
Great less visited temple.. Not as popular as the other temples in Angkor but I found it very interesting and beautiful. Maybe because we had it almost to ourselves. Fantastic!

Another Great Temple. This was a smaller temple ruins in the area, but so worth it. We were lucky enough to have a great tour guide, Hiek Han, through Angkor Wat Sam's tour guide service, which made this visit all the more worth it. Don't miss this temple!
Less crowds. This temple is often quieter than the otehr main ones and walking around a lone is the best way to soak up the atmosphere.
Awesome. SO COOL!!! Very beautiful area, quite secluded. Totally worth the trip. I visited as a part of a bike tour and fully recommend.
Unique Temple in Siem Reap. Amazing temple with 2 floors, a rare site. Nice view, especially during the sunset. This is a must-visit place in Siem Reap and Cambodia. Highly recommended.

Large, Cool Area. Approximately 140 acres make up the Preah Khan temple complex, and there are numerous trees, making the visit here cooler than to some of the other temples. There also is a free exhibit that shows how reconstruction by World Monument Fund has been carried out. I found Preah Khan to be particularly beautiful, and I especially appreciated that it was not crowded when I visited in early March.

One of the best. For me, Preah Khan was one of the best temples in Angkor. It was a lot less crowded as Wat, Thom or Bayon and it is big enough so you can find places where you are all alone and can really enjoy the magnificence of this incredible temples. There is a lot of crumbled stone all through the temple which provides a special atmosphere.

Visit this temple after Sunrise!! You would be alone!. Preah Khan is one of my favorites temples in the Angkor Complex. Really worth a visit, since we have been all day long at Angkor Wat, we decided to see the morning sunset at 6 at angkor and then go to preah khan, the best decision we made, we were totally alone in the temple, without the noisy chinese tours, without crowds, and other explorers.

Enjoyable!. This temple was quite cool - all of the doorways were set up so that as you walked through, it almost looked like it would never end. The carvings are wonderful, there's a decent amount of shade (particularly important during the hot season) and very enjoyable. If you only have one day for temples, I wouldn't necessarily put it on the "must" list, but if you have two days, definitely go see it!

One of the most amazing temples in Angor complex. It use to be an university in the past (at least this is what they told me). The place is beautiful and so big, you can get lost in there. And all of those crumbling stones make the scenario very dramatic. Got wonderful pictures there.If you are in Angor, you must go.
A must do!. This place is just amazing. Magical and if you don't want to get disappointed, see this place! We went there today and it was sooooo hot but everything was so well worth it!

1000 doors ;-). My favorite temple. If you have enough time to cover the small temple, this one has to be included. for it's so beautiful, simple, and covering all aspects you wanna see in a temple ;-) i just love this temple...

One of my favorites. Very photogenic, atmospheric temple. The light streams in...illuminating the many massive trees and roots that appear to be swallowing this temple whole. It really was amazing and it was not overrun by hoards of tourists. Loved it.

Better than Ta Prohm. There were less people when we went there. I liked it better than Ta Prohm. I didn't like the cheesy poses that tour guides make people do though. Especially with the stupa that looks like a candle. Someone should tell guides that not all travelers like to have cheesy photos.

Different as it was a Monastery Temple. It was the last of the four temples I squeezed into my day at Angkor Wat. I did think as I got out of the car into the burning heat "why do I need to do this?". I was glad I did as there is enough left to imagine the orange robed monks in their standard but quite spacious quarters praying and sleeping. The interminable central corridor loses some of its impact because of fallen stones and props and work in progress.

Awesome temple going back to nature. Like its more famous cousin Ta Prohm, Preah Khan is slowly being taken over by trees. The result is a very photogenic temple that does not get the high volumes of visitors that some of the close-in and more famous temples receive. It's just outside the massive Angkor Thom complex, so it's not like it's way out of the way. If you have a three-day pass it should be one of your stops.

Hidden Treasure. What a beautiful place to visit, our tour guide took us to this amazing place with a picturesque temple. The overgrowth of the trees and the amazing photo opportunities made this place one of the highlights of our two day tour through Siem Reap. Our party of 8 loved this place more than Ta Phrom. Preach Khan not nearly as touristy either, just beautiful.
Temple dedicated to the King's Father. A flat temple (not the pyramid temple style). Still majestic and worth taking a trip to visit. DO not miss this

Small perfection. Visited in November two thousand and FOUR! it seems not to be on the shorter popular tour routes today. It remains in memory for its exquisite details; we took photos of delicate inscriptions on the walls, rather than of imposing towers etc. A more intimate atmosphere than the greater temples, which (we hope) it has probably kept.

A temple less touristed. Sure EVERY temple in the Angkor complex has tourists and groups, but I found this one to be quite a bit less crowded and still very atmospheric. I really liked it and would definitely suggest making the time, to spend some time there!

Nice carvings. One of the temples close to the center of the ever growing city and in the proximity of Angkor Thom. It's a nicely decorated temple that one can visit within 1 - 1 1/2 h and not to be missed.
Doors like mirror. Huge temple like a maze. It has those well aligned doors (but different in height) that stretch out from north to south and east to west. Lovely interior.

Sublime, underrated compared to other sites.. This temple system was one of my favorites because it was less crowded and I could actually enjoy the place without having to line up behind a tour group or bunch of yoga-pants.The perimeter of the site has trails where you can actually walk around away from the crowds. There are iconic headless statues that are on the edges that many miss. There is jungle right close to to the side s of this complex which makes it more mysterious. The center pathway through the temple is congested and narrow. Take an alternative path around!
worth a visit. some of the lesser known temples are incredible and not so many tourists around. This makes it easier to see everything and let it soak in
nice. as all angkor temples i adore Preah Khan. But it is not main one, not must see when you are in angkor complex

30 TONS OF GOLD+SILVER AND GEMS !. King ......Nr 7 made this fantastic temple to pay homage to his father.It used to be the administrative centre and the walls og the central part show numerous holes which were used to hold the plates of pure gold. (Estimated to be 30 tonns!)The temple is like a smaller version of Pra Thom,but less busy.It has not been fully restored and shows fantastic Banyana trees that still encompass some of the walls It has numerous fantastic carvings and has a mixture of buddistic and hindu architecture.MAKE SURE YOUR GUIDE TAKES YOU HERE !
I love this temple!. We went to this temple after lunch. Big trees shaded our walk way path towards the temple.The cloudy afternoon light made this temple look dramatic and mysterious.
Good for a short visit. Part of what its called the big circuit, this is a good place to visit, a short stay would be enough, not so much around but still interesting.

Like a less busy version of Ta Promh in some ways. I wouldn't suggest coming here in place of Ta Prohm, as it is undoubtedly less spectacular. However, it is in a similar style and makes a good complement to Ta Prohm.

Lots of interesting things to see at Preah Khan. Our guide took us on a stroll down a well defined path in a wooded area. After 5-10 minutes we came upon a gate to Preah Khan. Preah Khan is an interesting temple with much to see and photograph. Highly recommend a visit to this temple. We spent about an hour going through the temple, although it is not fully restored you can walk through the interior corridors of the temple. There are several temples on the grounds including one with what looks like Greek columns.

Adventure to the Cambodian countryside. We hired a tour guide to take us to Preah Khan, which I would highly recommend. Visiting requires a 2.5 hour drive into the Cambodian countryside from Siem Reap, and then a 4x4 ride up to the top of a ridge overlooking the Cambodian-Thai border. This is a disputed area, so the first thing you will notice is many Cambodian Army personnel guarding the site. As unnerving as this might sound, the Army folks blend in pretty well with the scenery. And the scenery is amazing. Unlike the Buddhist temples around Siem Reap, Preah Khan was a Hindu temple to Shiva. It buzzes with energy, if you are into that kind of thing. These are definitely ruins--although not as old as the temples at Angkor, no restoration has been done here. But it is still an amazing place to visit.

Almost everything united in one temple. Preah Khan has almost all the ingrediënts you can find in the Angkor temples but it's much more quiet there than at the more famous sites. Specially interesting for a first visit of the Angkor complex or for those with little time

magnificent!. all of the temples in siem reap are jaw dropping work of art. All the walls have intricate drawings of history. I would think alien did that but no. i guess people from the ancient times are more advanced than people now.

Temple Ruins. Preah Khan hasn't been restored like some of the other temples, so much of it remains in ruins which somehow adds to the interest of the place.I was able to visit Angkor Wat, Bayon, Preach Khan and Ta Prohm on the same day, using a tuk-tuk driver and a tour guide. It made for a full but very interesting day.

Beautiful Temple. The intricate designs of this temple were awe inspiring. I would recommend getting a guide so that they can tell you some of the history behind each temple as you go. It truly adds to the experience.

Busy but worth it. This temple is good to walk around and explore, don't just stick to the straight path. It was very busy inside and appeared popular with local people. Despite it being one of the busiest temples we went to it was still lovely. We went in the morning, it may be quieter in the afternoon.

Splendour in the Jungle. This was one of my favourite temples, with features not found in other temples. Many photo opportunities without the crowds. It had several passages, interesting carvings of apsara dancers and garudas, a linga (phallic symbol) which cannot be found in other temples, stone rubbles, and ruins of a 2-storey Roman-like structure (said to be a library).You would feel like Indiana Jones or Lara Croft as you explore the different sections of the temple. Not recommended for the physically challenged though, as it will require walking along uneven stones and some climbing. Banyan trees with their massive root systems claiming the structure can be seen. I spent around 2 hours exploring this gem amidst the forest (with fluttering butterflies and dragonflies and the sound of birds).

Well worth the journey!. This temple is further out from Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom, but it's definitely worth the visit. We hit Angkor Wat on a Saturday, but went to Preah Khan on a Monday. We're not sure if it was the choice of day or the location, but there were very few tourists at Preah Khan when we got there. It's a magnificent temple, and is quite different from the ones we'd seen before. There is a long hall that you can see the end of (barely) and walk through at your leisure. It's another awesome experience at the Angkor National Park. By the way, we went to the park three times over the course of four days. We bought a three-day pass for $40 (the price of two days if you pay for them separately), and we had a week to use it. That was a very good idea - highly recommended!
1 day pass includede. Do all of these temples in 1 day - but watch the temperature and humidity and take plenty of water and don't forget that toilets are few and far between!

Definitely worth a visit. Some quite unique structures compared to the rest of the Ankor area temples. Temple swallowing tree at the rear is quite amazing too. Definitely a spot that you can spend at least an hour on.

Great site like the others. This temple is also rich in history like most of the temples. This is the one site that has probably got me thinking how rich Cambodia was in the past. I remember our guide telling us about a section with a lot of holes where gems used to be and probably looked really good with fire lit a the center. Although the structure of this temple is just similar with most of the other temples, there are also distinct and unique structure found in this temple, so you might want to check this out.

Great for pics, excellent temple. P.K. is a goldmine for photo opportunities, much like Bayon Temple. You can get lost for hours to photo-document a temple that lays in ruins. A tour guide would be helpful to get a more historical understanding of the details behind the scenes.

Don't miss the Great Circuit on your 2nd day!. We actually enjoyed the 2nd day of ruins more than the 1st as we were able to spend time alone with some of the stones. (Fewer crowds) and this place is great to explore.

Angkor Grand Tour - quieter than the madness of Angkor Watt and the Mini Tour. On our second visit to the temples at Angkor, Preah Khan was the first stop on our Angkor Grand Tour - a trip round 4 of the quieter temples in the complex. Although still busy on the morning of our visit, a Saturday morning in peak season, it was by far less crowded than Angkor Watt and Bayon looked when we hurried by in our tuktuk. This temple is equally as beautiful and grand as the more famous ones in the complex, and also has an interesting visitor's centre with some information about the conservation and restoration work which happens on site. The stone faces are equally as beautiful and ornate as those in the Bayon temple, so if you want to avoid the crowds, I'd recommend heading here. Continuing on the Grand Tour only takes another hour or so, as the remaining temples are small, but well worth it for another look at this ancient civilisation and some better photo opportunities with less tourists around.
Ancient site. Very Ancient complex of rooms and Temple areas. Still Good condition and quite a lot to see. No major climbing required either
Our favourite temple. Get here early in the morning to get the best experience and pictures. Far less crowded than the tomb raider temple and in my opinion, more beautiful!

One of the best!. Wonderful, atmospheric temple. Give yourself lots of time to explore this huge site. Our guide took us to shrines we never would have found on our own and it's possible that you would not be allowed to find them so deep into the labyrinth they hide. I found a beautiful Buddha relief that our guide had never seen. Go slowly and take it in. We went in the early morning and there were big crowds and tour groups taking up a lot of space, but it thins out quickly once they march down the center gallery and back. There is a lot here. Expect 2 hours easy.

Architecturally very similar to Ta Prohm.. The meaning of Preah Khan is 'sacred sword,’ It is full of carvings, many passages and great for photos. Ist original purpose was as a Buddhist monastery and school. Ta Prohm is architecturally very similar to this temple. The Buddha images as with many of the temples were vandalised.A really interesting temple to explore.

Very beaytiful temple, a must to visit. Also here, go early in the morning, even then there are many tourist. Dont forget to see at least one garuda on the outside wall of the temple. Visit al the places inside, not only those where walk the tourgroupes. Amazing decorations

A great Maze. Quiet surprised by the original temple, which has a lot of different things you do not expect from the outside. The inside is a funny maze that the kids loved. Some nice carvings and a small temple that looks like a Roman one.... Worth it !

A Beautiful and mysterious jungle temple, one of the better temples!. A "midsize" temple compared to other temples. Beautiful and mysterious still with large elements from the jungle. Large areas are still relatively "intact" compared to several other temples. Certainly in class with and sometimes even better than Ta Prohm temple and with a lot less visitors. Well worth a visit!
Small but Classic. We love checking out temple ruins & this one is well worth the visit. All the temples in this area are interesting.
One of the best in Angkor.. This is a good one. Lots of photo ops. Similar to Ta Prom. I did the big loop by bicycle and this temple was the best on that loop.

The "Sacred Sword" temple Preah Khan. Enter the temple from the west, then make the long and winding walk along the central axis, exiting through the east gate where you'll see a massive spoong tree (like a banyan tree). From here, make your way back through to the west entrance and your transport.Preah Khan was built around the same time as Angkor Thom, and like it was conceived as a whole city, though on a smaller scale. It was erected on the site of an important military victory and its outer perimeter is guarded by 72 stone garudas (winged mythological creatures depicted throughout Southeast Asia).This temple was also covered with huge tree forest and you can still see the stumps hugging the structures in the squeezing grip. Many walls have spaces for statues that were probably destroyed or just taken away. Rubble is everywhere but there is also an easy access to the main areas and well walked path. Preah Khan is just one of the must-see temples…

Adventure. Preah Khan is the most exciting tempel of Angkor Wat , you can explore this huge complex and find at each corner new atonishing sculpures or places where people still worship some apsaras .The point is also that this temple is not crowded like Angkor Wat or Ta prom so that you can go your way all alone really EXCITING

My favourite of them all . It's so difficult to put in words how beautiful and peaceful this place is. I wasn't expecting much from the pictures I'd seen, but that's because the pictures just don't capture the beauty. Walking up to Preah Khan there are hundreds of dragonflies. The place is so quiet (when we went, at about 2.30pm), and the light catches the buildings in a lovely way. I won't try and describe it any more, as it won't do it justice. Just go!!

Very interesting temple complex, more quiet tan Angkor Wat or Angkor Thom. On our last full day in Siem Reap we had hired a tuk-tuk (with driver of course) to take us to a number of interesting temples outside the tourist vortex of Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom. The first stop was at Preah Khan. Preah Khan is not just a temple but a vast temple complex, which was functioning as a real village, with all the village functions. The complex is more than 8 centuries old. Everywhere you can see the struggle between the man made structures and the encroaching nature. I focused on the multitude of well preserved stone carvings. I have added several pictures to this review to give an impression of this attraction. Worth the journey.

Peaceful, less crowds. Smaller with less crowds, I found this one much more peaceful. It was one of my favourites. In Angkor you are spoilt for choice with big temples, but the smaller ones have a certain charm to them.
You Can Get Templed Out. After seeing the larger temples, this one did not impress me. It is like Ankor Wat on a much smaller scale, yet still pretty crowded.

Most atmospheric Angkorian temple?. One of the most atmospheric temples at Angkor. It is very popular with tour groups but it was fairly quiet around 11am. The temple is a bewildering jumble of dark corridors, beautiful sculptures, unusual collonaded buildings, and tree roots tearing through massive walls. It is a huge complex so give yourself plenty of time to enjoy it. Large groups began to pour in around 11.30.
Vast. This is one of the biggest temples we've visited, and the grounds are gorgeous. Allow at least one hour to go round and make sure you have some water with you.

Combines Highlights of Several Temples. Probably the best way to sum up Preah Khan is that it seemed to combine a few highlights from other sites into one area. Namely, it has impressive trees in the ruins like the "jungle temples", huge blocks of ruins like Beng Mealea and impressive walls and libraries like many sites. One unique aspect is a two-story library that is still largely standing. I would say it could be skipped if you only have one day to tour; it's well worth a visit on a two-day itinerary.

Less crowded, excellent carvings. We went here early in the day, and there were only a few other people. (It was our second stop on the "counter-clockwise" tour after Ta Prohm.) I can see why the buses skip this place because it's harder to walk through quickly, with a lot of stepping over stones to transit the interior. There are no boardwalks or other aids for accessibility. We found the apsara done in the likeness of the queen (by tipping one of the guards.) The interior lintel of Hall of Dancers was beautiful. The lack of crowds was a real blessing.

My favorite but I only got to 3. This was my favorite between Angkor Wat, Preah Khan and Banteay Srei. There were very few people there so we could hear birds singing all the time and see monkeys running around. We were able to explore freely and it was beautiful there.

A Snapshot back Down the Centuries. TO take a walk round the Preah Khan temple site is to enjoy a special experience.Many of the larger sites are more famous, but Preah Khan has just that subtle extra touch of how it was centuries ago, just that fraction more feeling that you are exploring a site which has still only just been discovered.It has the ruins to inspire, the carvings to marvel at and the snaking invasion of trees and roots to draw comparison with Ta Prohm, but it also has something which leaves a lasting memory.This derives from sections which quite clearly are untouched by modern man as I found out when I explored the temple for myself.My very good guide piloted me carefully round all the main points of interest and some that few tourists ever get to see and it was while we were in one of the less explored parts which was almost deserted of tourists that I came across a hidden courtyard.This to me epitomised how it must have been years ago when the scale of all these ruins was first being appreciated.For a start, I didn’t even know the courtyard was there. It was only betrayed by a single waving frond of grass, enough to make me curious enough to find out where it could grow because all around was stone.It took quite a bit of effort but I clambered up high enough to look over the wall in front of me and there revealed was the courtyard, heavily carpeted with grass which was growing on a tumbled mass of wall and roof masonry.The walls were beautifully carved and it was clear that no-one would see this hidden gem easily far less go down into it which was pretty much impossible because the lowest remaining wall masonry was at least a dozen feet high and it was much higher in parts.I felt like I’d found a snapshot back down the centuries and it made a big impression on me.So did the rest of the site be it tumbles of stone, stunning carvings, the might of giant trees and the root systems or the impressiveness of restored sections. Even those sections closed off to the public because of their dangerous condition still had a forlorn allure of their own.The walk through the site from gate to gate included a meeting with one young woman, baby in arms, selling shawls. Never have I received such a delighted smile for the donation of a single dollar. Put life in perspective.Don’t miss a tour of this special place because you’ll leave with some special memories.

My highlight temple. For our family that complex was the highlight of all the temples. We went in the morning and could explore the place nearly on our own. You can work round a huge area and can see very lonesome corners. Very green and with an untouched impression.
Massive structure. The temple is spread over a large area. Amazing sculptures. Long walk from west to the east gate. Amazing.
Beautiful temple off the beaten trail. A gorgeous and special place with WAY FEWER tourists crawling over every inch (as with Angkor Wat and Bayon during Chinese New Year.) Very much worth the trip.

Best of the rest . We did this temple, and a number of others nearby, on our first day, because they are a bit less impressive than the big 3. Preah Khan is a good number 4, very large, a lot to see and in good condition. We took more than an hour to see the whole thing.
Great as it's largely off the tour-bus route. We went at 3.30-5.30pm, and managed to avoid the huge tour bus groups that plague Angkor Wat. It's a mini Ta Promh without the crowds

Another example of Khmer building expertise. Most of this temple is in ruin but what is left gives a good idea of what it was. Notable are the 4 concentric walls that demarcated the different areas used by for different purposes - shrine, living quarters for monks, students and royal attendants.

A much less busier version of Ta Prohm. Lovely memories of this temple and well worth the visit Was able to have a much more relaxed nosey round everywhere compared to ta prohm whichfelt a bit rushed..

Guide saved 'the best for last'. We visited after lunch, and even in high season, had the place nearly to ourselves. This is a great temple for both visiting and photography, with some 'hidden queens' that the guide showed us (ducking through relatively short passageways to a dead end with a pile of collapsed stones was a true 'Indiana Jones' experience.)

Higher on my list!. This temple is not as highly rated as some others but was my favorite. There were plenty of spots for climbing and exploring the many original details. There was not much of a crowd.

A place worth to spend some hour.... The Preah Khan temple complex situated at the northern edge of the Angkor Archaeological Park is one of the most significant buildings erected during the ancient Khmer empire. Dedicated by the great king Jayavarman VII to his father in 1191, Preah Khan serves today as an outstanding example of a large linear temple complex in a dense jungle setting. Rectangular in shape and occupying 138 acres, Preah Khan’s boundaries are defined by a protective moat and fortified walls adorned by monumental carved stone garudas—eagle-like divine beings. The temple complex includes entryways, towers, ceremonial spaces, courtyards, shrines, and a variety of connecting corridors. Additional special features of Preah Khan include its two-story pavilion, the once-bronze-plated sanctum sanctorum, and its Hall of Dancers.

Sprawling beautiful ruins amidst natural pretty setting. Enjoyed these sprawling ruins in their quite, natural setting more than angkor wat! the spiritual beauty of the architecture and the sounds of nature in the midst of beautiful trees made me feel very peaceful and meditative inside! Wish could have spent the full day reading, painting, picnicking here- but its a short trip to siem reap and had other attractions to cover! Maybe another time!

Favorite Temple. This isn a fantastic temple with a deep jungle feel. Seems less visited than the other temples and easy to explore. A lot see in this overgrown and crumbling temple. This and Tab Prohm are my favorite temples.
Beautiful Temple. Another breathtaking temple in Cambodia. Go early for best light. Take your time walking through, lots to see. One of my favorites of 12 temples I saw while in Siem Reap for 3 days
Excellent. Outstanding ruin with great trees and crumbling walls. It tells you a lot about the building and about 12C Cambodia.
Must See. The temple located in front of beautiful lake. There are line of headless statue welcome the visitors to this temple.
Go in the morning. As with most of the temples, you will want to get there in the morning because a} it gets really hot and b} the crowds really pick up in the afternoon.
Another must see!. The smaller temples are in many ways more accessible, fewer people and easier to explore, and this is one of the better ones so if you have the time make sure you see this.
This was my favorite temple in Siem Reap. I loved it so much, I climbed on top of it. They told me I would get arrested. So I climbed back down. It was totes worth it.
For his father!. This temple was constructed by the king, for his father. Do not miss the so called "roman" construction in the temple, believed to be a treasure room.

Labyrinth Zone. The aesthetic of this glorious temple is spectacular and stands out from the other temples even after a whole day of seeing nothing but. It is built like a maze and was the home for king Jayavaraman VII to honour his father, it is quieter in the evening and was the perfect final stop on our second day in the Angkor area.

Not to be missed. If you go here, come in the morning from the east or the evening from the west to enjoy the best possible lighting. Rather crowd-free and an amazing maze to explore. The temple has some very good apsara carvings worth seeing. The “greek style” pillar building is different from anything else and you can climb the building behind it and get a very nice view. Well worth a visit!
See it because all temples are beautiful and different. I explored it because although you see many other temples, each one is beautiful and unique in its own way.
Beautiful . Another great temple to see. Here too you can see the roots of huge trees zigzagging bewteen the stone of the buildings. Much calmer than some of the other temples.

Amazing!. I know that so much looting of antiquities has happened and I felt it most here. Although selling to the black market has been going on since time immemorial, it's really sad... Although most of these temples are shadows of their original forms, I can't help but admire what men accomplished at that period in time.

Interesting Echo rooms!. Another temple, this is where we discovered that the temple has an echo part where it was used before by the king to tell his people of his arrival. A piece of information from one of the guards.

First Temple in the Grand Circuit. When you talk to the local in the tourism industry, the Angkor Temples are divided into 2 different circuit, the grand or big circuit and the small or inner circuit. With sufficient time to cover both circuits and few other outside these circuits, the visitor will be most rewarding. Preah Khan is the first temple in the big circuit. The size of the temple is large, most tuk tuk will drop the passengers at the west gate and pick them up at the east gate. The Lonely Planet recommended 2 hours to see the whole complex but an hour will give sufficient coverage without missing all the key sights. Much of the walking will be through various gates, doors and courts. There are interesting sights abound.

Impressive scale and a hidden gem. This temple has been taken over by nature, similar to Ta Prohm, but it is larger and more atmospheric.There are unique boundary stones on the approach and some nice carvings.All around are a tumble of stones which makes you wonder how they ever reconstruct some of these temples.No throngs of tourists here so take your time and enjoy.

Climb! It's fin. Beautiful, am so thankful it was a little more kept than "Ancient Angkor (River Books Guides)" suggested. Way easier to navigate than suggested, still rugged. Tres everywhere, make you cautious about exploring beyond wooden pathways, however still entices you to do so. Guides/guards super friendly.
Ancient Temple. Be prepared to walk alot. Hugh build up. Very old and falling structure being propped up. Very uneven floor with countless steps. Wear comfortable shoes.
Hidden gem!. While most people would focus on Angkor Wat, I highly recommend this - my girlfriend and I visited most temples there and this is the one we love the most!

picturesque temple. take lots of pictures but avoid the noontime sun. everywhere, it's worth taking a photo! try to avoid the main times when tourists go here. ask your tuktuk driver for better information

My favorite temple. There are so many wonderful temples, but I think I loved this one most. It's a romantic place, partly in ruins, in the middle of the jungle. Like in Ta Prohm the temple is bound by some massive roots, but there are way less visitors here, which is why it makes for a very nice and stress-free visit.
My favourite temple. Absolutely superb photo opportunities here. The icing on the cake are the monasteries where monks are kind and friendly enough to let you photograph them.

Preserved version of Ta Prohm. Unlike Ta Prohm where the tree roots have been left to take over the temple Preah Khan is being restored to its former greatness. The highlights are the Temple of Four Faces and the Hall of Dancers.

Another temple on the must see list. A temple built by a Hindu king for his father. It is a big complex but essentially in ruins. The gates to the temple are made smaller and lower as one comes towards the centre of the temple. Apparently, this was made so that visitors have to bend and bow their heads in respect as they approach the centre.

Amazing Place. This temple was a pleasant surprise after Angkorwat and Bayon. Completely different, in some places a merging of styles filtered by intricate attention to detail
Tip: make sure you have a tour guide, Angkorwat pass, sunscreen, sunhat , water and camera

Reminds me of Ta Prohm. This temple kind of reminds me of Ta Prohm, but a bit more temple than trees. It's still a beautiful place nonetheless. It's also much smaller so it's a nice little stop in Angkor.

relax. It might take a longer to reach it (compare to Bayon and Angkor Wat) but it is worth as there is not much people and you can take your time to admire it.An advice if you are with montain bike you can reach the temple by the forest and arrive directly inside otherwise you need to let your bike at the main entrance

Architectural delight. It does take a little time to grasp the layout of the temple. At first sight it seems a set of unending doorways but yeah has two to the side and they are endless and it goes on an amazing puzzle of corridors and doorways. beautiful when it sinks in.

One of great temples we enjoyed. . On grand circle. We visited after our sunrise viewing at angkor wat. Early morning lighting is great for ordinary phone camera. Lot of large tall trees. Reasonable quite at this high season. We got in from west and out at east gate.The cleaners often want to show you and take you around for free but expect $1-2 tips for 10 min work or walk. So if you don't have small bills think before you follow them.Good visit. Suggest not miss this one.

Beautiful temple without the crowd. The temple walls have a unique hue of red, yellow and grey. It's very interesting almost seems like each stone used was different but they are actualzly the same. There is a sacred shrine inside where locals visit for prayers as well. It's the only temple with the diffrent shades of color on the walls. Beautiful and magnificent temple.
Quiet and beautiful temple. This is my most favorite temple for me during my trip to Cambodia. It is located in the jungle and very quiet peaceful place.

a huge temple... not on the main list for some but it should be. a huge temple to visit. and very special too, if you have some extra time make sure you come here and make sure you enter in one side and exit the other to just realize how big it is

Each one a new amazement. Temples, temples, temples each one a stunning amazement. It is amazing how huge these temples are being built before machinery, all the rocks from many miles away. Another great visit with fewer tourists.
Ta Prohm minus the crowd. this is probably my favorite one because it's less popular and so you can actually take time to look around and take good pictures

As nice as Ta Prohm. We enjoyed Preah Khan about as much as Ta Prohm. They are both kept in a state showing some of the remoteness and how the jungle has taken over, rather than being completely restored. This really adds to the mystery and atmosphere. Super place.

Preah Khan. A master piece by King J VII. Preah Khan is of good size and variations in terms of architectures. There are lots of photography spots that good for those who are into photography. Even the locals go there for their wedding pictures! : )
