great place. this temple had lots of long vaulted corridors of carvings and the grounds around it where fab , its one of the largest complexes
Mesmerizing View. The design of each temple inside Angkor Wat are actually different and unique in their own way. Preah Khan architectural design is stunning and calming at the same time.

another interesting temple. Definitely worth a visit. Interesting history, as with all the temples. It has a "hidden" tomb of a princess deep inside. Ask the lady sitting in the middle of the temple where it is.
Stunning and calm. Gets overlooked by the other temples. But this one is large and unspoilt and has a calm serenity about it that would make it great to go to after one of the busier temples.

A part of your tour, do it. Every Spot has the Guide that makes livig the experience true time possible, if you feel it is too much to have, Make a research before going so that you can understand about the place

my favourite temple around Angkor. Stunning place, not so crowded as Bayon for example. It's in Big Circuit so not everyone come here but I loved this place the most. I adore places like this, where you can be alone even if it's just for a while. Definitely worth to come :)

Great temple with its own personality. This temple snuck up on us! We didn't expect it to be so big and so charming. It was incredible! And despite being just north of Angkor Thom, it was very sparsely visited. We entered from the west and were kind of put off by the local vendors hawking the temple rubbings. We were told that only three Cambodian families are allowed to do rubbings. Never verified this, but after a bit of research making sure the rubbings are legal, we did purchase one. As they are done on rice paper, they travel beautifully. Preah Khan is a great temple to see and has fewer crowds but isn't as far afield as others.

BEST Temple in Angkor Wat & Angkor Thom Compleax. Well, surely you will be visiting lots of temples here in Siem Ream, lots of highlight.But Preak Khan is the BEST. Don't miss it. It's hard to describe but if you like to see temple in peace, Peah Khan has lots of beautiful trees and carving. Less Tourist here. If you have a good taste you will like this temple A LOTS.

Less well known but well worth a visit. Preah Kahn is located on the northern edge of the main group of temples at Angkor. As you walk up to it from the west side which is the route used by most visitors, it appears small but actually turns out to be one of the largest complexes. As such it readily absorbs tourists and we found it one of the least crowded and more relaxed places to visit. We were there about 3pm when it quite hot and maybe that suppressed the visiting numbers. The central corridor is amazing. It gives the impression of being like in an infinitely reflecting mirror. At the east side of the complex there is a massive tree that is similar to the one that everyone lines up to have their picture taken in front of at Ta prohm. Only for this one you don’t need to line up and you can get right up to it (and on the back side of the building stick your head up a hole in it if you are so inclined! – see photo). It is possible to walk through the site and be picked up at the far (east) side. Or do it in the reverse direction.

Lesser-known true treasure. Preah Khan is a bit of a ways out, but the longer drive lets you see more countryside (and it's nowhere near as far as, say, the Rolous), so it's no big deal, and SO WORTH IT. It's a big one, with both Hindu and Buddhist elements (look for the shrinking doors on one side!), well-preserved carvings, and tons of atmospheric jumbly collapsed piles of stones to get your Tomb Raider on. Even at the hottest time of day there are enough tunneled passages and shady courtyards that you can spend time here without collapsing from heatstroke. Allow a good chunk of time to explore - we actually went back another day after sprinting through at the end of a grand tour the first time. As with other temples, the earlier you show up, the fewer other people will be there with you. WARNING! Though some temples and sites have fairly clean and modern bathrooms quite close, the nearest restroom to Preah Khan is a full kilometer down a dusty road well outside the perimeter, so if there's any chance you might feel nature's call, stop off at one before going in!

Huge temple. Our driver suggested this temple on our way back from Banteay Srei and so glad he did otherwise we would have missed it. Huge temple.....corridors went on and on. I understand it is the 2nd largest temple in the area.

Big temple not to be missed. To me the most intriguing feature of this temple is the multiple doorways lined up so that you could see 'through' the whole temple. It is like you are watching to infinity or there is a mirror further away from you etc. Reserve some time to explore it further, maybe 45-60 mins.

AngkorTemples. This is one of many Wats & Palaces to be found in the Siem Reap area. All are a magnificent mix of architecture, history, art , and spirituality.
Plan on at least two days to seem them with three giving you time for all
A quieter temple. A less crowded experience allowed for more time to reflect on the architectural wonder. Loved the blissful atmosphere.

lovely temple - put it on your to do list. I like many other writers really liked this temple, i went first thing in the morning and there were few people there, and you feel like a real adventurer exploring this amazing site... there are lots of nooks and crannies and i loved the courtyard.It might not have the grandeur of angkor wat or bayon temple but it has a great feel to it and far more personal than the larger temples.

Preah Khan and will.. Nice temple that forms part of the over al archeological area. Preah Khan is quieter than some of the other temples. However, no less impressive. The entire area is framed with forest and provides a quieter experience to visitors. Preah Khan is a good option when combine Angkor Thom.

Most beautiful temple at Angkor Wat. This temple is really not to be missed. It is not as touristy as the others, when we visited there were barely any other tourists there and it just added to the magic of the place. The ruins have not been restored to the same extent as the other temples, which gives it a feeling of being deserted compared to the others.

Interesting examples of heritage conservation. The temple is a good start at the park given its "medium" size and richness. There are beautiful freezes and reliefs throughout and one can find solace in some of the courtyards despite the continuous traffic of tourists. A good time to visit is before 12pm though. As a heritage conservator my attention was drawn to the vegetation growing through some of the walls as well as the restoration work. The latter as one can see from my photo is a clear example of ethics going mad - the need for new additions to be easily distinguishable from the original.

Favourite location. Preah Khan is so worth the extra distance! I loved that you look in one direction and you see endless door ways and the other you see a pile of rubble from what has not been reconstructed. It was also delightful not to have hordes of tourists there like at places like Bayon. This is my new favourite temple (my last visit 15 years ago, it was Ta Prhom).

Smaller temple, but well worth visiting. By chance we timed this one perfectly after seeing Angkor Wat and Bayon in the morning - most of the tour buses were on their lunch break (12:30/1:00pm), so Preah Kahn was really peaceful and quiet. The temple is big but on a single level with lots of skinny hallways so it's easy to navigate through and it's set in the serene grounds of Angkor Thom. It's quite exposed to the elements so pack your hat and sunscreen.We were also fortunate to catch the annual procession of 3000 Buddhist monks making their way through Angkor Thom receiving donations, which added a great pop of colour to our temple snaps.This was our second favourite temple, with Beng Mealea taking first place.
A great starter temple. It was a good temple to see before seeing those big 2: Angkor Wat and Ta Prohm, because it included elements from both. And there are fewer crowds.

Be careful of locals inside. A local guy inside the temple will try to assist you by giving you unsolicited pointers and facts about certain parts of the temple. He tries to take you pictures. At the end he just wants a simple gratuity not below a roller. He does not take local money

Not as big as the other temples. A smaller temple compared to the others, but it still remains impressive. The temple is also well-maintained, but not as crowded as the main Angkor Wat temple. Still recommended for a visit!
Favourite. Easily my favourite temple of the complex. It's all in ruins, meaning they didn't take much care of it until now, leaving us with the sensation we're lost in the jungle and in time.

Add it to your list. Another structure you should not miss, this one is as unique as the others and very beautiful. Enjoyed exploring all the rooms and passages and the grounds beyond. Took some great photos in the morning light.
One of the main temples! very beautiful to visit. This temple is one of the main temples in Ankor Wat. It's nice to walk around and see all the beautiful details.

Amazing colors in a smaller temple complex; excellent!. The orange/reddish color of the stones used in the building of this temple complex make it unique among all the available temples in the Siem Reap area. We went here on the way back from the mountain streams and it was a gem! There were few tourists here and we loved the quiet solitude of this place. There is also good food and souvenir shopping nearby. I highly recommend visiting this place!
One of the best temple with a large tree growing on. Among of hundreds temple in Seam Reap, Preah Khan is the temple which represents to Buddhism. The view is very nice and amazing with East Baray.

Magnificent Temple. Our tour guide Rany brought us here and it was another large temple that had so many interesting sides to it.It is one of the less visited temples but in my opinion one of the most spectacular,having a guide means you get more of an insight into the temples history as well as having the knowledge of where to go for the best photo opportunities.Not to be missed.

Similar to Ta Prohm, but bigger and better. Another extremely big temple, 800m from east gate to west gate and north to south. Walking through the corridors it looks like you could be victim to a cave in of the stone ceilings, as they are just pieced together and somehow still intact, in most places anyway. Being lots less tourists here, helped you appreciate the experience even more, and ended up being my favourite. It had a lovely unkempt connection to nature which added to the experience. Highly recommend adding this one to your itinerary.
A place for ancient armours. This is a place for storing ancient armours as well as military decisions. However, without some guides briefing you the history of this place, you just can't imagine it.

Better than Ta Prohnm!. One of the bigger temple cities in the Angkor area, but less visited. Most people go to Ta Prohm to see the tree trunks covering the ruins. I can surely recommend Preah Khan to see that. It's much quieter and in my opinion also more impressive.

Quiet, beautiful temple but be careful of off duty policemen . Our 6th temple of the day, it was getting hot so nice to have a temple with Covered pathways. Lots to see and get lost in. We went by tuk tuk and bought a guide book, we seemed to miss the noisy tour groups which was nice. However we got bothered by an off duty policeman wanting to guide us around, we politely said no but he followed us. We had heard about this scam we saw him doing it later to another couple. He will charge you a lot in the end, just say no and walk away. Be prepared for fake guides that charge you, sellers calling you to buy things and book sellers. But that's at every popular attraction. Please don't give money to the children they are working for someone the money won't go to them and they will go out and do the same thing the next day. Remember to promote good tourism in the country.

Amazing temple. It's another amazing temple. What impressed me most was when we walked along the main corridor with numerous craved lintels, the corridor was so long that the farthest end seemed like the reflection of a mirror.

Favourite temple!!. This temple is my favourite, in my opinion it is better than angkor wat, just as it has a better vibe to it. Most of the structure has collapsed which is saddening, however it would have been filled with life long ago.Definitely see this temple! It's long and full of history. I couldn't believe my eyes when i continued walking through it.
One of my favourtes. After Ta Prohm this was my favourite temple. It was sprawling and totally stunning and much less busy than some of the others. Would definitely recommend.

Our favorite temple!!. Of all the temples we visited this was by far our favorite! It is much quieter than Ta Prohm or Bayon. The jungle is taking over and many parts are crumbling. It makes for a fascinating place to explore!

SPECIAL MEMORIES. Out of all the temples, Preah Khan would have to be my favourite for several reasons. One being a little less overcrowded and the main one is the beautiful "Lady of Preah Khan" who sits quietly in an alcove offering blessings.This delightful soul is 78 and alone. She makes her living by her blessings. This is my third visit to see her and I hope to see her again. She is part of the temple; spiritually....The temple itself is a lot smaller than many of the more popular. I think that is why it is special.

My new favourite place. Preah Kahn is like the sister temple to Ta Prohm but without the tourist trap. This temple is beautiful, not so busy and you can still feel the mystical energies resonating around you. If you come here I suggest you keep a look out for the sweet old lady by the name of Ael, who does blessings in exchange for $1. She is 78 years old, lives alone and is very poor... It was lovely to see her there on both my trips to Cambodia...I hope she is still there for years to come.

Don't miss this lovely temple. We visited this lovely temple as part of a All Points East tour of Cambodia with a small group (just 6 of us). The local guide they employed really made the whole tour of the ancient temples so enjoyable. We walked through the peaceful jungle setting , all alone and then suddenly were confronted with the most amazing ruined gateway and tumbledown causeway. The huge blocks of stone are everywhere - how did anyone lifted them into position.? We walked into the temple itself , through all the multiple door ways and corridors . marvelling at the remaining roofs which looked so precarious.
Another kind of temple.. This temple is a funny maze, in good state of conservation and presents refined sculptures of all sorts of gods and Buddhas. It is not as crowdy as the other temples.

Another amazing part of the Angkor puzzle. Perfect day for visiting Preah Kahn, the complex built by Jayavarman VII in honor of his father. A long, shady white sand path leads to the temple area, where the ruins of the temple are the last remains of a thriving city that was a center of learning.Plenty of wall sculpture tells the story of that period, the height of the Angkor empire, and plenty of photo opportunities present themselves.Most visitors walk straight through and out another shady path in the back to the shores of the baray (artificial water body). Tuk-tuk drivers usually drop you at the front gate and pick you up at the back, avoiding a turnaround hike.My visit today, my second, was helped by cloudy skies and a brief shower, but as at most of the Angkor temples it can be brutally hot, especially at midday.Tip: Take a couple bottles of water and buy a couple of cotton kramas (the ubiquitous Khmer scarf) -- the kramas are indispensable on a hot day in dealing with the sweat pouring off your head. Remember to bring your Angkor pass; you will be checked.

Very cool temple - take a good guide. This was the first temple we visited. We arrived just after a couple of tour buses, so our guide took us on a path through the jungle and round to another entrance. As we rested, an ethereal child joined us, stopping a few metres away and watching (her parents were gathering fruit in the forest). We then toured the temple, only meeting others at the centre and we we exited via the main entrance.A good guide makes all the difference!

Hold the light. Another must see temple with its beautiful carvings .Entering the west gate go left of the bridge and take pictures with temple reflection in the water .Hold the light above the stuppa in the centre of the temple . Visit in each direction from the centre point . North direction - square with nice temple and high tree . Outside east side with beautiful sight of temple and tree . Once outside , walk towards the water and relax , enjoy the scenary

Love this place. Bigger version of Tomb Raider temple. We loved this place. It is a bigger version of Ta Prohm where Tomb Raider was filmed. Enter from the West to cross the moat and then explore the mix of broken temples, the restored central complex the stunning Apsara dancing carvings and then massive trees growing around and through the temples. Love this place.

ANother good place to see. IT was our 5th stop near temple in our day trip... THe BEst part you can take a lot of photo and there are not so many groups visit this temple .. nice view from eastern part to lake .

Mysteriously beautiful. We biked to Preach Khan before sunset (while everybody else was going to the top of a hill somewhere). It was absolutely amazing. It was so quiet and felt we were alone in the temple. All the birds stared singing and the jungle surroundings are stunning. One of the highlight moment for us in Angkor Wat.

Interesting Construction. It's got an cool little cross like construction with some a primary hindu statue in the middle. Among it's other features are it's imposing entryway and forest setting. An average temple when it comes to Angkor.
Khmer Machu Picchu.. Stunning location and views. Tough work to get to although the roads are now much better than the past but worth taking a day for what is a World Heritage Site.
Incredible Wonder of the World. What a stunning and surprising place to visit. World Heritage Sites are worth the trip every time. These temples take you back in time.

Come here instead of Ta Prohm!. You could see trees enclosing temples here with more tranquility and less tourists!
First stop of your Grand Tour Circuit. Combine this temple with Neak Poan, Ta Som, East Mebon and Pre Rup.

Remote Jungle temple. I visited Preah Khan the second day I've been in Siem Reap. After been visiting most famous temples the first day, I continued with the most remote ones next day with a private guide. I loved all Angkor temples but specially those really far away from the crowds and offering a little bit of calm. I recommend you to stay at least 3 days in Siem Reap to enjoy a pleasant journey and of course, book a private guide to enjoy better the experience. My guide, made my day!
Temple within a temple. Excellent architecture, picturesque location. Located on the south side of the temple complex. Buddha statue adorns the central arena.
Similar to Ta Prohm, but quieter. Parts of this temple have also been taken over by trees. It is less popular with tourist buses, so definitely more peaceful.
Good place to visit. This is a temple built by a king in honor of his father around 12th century. Largely unrestored, but a fascinating site.

Unique. There was not a lot of people who visited this temple so we had ample time to take pictures and comfortably walk around without bumping into someone. There also is a Roman Pavilion inside the temple which is a unique feature of this temple VS the other ones.

Amazing place. This was one of my favourite stops on a busy day visiting temples. I met a guard in the entrance area who showed me around the temple providing me with lots of information about the history, legends and myths surrounding the different carvings and statues.
Interesting place. Carvings & sculptures amazing. Wander around & take your time to take in everything here. Early morning a good time to avoid the crowds from the bus tours.

Mystic Temple Ruin. Another temple ruin ... but not just another one. This temple is a bit more hidden in the forest and if you are lucky and not many people are around it is a little bit like finding a hidden treasure in the forest. Take your time to find the areas at the sides and some huge trees that have grown over the temple.

Go see it!. Another gem. This is another massive structure that you should not miss. I visited this on the 2nd day after Angkor Wat, Ta Prohm and Bayon. All structures are different and unique in their own right so if you travel all this way to Siem Reap do not miss this one.
delicacy. Delicate as a woman is. beautiful ornaments and very well maintained. It is a little far but worth the time expended.

A really good, and varied, temple complex. This was one of my favorite temples (or temple complexes) I visited. It was big, and had the structures were really varied. It also had some of my favorite features from other temples- trees and other greenery were taking over in some places (like Ta Promh), and there were carved faces (like Bayon). Like many of the other temples, Preah Khan was restored by the World Monuments Fund. I THINK (I might be getting it confused with another temple) that this was the first temple that Cambodian restorers were trained to restore themselves, which is kind of cool.Whenever you visit, bring a LOT of water. Like a comical amount of water. And please cover your knees and shoulders, don't be that person who thinks the rules don't apply to them.
Beautiful architecture. The tempel is great. The architecture is encouraging to see everting in here. It is one of biggest tempels in Angkor complex.
Definitely worth a visit. An amazing place. Try to go early in the morning when the temperature is lower. Preah Khan is definitely worth a visit.

Definitely worthy of a visit, despite the other temples to see . I don't understand why people rate some of these temples as 3* for reasons like 'Ta Prohm is better' or 'a bit similar to all the others'. Would you mark down Chichen Itza if it happened to also be in Giza?! Rant over... This is (another) stunning temple and definitely worthy of a visit in any busy Angkor schedule. There are some great tree growths here and the Grecian/Roman style pavilion is a unique feature. There are some great panoramas and perspectives to get lovely photos from.
Worth visiting !. The ruins is huge, largely left unrestored but the details of design and its size is defie worth to embrace
Charm...... A nice place to spend few hours...Tip:Take water and umbrella this place can get very hot and humid during day..

one of my preferred picks. This is an amazing structure with lots to explore. Some of the temple has been overrun by the trees which i find spectacular, and much of it is in various states of ruin. Personally i prefer this to many of the big tickets temples (including angkor wat). Its also quieter than others we visited which means more opprtunity for picture. In the middle we did get into a discussion with some form of police or security who was angling for something, but ive become good at brushing that off quickly.

Far from the madding crowds.... I'm not sure if this literary reference is an appropriate title but it reflects the quiet ambience of this temple, compared with the crowds at Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom.It is approached down a quiet path then over a serpent bridge over a tranquil moat. Inside there are four passageways that lead to the central tomb. It's pretty much surrounded by jungle, and is so quiet you can hear the jungle noises. We bought some lovely temple rubbings from a local artist who was displaying her works at the entrance.
Nice temple. We did this on our way back from Kbal Spean. Like other temples in Angkor, this one is also huge and similar to some of the other temples.

Better than Ta Prohm. A quieter temple than Ta Prohm [which gets too many visitors]. Great to explore as it is really large and like a maze inside. Check out the visitor center just off the path on the way to the temple. Great before and after photos. This place was overgrown with jungle right until the early 1990s. Would chose this over Ta Prohm on a busy day

A wonder to be seen. So close and quiet. . This temple is a must to be seen and only 10 min from Bayon. Do not let guide or tuk tuk over charge you. Fantastic temple and very large temple. So much structure and shape, rooms to see, carving, magnificent trees and hardly no tourist. It is part of the grand tour but take hour to see it especially to see the east side with the double column temple. Enjoy.
Unbelievable!. One of the largest complexes. It is unbelievable that such huge pieces of art and architecture were completely hidden and forgotten for centuries.
Unique Architecture. This temple is specimen of Khmer architecture. Some of the parts are well preserved . Design and style are also different.
My favourite. A little quieter than the more famous temples. Really very beautiful with amazing energy, a special place.

One of my favorite temples to visit. Preah Khan is laid out in a very long interesting fashion and it feels amazing walking down corridor after corridor, entering through doorframe after doorframe. In some respects the ruins reminded me of Grecian ruins because of the many pillars. I felt a great sense of grandeur and antiquity just being there.

A litany of temp,Es that defy imagination and envelope you in an embrace that is otherworldly. These temples are a true veneration of man homage and dedication to their gods. To build these temples in an era of when technology was far too limited & basic. To me it always generates awe and hope. The awe is because it was built with so little and hope because man can achieve so much.As in other temples in Siem reap this is a must monument and worth spending time wandering all around. My fervent wish is that tourists respect these temples and understand the basis on which they have been built.

My new favorite among Angkor temples. Preah Khan is my new favorite among the great temples in Angkor. It is a vast temple area. It is partially well preserved and partially in ruins and covered by jungle. There are some fine apsaras and other skillfully done carvings. I liked especially those in the dancing hall.

Authentic temple, few visitors. Some construction, but nonetheless beautiful. There's a great photo opportunity where you can line up a opening in the ceiling with a statue reminiscent of a candle stick.Note1: Take a bike! They're $1usd and most come with locks, not that you really need them. Some routes/circuits are 10-12km, but you obviously don't have to follow the recommended three day tours. Biking allowed us to observe daily life in the rural areas outside the temples as well as Siem Reap as a whole.Note 2: do not go ticketless! They will fine you. Grab tickets en route to the temple roads, on your right approx. 3km before arriving at a fork in the road. Angkor is to the left of the fork. Note 3: Money is changed in USD, Cambodia uses the reil as change, like cents. Note4: snack stands and beverages available near Angkor Wat - restaurants too, and vendors line up near other temples. Prices slightly elevated but it's not ridiculous inflation.

Another stunning temple, quieter atmosphere than Angkor Wat. Particularly if you have more than 1 day in Siem Riep it is well worth a visit. Quieter than the main Angkor Wat temple complex but in many ways just as special. Unusual columns and facades which were interesting to see.Because there were fewer people and a number of shady its this was a good place to sit and soak up the atmosphere of the forest. Sounds of parrots and lots of dragonflies flying around the dappled shade. Lovely atmohere.

Bhuddist Temple and University. If you walk thru the Angkor Wat Archeaeological Park you´ll eventually pass Preah Khan, a Bhuddist temple and university and don´t miss it out. The main Temple is Bhuddist and the (later added) south, north and west temples are Hindu. The outside of the temple is decorated with 72 Garudas holding snakes.

Best Temple, least tourists, most authentic. My favourite temple, the most interesting and authentic of the 'ruined' ones. The south gate is still totally destroyed, you get to explore in the forrest if you like. Amazing spot
A "must visit" temple!. This temple is similar to style to nearby Ta Phrom so combine these 2 together. Another one of Angkor's jungle temples.
A favourite. One of my favourites. Large temple and University. Main path leads into the temple but make sure you find the university part on the east side. Tree on wall at East gate

My favorite of all visited temples. Our guide did a great job with our approach as we walked through the woods, alongside the moat and came in from the backside which was completely desolate and hidden. The walk through the woods and anticipation of what and when we'd see our destination added some surreality to the experience. And then to find it and have it all to ourself until we got closer to the front and main area. I enjoyed taking some photos of nature along the walk ahead of the temple. The temple itself seems more special than some of the others as it has not been as restored and can be seen with a lot more growth on it without the crowds seen at Ta Prohm. It is similar to Ta Prohm but better in my opinion due to it being smaller and less "touristy" but with the same awesome tree growth and feel of being one with the forest. I highly recommend a visit but ask specifically to approach from the back for a more unique experience. We left from the front and could tell that we wouldn't have walked away with the same memories and experience if we had approached it from the main entrance. It would have felt more like "just another temple".

Magical and mysterious . This temple was one of the first of the day for us and virtually deserted. It was cool, dark and almost mysterious with a magical quality tot he ruins let behind fro. The storm that started to destroy it and time. You could spend a lot of time her wondering the grounds and marvelling at its beauty in almost solitary revelry.

Stunning! An absolute must!. Depending on the direction you come from, you may be underwhelmed when walking up to this temple as it is not very tall or wide. However, it is such a stunning temple and a lot larger than you expect until you get inside as it spreads out in length.It is similar to Ta Promh with large tree trunks merging with the ancient walls which is absolutely stunning. What is amazing with this temple compared to Ta Promh is you can really weave through the temple and get amongst it without pathways and fenced off areas. Definitely put this on your itinerary. It was one of our absolute favourites on the trip!

Relaxation at Angkor. Visiting Angkor can be quite tiring (but worth it). Preah Khan provides an opportunity to relax a little and take in some beautiful sights. Sometimes overlooked it is worth stopping off during your tour of the Angkor Wat area. Much interesting Khmer architecture as well as nice countryside. Don't miss.
Magical. If you like archeological site, full of history, mystery , you must see this place. Hard to walk around at 40 degrees and high humidity but it's worth .

Cool, dark and beautiful.... Careful you dont get lost wandering through this temple, lots of cool dark passage ways. Once again as with all other temples in the system there is so many photo opportunities, lots of prayer areas with offerings to the gods. Dont get sucked into a friendly local wanting to show you around or offer you a blessing then expect to be paid and will hassle you until you do.If you want a guide hire a professional

Absolutely stunning!. It was an excellent visit.
I could sense that the Khmer Emipre was very advanced, not only technologically but organisation wise as well!
Amazing!

Preah Khan. A very interesting temple. It has a greek temple in one corner which shows the extent to which ancient people travelled and were aware of other cultures. In this temple there are sections for both Buddhism and Hinduism
Gorgeous temple with many doors. Out of all the Grand Circuit temples, this was actually my favourite. I loved how it had endless number of doors and windows, and beautiful carvings.
Beautiful. No where else could build something which I calll stuning temple like this. The temples has so much of character which you will be amazed with the story by the tour guides.

One to explore...full of passages. A symetrical monastic complex that is quite untouched. If you like photograhing doorways and passages you will enjoy exploring this one. There is some great detail to be seen with a number of apsara dancers in rellief and inscribed.The centre is well defined from whence you can go N, S, E or W. We came in from the North to the centre and out to the Eastbefore retracing our steps to return to our driver.There are some interactions between trees and stones to photograph as well.

Peaceful. . This ended up being my favourite temple of Angkor! Not sure if it was because it was so quiet and cool and peaceful. Amazing scenery everywhere in this crumbling ruin. Everything lichen and moss covered a photographers delight! (Be aware: we found on several occasions that you can pick up an unofficial guide, wanted or not! Including policeman, they strike up conversation about a particular part of the temple next minute they are following or leading you with commentary then let you know guides costs $15/hr, we just have the guy who took us at bayon a couple dollars! And tried to evade the other helpers!)

Amazing humbling place.. When I was here, I felt that silence was the best response. To hear the khmer ancestors calling out to us. Awe inspiring! Well worth a look. places like this, makes you realise that you need a week in Siem Reap to visit every day to get the most out of it.

Beautiful spot. There is nothing more to add than had already been said a million times on here. In a time that we Europeans arrogantly call the "dark ages", the Khmer empire was at it's apex. Very little remains in Europe from this time period, yet the Khmer still have these treasure troves of history. It's sad that they are owned by Vietnam rather than Cambodia, but that's the way it is. Great photos here!!!

Precious Place. This is the father temple. This great temple is a temple where you can easily spend between 2-3 hours depending of what you are looking for. Be careful, you can really get lost in this temple. You will have multiple doors to get by has you manage you way to the middle of this temple, you can wonder left and right but be mindful of where you are. They are 5 sections in this temple just like the 5 towers of Anchor what. Great pictures can be taken inside this temple with between the doors. If you explore this place carefully, i manage to found a great place for praying and witness a private ceremony if the left side of the first building. There is a clear carving of Shiva which is in outstanding shape, during the ceremony they were requesting the help of the gods for someone who was sick and laying down on the ground with some people filling the room. The made some offerings during the ceremony and it was interesting to watch. You can also get bless by a lady in the middle of the temple, you just need to go down on your knees and she will attach a piece of rope on your wrist and when she is done, she will blow on your head.
Preah Khan is fun. Preah Khan is in the Angkor Thom complex and should be seen for the various statues. The south gate into Angkor Thom has a restored series of statues.

Unrestored charm and beauty - peaceful location by the river. Not as busy as the other sites we visited. Very different in it's style and the symmetry of its passages is amazing, some great pictures to be taken. Not as impressive as in size and statue but very interesting walking through the many passages within this site. Sprung trees grow with it's wall adding natures charm and beauty. The entrance to this site is grand and tranquil as this site sits next to a large pond. The carvings are beautiful and detailed, this site is steeped in history.Shame all the heads of the statues leading up to the entrance have been stolen over the years, would have looked very impressive with all the heads in place. Well worth a visit.

Peaceful and charming - our second favourite temple!. Preah Khan just has a charm about it that had us hooked straight away. Yes, Angkor Wat is very impressive but it almost felt too 'perfect'. The tumble-down nature of Preah Khan really made us appreciate just how old it is and how special it is. It's also much quieter than the likes of Ta Prohm.

Interesting to visit. This temple, though not as majestic as the Angkor, is definitely worth your visit. Largely unrestored, Preah Khan is charming in its own way. You would not imagine how this was once a Buddhist university some 800-900 years ago. Adding to its charm is the growth of the kapok/spung tree in its walls. What made my visit more special were the effort we made to get into the rubbles to see the carvings of the first and second queens of King Jayavarman VII, and the enounter I had with an 80 year old "nun/fortune teller" who seemed to live near one of the lingams in the temple. My tour guide asked for her blessing and got to read his fortune in her little sanskrit book. Recommend to visit this temple around 12nn to 1pm so it will be all yours, less touristy.

Do Not Miss This!!. This magnificent temple beside the river is simply awesome! There are garudas everywhere so don't miss that photo op with them. This temple is rich in history and the only sad part of the tour is seeing the defacement and abomination done by poachers and raiders. I hope they got their karma. Nevertheless, do not miss this temple!

worth the visit when in Siem Reap. Preah Khan is another must-see temple in Angkor. It has its own mystique. There weren't many tourists when we went there in the morning so it was a good time to explore. It took us about an hour to go around the temple. The huge trees growing among the temple ruins was quite a sight. The only thing that we didn't like during our visit was our encounter with a 'police' officer in uniform who quickly started to tell us about the history of the ruins and offered to show us around a bit more. We initially thought it was a kind gesture until after guiding us through some areas of the temple, he asked for "donation" of $5 each which caught us by surprise. We felt robbed but oh well, who would want to argue with a 'police' officer so we gave in.
Nice Place To Visit. I really love that place during I visit for my photography shooting really beautiful temple with big tree that you can find my pictures in here too.
Stunning and serene.. Very serene with a huge lake. Not so much to see, but beautiful all the same. The lotus flowers growing in the lake were stunning.
One of the more peaceful.. If you aren't tempted out you should go here. Not as busy as some of the main temples. You can wander and feel slightly Indiana jones

Different Architechture. This is a very beautiful, as are all, but also a very interesting temple. The architechture is different from most of the other ones. This one was built for King Jayavarman VII father. As opposed to Ta Prohm that he built for his mother. The temple is huge and it is a ground temple with alot of rooms, so make sure you waste a little time exploring since there isn´t a single way to visit it. The colors are greenish which makes for a different and interesting sight and the carvings are clear and intricate. This one also provides at the West Entrance a very informative "small museum", so you get to know a little history if you don´t want to drop some dollars on a tour guide. The bridges in and out were beautiful as well.
amazingly awesome. the entire anka wot site is worth visiting one day was enough for us you can pourchase a multi day pass though

Massive temple complex with precise symmetry. This another of the massive Angkor temples. It has big entrance gateway that leads to a structure that seems to held together by two massive cutdown trees on its top.
It seems to be easy to get lost inside the main structure because of the symmetry of its passages.
A must visit if you're in Sieam Reap.

Not as dramatic as some Angkor Wat but worth seeing. This is part of the 'big circuit' of 7 temples a short drive from Angkor Thom. Although not as dramatic as Angkor Wat, it's worth seeing because it has its own unique features such as am amazing view through a large number of doorways perfectly aligned which gives the impression you are looking at a double mirror. Don't just go to Preah Khan though - do the 'big circuit' and see the other ones too because they are all unique.
Not to be missed. Another gorgeous temple which is off the beaten track but definitely make time to visit if you can.Beautiful carvings and doorways.

Soothing and Refreshing and adds beauy to the temple complex!. This huge water body was actually man made is difficult to think since its so huge and surrounds the Angkor Watt Temple Complex. When wind blows the ripples in the water makes it look like waves and the sight is wonderful specially at the evning hours when we saw it! This water body adds an exrta beauty to the tmeple complex and in the early morning the sun rise looks marvellous from its side. The whole sky becomes red and that colour is reflected in the huge water body makes it a heavnely sight! You can sit beside and enjoy the calmness all around you with huge trees surrounding you from all sides.

Small temple, in need of further restoration. Somewhat off the beaten tracks, it is worth a visit for its history, than the temple building, which is still in need of more restoration. Visit if you have the time.

Wonderful place.. Preah Khan was certainly one of our favorites temples in the big circuit. The temple is exceptionally beautiful and massively picturesque. The small doorways and pathways make for an excellent sight. The carvings are also as scenic as ever. Certainly not to be skipped.
Amazing Temple!. I would recommend all visitors to visit this beautiful temple. There is an incredible place which looks like a candle when we look at a hole of the building with a cemetery inside.
beautiful place.. Angkorwat's preak khan, is one of the most scenic spots & a must visit place fromamongst the thousands of temples scattered throught out the angkorwat region & cambodia.

Preah Khan is the Tops!. I biked to Preah Khan from my hotel--about an hour in all, but I was biking slowly due to the heat and exhaustion. It was a lot further from Thom than suggested by the map, but as they warn, the maps are not done to scale. It was well worth the trip, and absolutely beautiful. I very much suggest, as I do with all temples, to see this in the morning, so you can be at peace with the ruins and the jungle. It's a gorgeous setting and in better condition than much of Thom is. They haven't pared away too much of the jungle, so you can still appreciate the ambiance of the wild in much of the way you do at Ta Prohm. This was my favorite ruin by far of all that I saw. MUST MUST SEE.

great experience. Preah khan temple is very well worth a visit in cambodia. I really enjoyed the history & culture of khmer & Hindu religion. I also liked the architecture of temples - very amazing in priavte style!

underrated temple. Many people will say the key temples to see in central Cambodia are Angkor Wat, the "smiling Buddha faces" temple and the "tomb raider" temple. Not that those aren't all amazing, but this one belongs on that list. The bridge to the temple is worth it in itself. There are many giant trees growing in and around the temple structures, a la the "tomb raider" temple, which gives it a very mysterious and untouched feel. It's also a very large temple - many different areas to explore. Located close to Angkor Thom so right in the middle of things. Don't miss this one.

One of the Great treasures of Cambodia - we were fotunate to view!!. Preah Khan (meaning ROYAL SWORD) Built in 1191 AD, built by Jayavarman VII (to honour his father) after his victory over Chams, with Khmer architecture, sadly remains unrestored. Well worth viewing the damaged Hindu and Budhist style statues!
Most impressed by this one. This was one of the most impressive ones to me. More so than Thom or Watt. Also because it was way more quiet. Every corner and turn you take you will be amazed.
Wow for temple visit!. Lots of steps and walking. We were exhausted after only a half day. Beautiful and hard to capture with words. The carvings and expanse of the ruins were phenomenal
Breathtakingly Beautiful.. There was hardly anyone there when we visited. It took my breath away. My husband took over 600 photos at this one temple!! A must see. Can't wait to visit again.
Large Temple. After spending two days inAngkor Wat, it is hard to differentiate the temples. They are all amazing, but after a while they all begin to look alike.

Great place for photos!. One of our favorites! Off the beaten path, not crowded - fascinating nooks and cranny's to explore. A former Buddhist University. A great place for photo taking as well. We could feel the peacefulness and serenity as we explored this temple. If we return to Siem Reap, this would defintely be on our go see again list!

Most beautiful site on the Angkor Outer Loop. This was the most beautiful and interesting site we saw on the Outer Loop at Angkor - interesting history and great for wandering down beautiful passage ways.

Temple with Angkorian Architecture. This temple exhibits six towers. It was built by King Indravarman I. The side towers of the temple are dedicated to Indravarman's own ancestors. The east side was dedicated to the memory of King Jayavaarman II. The temple has delicately carved images.

watch out for dodgy police officer "guides". This is a nice temple and not as popular as some of the others so good for photos. However when we were there a police officer started talking to us and pointing out a few things. He seemed like he was actually just passionate about the temple. After a couple minutes of him talking to us he then asked for some money. Normally we would have just said no and walked away but because he was a cop we didnt know what to do so we handed over a couple dollars. He was then very rude and said it wasn't enough and he needed at least 5 dollars. Then he tried to ask for other currencies too. It was disappointing and soured our visit. Shortly after he had taken our money we saw him latching on to someone else.

Another great place - just not one of the best. Another awesome place to visit - it's just not one of the biggies here. It's best when you don't do lots of temples in one day - otherwise they just all blend together. So definitely worth seeing, just not one of the best.

A fave of mine. Preah Khan was one of my favorite of all the temples we visited on our two-day tour of the area. Covered in deep jungle and a photographer's dream to visit here. Some incredible tree growth here as well, to include a lot of ruins. If you're making a list and not sure which temples to include, I'd recommend including Preah Khan for sure, as the uniqueness will surely bring a smile and inspiration.
Amazing temple with trees. This is probably my favourite temple, lovely shade and the jungle atmosphere make this spot a real winner.

Some of the best tree growth. I might not be the best reviewer of all the temples because they all were so wonderful and have different feels.This one had some of the best tree growth through the ruins.It also has a unique two story building with columns but no access to the second floor.

Hidden Treaures. I thought that all temples would be the same, little did I know.The Sacred Sword is the meaning of this temple. The walk to this temple has shade from the trees along the way. Very narrow and low corridors, lots of fallen ruins and trees growing through the temple reaching up and out to the sky.
Beautiful. One of my favorite temples at the complex. Beautiful jungle surrounding and.atmostpheric lighting for photographers. Definitely one of the less busy temples too

One of the best temples to visit. In the middle of Preah Khan is a place to worship. It includes a stupa which is topped by sunlight in the shape of a flame. There is also a really cool echo room that doesn't work when you stomp your feet but does if you pound your chest (just make sure you do it 3 times for luck).

Don't miss sister wives. This was one of my favorite sites. Do not miss the somewhat hidden images of the King's two wives (sisters). They are off the beaten path and one is hidden by collapsing stone yet readily visible when you get to the right spot. She's particularly beautiful. Locals have kept incense and offerings before them both which adds to the allure. Find a friendly guard and they'll show you for a nominal tip. Also, when you get to the stupa in the center stop for a photo op of yourself holding a little spot of light over the spire on the stupa. Again, your new 'guard friend' will show you what to do.Have fun!
nice green area with temple ruins. you could see this temple area also within your 3 days temple tour when you get a TukTuk for 15 $ a day

The landmark of Unique face sculptures. These temples hold the attraction of the giant face sculptures walls of the unique features of the faces . The each one close together a few feet apart . The view gets better by going up . A picture oportunity here for sure . Keep it on your iterinary being one of the temples covered / permitted with your tkt / pass . The walking shoes advisable . Foot ware allowed inside temples here . If tired the refreshments are available . For vegetarians lovely Pineaple slices - the sweetest you have eaten .

Most interesting temple in the park. We stumbled upon Preah Kahn temple, and were not disappointed. Nature is still a huge part of this temple, much more so than Bayon or Angkor Wat. There are huge sections of grassland, massive trees (around and on top of the temple buildings) and it's huge footprint makes it an amazing place to explore.There isn't much signage or history around, but it isn't really needed. It's a magical place and definitely worth exploring.

Preah Khan; Don't Miss This Temple. Last year my wife and I spent 3 days exploring temples, this year we came back to explore some more. Our Tuk-tuk driver stopped at Preah Khan and asked if we wanted to see it. We're glad we did, It's quite extraordinary. After passing through the entrance way you'll walk a considerable way through the cleared jungle when you'll come across the Temple with it's bridged entrance. This temple is quite large and will take you some time to navigate. You'll find lots of corridors and hallways all interconnected with many alters for prayer, this alone makes it different from others. Do not miss this Temple.
peace and tranquility. Loved the place. If time permits we will certainly go again. It is so peaceful and tranquil. The green tees and the cool air. Just divine.

The most unique temple in Siem Reap. Besides the many beautiful carvings like other temples, this temple has at least six uniqueness. Firstly, it has a lake and pier for worshippers. Secondly, the approach to the temple has statues of soldiers holding a long snake like creature. This is common at that time but most are destroy for other temple. Thirdly, there are also lantern like sculptures for lights at night along the path leading to the temple .Fourthly, there are plenty of worshiping equipment inside the temple that give a glimpse of ancient practice e.g. the water container for female and male fertility, Fifthly, remember to light the candle made of stone - aligning the light from outside with a candle like stone structure inside when you take a photo. Finally, take a leisure walk inside the long corridors. Another key temple that should not be missed.
Magical temple. Not to much tourists and another site you should visit during a 3 day trip in Siem Reap. We got lost in the super nice old and very quiet temple. Worth a visit!!

My favourite Angkor temple to wander around . This truly is a ruin and an amazing place to wonder around , there is a continuos corridor that runs east west, with a central transcript with a Buddha at the centre , however the best part is to walk outside of this central corridor , going to either side of the temple's boundary , you then truly get the feeling of its decay and its battle with the jungle and fig trees , Certainly when I visited not that crowded , and a great relaxing atmosphere
Nice. Nice to be here. The ambience.are very nice. Eventhough it is not the biggest one but you can.find this temple.is interesting... Quiet and nice to meditate here

I love Preah Khan in the rain. I know this may be a strange thing to say but I do really love visiting Preach Khan at any time but especially in the rain. One thing is of course that you are basically alone almost anywhere you go in the Angkor Park when it is raining, but the other is that the rain drips down the stone walls, the chedis and all other exposed areas. To me it is a magical time.

Ancient Magic. This was one of our favourite temples within the Angkor Complex, mainly due to the comparatively small number of people but also the quality of the ruins themselves. From the moment we approached Preah Khan in the early morning light, she won us over. We arrived there about 6.45am and the sun was just rising over the entry gate and causeway giving us some stunning photo opportunities. Once inside, the level of detail in the reliefs was amazing and exploring the small courtyards and galleries sans that maddening crowd was fantastic! We'd highly recommend getting there early and spending a good couple of hours taking it all in.
Our favorite. We visited twice during our 3 day stay. Not as large as some of the main temples but extremely beautiful.

The tree temple. This lush beautiful temple is overgrown with trees and gives it an unexplored feel (except for the crowds of people which you can do your best to ignore). It's one of the more interesting temples and there's a lot to see.
A huge temple. This temple is becoming more popular with tourists. It is the yin to Ta Phrom's yang. Give yourself plenty of time to explore this temple (about 90 or more minutes).

Spectacular . This one is a little further up than the other main temples but well worth the visit !
Extraordinary detail, combines Hindu with Buddhist beliefs and space for worship. Tomb raider style look and feel at one end and well kept monuments at others.
Plenty of shade and few people makes it well worth a visit.
worththe look. it is one of many temples on the tour but is worth the look and a easy walk. it has not had a lot of reiteration to it which made it interesting seeing then ruins and growth over them

Don't miss. Well worth seeing this temple, it is underrated, and free from the crowds of Bayon etc.
This is on the great circuit tour road, north of Angkor Thom.

first impression of ankor wat. thi was the first temple we went to to meet our friends, we found out to our peril there are 2 entrances so beware meeting people! lots of little nook holes and interesting areas to look at, furthest away, but worth it

Half Hindu Half Buddhist . Preah Khan temple was built by King Jayavarman VII in late 12th Century. Khmer people will call this temple as Royal Sword. It was Buddhist temple till King Jayavarman VII and slowly convert to Hindu monument. The entrance of this temple is also unique. The door is design from big to small. This is because, those days in order to meet the King, one should bow down. The design and carving of the temple was extraordinary. Can't imagine how hard it must be to carve those galleries.

Underrated as hell.. Very underrated temple that is better than Ta Phrom in my opinion. It has interesting architecture. The same giant banyan roots. It also has many interesting architecture and religious quirks to its design that is not reflected in the temples in the angkor radius. Not to mention it is very historically significant in many ways to the khmer empire. There are also much less tourists here because it's off the immediate track. The layout of this place is interesting and so are the unusual "romanesque" columns and its reasons for existing as a spiritual staging area for war.

A Must See. Another great place to visit. Best either in the early morning or late afternoon. The restoration here is less evident and the ruins are preserved pretty much as the were found. All that has been changed is the removal of the forest overgrowth that hid it from view.
Often Overlooked. A huge sprawling temple with overgrown trees. A former university for learning Buddhism. Not to be missed and sometimes not crowded as the others.
Just Beuatiful. Tranquil and peaceful as you enter, such a amazing creativity cant speak enough its one of my favourite.

Unusual temple. I believe this temple is unique in that it has a smaller building inside built with Romanesque type columns rather than the square columns used throughout and has a second floor though no visible way to get up to it. Our guide was unsure of reasoning.

Love this place second time round. Time stood still! Love the shady walk to this manageable size site. No renovation. It is just as it is. Would recommend this place to escape the majority of the tourists!

The temple of the sacred sword.. Preah Khan is the fourth most important temple in the Angkor complex and generally sees fewer visitors than Ta Prohm. This temple is once again amazing. Covers a very large area. Is in a reasonable state of preservation and is a genuine fusion dedicated to 515 divinities over ing Buddhism, Shiva, Vishnu, Brahma to name just a few. You walk through vaulted galleries generally from west gate to east gate arriving at the Central sanctuary containing a large stone stela. Set aside 90 minutes to two hours to do this temple justice. Really one of my favourites from all the ones we visited.
Don't miss it. There are about ten must see temples on your visit and this is definitely one of them. You will not be disappointed.

Quite different and amazing. Although in a more dilapidated condition than Angkor Wat and Angkor Tom, Preah Khan is a marvel in structure. It appears to be one long (as in 500 metres or thereabouts) corridor with doorways at about 50 metre intervals, each one getting progressively smaller. Like many of the Siem Reap temples, it appears to have been uniquely designed, and its purpose somewhat obscure. Its definitely worthwhile visiting, especially as there is little climbing...but take water. Its a long way from end to end.

A mix of Angkor Thom and Ta Prohm. Somehwat of a hidden gem, this temple seems to get the bad rap and not visited as much. I enjoyed it very much and spent a good two hours exploring the nooks and crannies of history. Add it to your list.

King temple. This one was not as busy as the others but was really fantastic. Beautiful architecture and has some of the tree roots growing into the temple like Ta Prohm. Could have stayed here several hours- except for the heat.

Astonishingly impressive. This is in many ways similar to the wonderful Ta Prohm, but surprisingly far less busy. Among the many fascinating aspects of the temple is the two storey building, constructed on rounded columns. This is unique to the whole of Angkor, and thus essential viewing. I can not recommend this temple highly enough. It is totally breathtaking.

Preah Khan or the Royal Sword Temple. The Royal Sword temple is not as busy as other temples and was deserted when we visited after lunch. I loved the walk up the path with statues on both sides and entering into the temple. Check out the view from the bridge over the moat on your left. It is hard to believe that 100,000 people lived in the area around this temple when it was built in the 12th century. The middle of the temple is interesting and there are a wealth of carvings throughout it. It is a shame that the Buddhas were removed from nearly all the carvings. If you look closely you can see a couple of the Buddha carvings being converted to Hindu gods. Our guide showed us some of the carvings. A lot of the outer temple is a jumble of rubble but the middle part has been restored. This is the ideal place to spend some time just wandering around and enjoying the peace and quiet without hordes of tourists. If you found the review useful I always appreciate a helpful vote.

Great spot for a photo.. The statues on the bridge are very unique and beautiful and great for photos. It's worth Googling this one to learn a bit before you go, it makes the visit so much more interesting. This particular building has a fascinating history. It is largely unrestored and although a lot of vegetation has been removed over many decades in the name of preservation, there is a lot remaining so it's great for photos. Not so good for Preah Khan.

A place you should go. The temple is not so well maintained compared to other major temples but it doesn't conceal the beauty of its original structure. There are countless holes on the temple walls and the used to be filled with gem stones. You can also find the library, the dancing halls and the elephant like spong roots. You wouldn't want to miss it!
Best kept secret!. Preah Khan is not as heavily visited as other temples, but it is well-worth a visit. In fact, it is one of my favorites now. Very beautiful. Large trees and many hidden beauties.
A toned down version of Ta Prohm. After seeing Ta Prohm I thought, I didnt see much value in what I saw here, but its just a different perspective.

I forget everything that is happening in my life for just a while wandering in this temple. And that was all I need.. I still remembered the walk from the entrance to the temple. It was just for a few minutes but still you just need to walk, feeling good sometimes. Very few tourists for both my two times visit in my one week trip and that is a precious thing in some of the famous Angkor temples. Bring a book when you visit there. You can really sit in one corner and just have a chill time all by yourself. Ta Prohm is very photogenic with its big trees growing on a nearly thousand year old temple and Preah Khan can offer that too but with fewer tourists. It's a gold, isn't it? Want to know more about visiting Angkor temples, you can check out @ http://www.heypt.com/#!Visiting-Siem-Reap-Angkor-Wat-Other-Temples-in-Angkor-Region/c1kiu/55688e3d0cf2adc1ad677703

On the grand tour but off the beaten path.... I loved this temple, we were there early in the morning and it was cool, the sun hadn't got to work yet. We wandered around this place for a while, and were literally the only people there. Its eerie and awesome at the same time to be in these ruins all alone. Its not as restored as the other big temples but i think that contributed to its charm, it really feels a bit more authentic than Angkor Wat with hundreds of people in your field of view. Check this place out!!!

Nicest of all temples. We found this temple almost empty and spent hours in if. There are so many beautiful figures to discover and many parts of the temple are party destroyed by nature which gives it a very mystic atmosphere

Really felt like discovering a lost temple. Go visit it and don't tell the hordes of tourists at other sites.. Unlike Angkor Wat, Bayon and Ta Phrom, Preah Khan isn't as packed filled with tourists, and isn't disfigured with all the extensive restoration works started in the more well known sites.I was in Angkor in 2005, and Preah Khan feels like what it was like 10 years ago, for Ta Phrom untouched. Preah Khan will feel like you are discovering by yourself this architecture of man and nature bullt a millennial ago. It is a large temple comprised of many long corridors with openings to ruins, untouched.What's most pleasant about this temple is that it is a little off the beaten path, on the way to Bantea Srey. So it's not as touristy, when we got there mid-morning, there were only a couple dozen other people visiting it, so it never felt like we were fighting for discovering the place.The entrance is beautiful and especially the back of the entrance which feels like a jungle with ruins.Overall, the best temple I've visited in Angkor... This is what Ta Phrom should have been, but alas Ta Phrom has been ruined by the tourists, conservation works which completely removed the charm of the untouched ruin. I understand the need to preserve these landmarks but there can be ways to let them continue to live, as well as prevent too many tourists to go in at once.
Very nice!!!. Preah Khan is a flatter temple with not many towers and has numerous trees all among the ruins.... enjoy!!!! :-)
Serenity, beauty Temple. Compare to other temple, it is quieter as it is on the grand tour. Want to see more detail the beauty of the ancient ruins, Preah Khan is one of the best!
One of the better ones to explore. Definitely worth spending a bit of time here and exploring. It's pretty big and complex and isn't descended upon by the hordes.

This is my next fave to Bayon. Expect to walk through the gates from east to west. Most of Preah Khan's parts are already in a rubble, so you really need to becareful. What I love the most is the entrance, as it has some trees that gives you refuge from the sun. As you walk along the path, I left with the sense of missing the past on how it looked like before, and how great Khmer empire was though trampled with many challenges. Now, it still stands its ancient grandeur. A piece of greatness, we must be glad to have a little glimpse from the past.

Very impressive, but go there early!. Since I wake up early, I deeply enjoyed my visit to Preah Khan. Carvings are very impressive, the temple itself is quite huge and the surrounding is quite lovely. Definitely worth a visit.

One of many One of the best. There are many temples to see (we saw about 17) but this one was our first to fully experience. Its a large temple complex in a jungle with amazing path to the temple with a bridge to the amazing wall. Inside the stone wall gate is a temple with great carvings, rooms, halls etc. Truely amazing.Our biggest mistake we didn't have a Tour guide to explain and show us what was not written in the book we had.My advice is please get a Tour guide or organise a tour as it is essential to understand the history to this amazing place. We used an excellent & best english (American accent) guide- Vannak (vannakguide@gmail.com), extremely knowledged.This tour was organised thru (the best) Odyssey Indochina Tours with a air conditioned car driver and guide- knowledge of history, language, customs and area including food. We followed this path 1. Preah Khan 2.Neak Prean 3. Ta Soam 4.Eastern Mebon 5 Banteay Samre 6 Prae Roup 7 Srah Srang & 8. Banteay Kdei approx 30 kilometres round trip from hotel about 4-5hours with Tuk Tuk cost $25usd

Worth a visit. Not as crowded as the others but this place is worth a visit. Once there, you would feel like you're back in time when the place was first discovered (I was there late one afternoon and not so many people there though). Personally I like this one better than others.

Worth a visit!. I have done the grand tour and this temple was part of it. I like the tranquility of this place. It has less tourist and you can definitely enjoy walking around a bit more. Although it may not be as big as the other temples in the Angkor complex but it's beauty can be much more appreciated.
A much smaller scale but equally impressive!. Although this is a much smaller site than the other more well known temples in the area it is equally as impressive! Very compact but beautiful.
Fav. My favorite Angkor temple. Beautiful n less crowded. Love the size. And the stones were nicely covered in moss n aged.

Excellence Place to meditate, to relax and more. Prah Khan's beauty is fantastic as Ta Promh. Because it is located on Grand Circuit, therefore, there are few tourist visit there.If you want to be alone and want to see more detail of the temple, I would like recommend to visit Prah Khan. There are a lot of great characteristic of Prah Khan:1. The pillars are line very straight. It seem that you are standing in the mirror.2. Good place to visit and to relax.3. For local people, Prah Khan is one of the sacred place. People always go there to give the offering to Prah Mae Indradevi and Prah Mae Jayarajadevi. They were the wives of King Jayavaraman VII. We respect him as Buddha as well. You can see his statue every where in Cambodia.Want to get away from a crowded temple, Prah Khan is the best!
beautiful. i find this temple to be less crowded than the other big one like Bayon. this temple is quite elongated and offer a longer walk in the complex under the roof.

Preah Khan, the pair of Ta Prom.. The first thing you can see the two headless 'Dvarapalas' guarding the west gopura. . One of them is holding a sword, but I don’t know what the other one was holding, because of the missing hands.Don’t worry, they let you in.Probably the most photographed bas-relief of this temple is a pretty devata with red paint.There are several small subsidiary shrines in the temple, not too significant, but lovely.Once the wall of main shrine was covered by long stolen bronze plates, but what remained to us to look at the holes where they were attached.A famous the Sri-Lankan style stupa is in the centre of the temple.You can find a seemingly pointless platform, what the base of a wooden shrine was probably. Now it is an excellent vantage point for viewing the east side of the temple.Close to the east gate, there is a mysterious two storey building, with very unusual round columns. We only can make guesses what aim did it served. Maybe it was a granary as some suggest it. Don’t miss it!Hidden deep in the collapsing Preah Khan, there is Jayadevi, (pretty enough, but isn't my type) one of Jayavarman VII's two sister-wives. So, not only the Egyptian kings, but the Khmers practised incest as well.Preah Khan is a huge temple, so even if you think, that you have seen everything, be sure, you missed a lot.

Grand Tour Temple. This was the last temple we did on our grand tour bike ride and it was probably the most confusing in terms of layout. It was really easy to go from an area crawling with people to somewhere that was deserted. I liked the fact this temple was fairly low and loved the relief work and the moat.

Still a great place to wander. I love Preah Khan. It's mostly quite busy, but, don't just follow the crowd through the temple as most people do. In one entrance and out the exit - that's boring and crowded. Walk around the perimeter of the temple itself and you'll find it's quite peaceful away from the maddening crowds. Plenty of interesting statues and carvings to photograph.Check out the Garudas on the outside perimeter wall, and the Gopura (gate) down the back where nobody goes. Well, almost no-one.It's easy to get disoriented in here, so take a small compass with you and make sure you are clear on which entrance /exit your driver will meet you at. This temple is surprisingly quiet early in the morning. From 7-8am you may find just a handful of people here.

A must-see temple. This temple is definitely a must-see one, along with Angkor Wat, Bayon--Angkor Thom, Ta Prohm. It has a unique two-storey building, that no-one seems to know what it was for (!), and it is generally less visited and quieter than the others, so it's good to spend a bit more time wandering around. It also has some she did trees like Ta Prohm.
dont miss this one. really cool bas reliefs and hidden courtyards, not too many crowds. This was the last of 9 sites we visited and on of our favorites
Quiet and peacful. The Buddhist temple which located outside of angkor thom. A bit ruin but interesting place to explore especially in the evening.

Hidden gem in the forest. To visit Preah Khan take a short walk through the forest and you will be welcomed by the stone warriors that will hold the bridge for you to cross. A very lovely complex surrounded by nature and not so crowded as Angkor Wat. Worth a visit of 2 hours. There are lots of statues, structures and details to be admired. It is amazing that we were allowed to climb on and walk through the ruins, not beiing very well preserved that way. Do not miss it!
Peaceful. We visited this place early morning, so there was no crowd and just let the feeling sink in. It was simply beautiful to explore this temple without a guide.
Men & Naga - Preah Khan. The most iconic bridge carvings in all Angkor complex. Good shot, but don't invest too much time in here, Angkor is still waiting!
Stunning trees. This is a large temple and one of the most photogenic. There are ancient trees straddling the ruins, much like Ta Prohm but with fewer people.

The best ruins in Angkor Wat Park. LOCATION: the place is in the outer loop, and best visited through tuk-tuk ($20 including a visit to Banteay Srei). It is possible through bicycle but just far.
PRICE: included in the Angkor Pass
COMMENTS: just amazing. Great for photo-ops and just roam around the ruins...Simply great!

Brick Angkorian architecture. This temple shows the first brick Angkorian architecture. It exhibits six towers. This temple was built by King Indravarman I in 879 AD with central sanctuary on the east side dedicated to the memory of King Jayavarman II. The side towers are dedicated to Indravarman's own ancestors. The temple is built on a sandstone platform. The temple has delicately carved images.
Amazing temple like in movie. The temple surrounded by jungle... Big place for hours of walking and exploring... amazing place! Some parts are damage but it still looks wow! Shouldn't miss this.
loved this as well!!!. enjoy all the Buddah statues around the area...it doesn't get as crowded like the bigger temples.....book your tour with TONG HANN +855-0-89986497

Just When You Think You Have Seen The Best !!!. This temple is a must see, even after you have seen all the other temples in Siem Reap. The carvings at this temple are some of the best I have seen at any temple. The trees are growing everywhere. Amazing sights in amazing surroundings.

Serene surroundings and some lovely carvings. Similar to Ta Prohm it is a sprawling site with giant trees engulfing some of the buildings but with fewer visitors. You can enter or leave via the "naga" bridge. Beautiful carved lintels and friezes, The remnants of a two story library also adds something different. Recommended if you have time.
Beautiful temple. Another amazingly interesting temple to visit in Siem Reap filled with interesting carvings and many over grown trees.this temple is worth a visit.
Excellent. Brilliant and another one that you must see. There are so many temples to see but don't miss out on this one as you will not be disappointed.

The Other Must See.... Preah Khan is a bit further "in" the park and maybe that is why it feels less busy. There is so much to explore here. It is like being on a voyage of discovery!The further in you go, the more interesting it becomes! Green and pink tinged stone and giant overgrown trees... It is full of carvings and photo opps!A real treat!

Much more than a temple. This 12 century "city" a probable Buddhist university is filled with interesting figures and friezes. You can cross on the causeway by a "naga" bridge from east to west or vice versa, so have your vehicle pick you up at the other side. Roots of the silk cotton tree push through the ancient stone like at Ta Prohm. This was our first stop of the day. Our tuk tuk driver name KONG (find him at the Clairemont Angkor Hotel, he is a gem) picked us up early to be there before the crowds. He then took us to Neak Poan, Tasom, East Mebon, Banteay Samre, Pre Rup and Prasat Kravan. He is not tour guide, but knew where to take us. So we took him out to lunch at a restaurant of his choice that was off the tourist path. SO GOOD. Then back to the ruins. Also the book guide ANCIENT ANGKOR by Michael Freeman and Claude Jacques is invaluable.

Beautiful and serene!. This is a lovely temple not too far out of Siemens Reap and we spent more than an hour here. Colors of the stone with green tinges and traces of pink were great in the early morning light. We also managed to be there when almost no one else was which made it perfect.

Amazing. You will see many temples that have huge trees growing right on them. These three began growing when the temples were abandoned and most are around 600 years old.There is also an ancient pool and library.The coolest part is the small beam of sunlight and iluminates one of the rooms.
Stunning. A beautiful temple with such intricate carvings in an almost pink coloured stone. Definitely one of the top temples to visit to see the contrast between them.
Preah Khan- also must see. Preah Khan is located north of Ta Prohm. Most tourists miss it, but it is big and different. It is worth to visit!

Spent 2 hrs here. There are trees strangling the walls and temples doorways, rubble falling down, rooms where you can beat your chest and it resonates like a drum, quiet alcoves AND not that many tourists crawling all over it like Ta Prohm. This is my favourite of all.

Well worth a look. Preah Khan is inside the Angkor Archaeological Park and is well worth a look. Less people here but definitely should be seen by all. Much of the site is in ruin with the spectacular site of large trees crushing and moving the stone blocks.
Impressive. Do not miss this temple. I really thought I would be templed out here but every temple is different and has its unique style.

Step onto an Indian Jones set. This might have been my favorite temple in Siem Reap. Unlike most of the temples this one has not been restored so it is not in as good of condition. But this adds to the mystique and awe of the temple. Much of it has crumbled and is over grown with moss and trees, but enough remains that you can see its history. You feel like you have just stepped into an "Indiana Jones" film and you are looking for ancient treasure. It was very fun and very unique from the other temples.
Sunset. great option to watch the sunset. Less crowded that Angkor Wat. The soft golden light on the temple just before the sunset was really gorgeous.
Visit the small temples such as this one before going to the 'bog boys'. This was the first temple that we visited and it did not disappoint. Prepares you nicely for what is in store later on.

So much better than overcrowded Ta Prohm. The best thing is there are no railings that obscure the views of the tree roots covering the temple complex. This is so much better then Ta Prohm. It looks genuine and gives the feeling of being in a lost civilisation. By far the best temple.

(Not-so) hidden gem!. Absolutely stunning ruins and much less busy than angkor wat, angkor tohm, etc. Such a wonderful, peaceful experience. Arguably my favorite of all the ruins, although it's hard to top Angkor Wat.
