One of my favorite temples in Siem Reap. I've seen many temples in many countries, so it's easy to get 'temple fatigue.' We did this one after one of the larger ones, and appreciated the more intimate feel of the place. It is different enough from Ankor and Thom to be worth a visit. When we first arrived, it was quieter, and then a couple of buses rolled up full of tour groups. Timing really is everything when visiting these old temples in Siem Reap. As always, wear sensible shoes. As another reviewer said, much is under renovation, there is only a partial area to go into, but I am glad we checked it out. Based on what we saw here, we went to another temple from the same era the next day. This may be personal preference, but I do not think you need a guide, especially at a small one like this. Enjoy at your own pace, in peace (if you get any!) and simply soak up the ambiance.

Stunning!. A definitely one of my favourites - if not my favourite - in the whole Angkor park. Less crowded, sporting a good balance between decay and still impressive size and decorations, with nature getting in adding to the picturesque effect, very quiet, atmospheric, mysterious... Absolutely amazing carvings and colours. An unforgettable experience.

Roots!. His is the temple complex that was made famous my angelina Jolie in her movie, Laura croft tomb raider.They have left the trees growing in and around the ruins ,s o the visual affect is quite stunning.

Not a big deal. After seeing a review that compared it with Macchu PIcchu I was sorely disappointed, nothing more than Angkor Wat and well below Attuthaya which is the old capital of Siam, an hour and a half out of Bangkok that is the equal of Angkor Wat.

Interesting but not as spectacular as some of its neighbours. Very nice temple that would be a major attraction in most parts of the world. Siem Reap is unique, however, due to the enormous number of temples in the vicinity. This was very nice but perhaps not as spectacular as some of its neighbours. If you have plenty of time you should see it. If you are pushed for time I'd play safe with Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom and maybe Ta Prohm.

One of my favorite. Lead by our guide, we entered this temple via an off-beaten track paved by yellow tree leaves. There were nobody but 5 of us. Walking on the soft leaves bathed in the sunshine and it was tranquil and solemn. This temple, thus, remained my one of the 2 favorite during my Siem Reap visit.

Very colorful temple / beware of tourist police. This ruins amazed me by having a greenish moss growth over grey rock, but also som reddish residue (iron in the rock?) ... so the pictures I took came out quite colorful.There is also a recently restored structure that has more Greek looking columns.We had a weird run in with a guy in tourist police uniform, first he approached us with tips for greta picture taking, then some tour guide advice and then he became our full fling tour guide for about 5 minutes, when he suddenly asked for money .. and the 1$ I offered was not enough ... so, who do I report a guy like that to? The tourist police?

Personal Favourite. Preah Khan's entrance over the moat is as yet untouched by concrete reconstruction and is more beautiful for it, highlights also include the library and the dancing hall, had great fun trying to imitate the dancers poses!

Absolutely beautiful and peaceful in the early morning. I came to this temple right after seeing the sunrise in Angkor Wat. Which means that the crowds were not out, yet. Also, Preah Khan is a bit further away ("big circle" on the map) so generally not as busy as Ta Prohm etc. This place, hidden in the forest, captivated me. I just sat there for 30 minutes, absolutely speechless from the beauty, just listening to the birds singing and feeling endless peace.Don't miss out on Preah Khan and go there! You will never forget it again! Tipp: Go there ideally before 8am. You will be rewarded with magic.

An amazing Temple. Preah Khan has a lot of green view and the tree growing around the temple ., also make you feel that you are on the heaven that have fresh air and cool weather make me forgot everything ., And this temple make all the tourist can relax 20 minute or 30 minute ,

Well worth the extra trip to a less crowded temple.. Preah Khan has the iconic strangler trees growing through the walls and set in amongst the forest. It's not on the day trip so lot less other tourists than the big names. Well worth seeking out with other smaller temples nearby each worth seeing.

Overlooked Place. Near from Bayon but think being overlooked by many. Dancers on lintels are fabulous, some devatas are said as the finest.Trees through some ruins telling vanity as can be seen in Ta Prohm... It is very different from the other ancient ruins of Angkor even in that you can see many traces of destroyed Budha, conflict of religions in historical spectrums.

Favourite temple. When you're in Siem Reap you get to see a fair number of ancient Khmer temples. Whilst Angkor Wat, Bayon and Angkor Thom are great, they also have a small army of people crawling all over no matter what the time. Preah Khan has the iconic strangler fig trees growing through the walls togehter with a beautiful setting in amongst the forest. It's cool and relaxing and is only modestly overrun with other tourists. Well worth seeking out.

Unbelievably interesting. Great visit here where you really get a sense of history. The building style is fascinating especially when you think that no cement was used yet it has survived for 1,500 years. The detailing on the various artifacts is still in fantastic condition considering its age. Preservation is an ongoing business here. Well worth visiting.....
small but interesting. Preah Khan is a smaller temple and another of the ones with trees growing up the walls. The carvings are very high quality

Preah Khan Temple built 1191. Preah khan was a monastery complex built in 1181 for King Jayavarman the Seventh on the site of his victory over the invading Chams.Not just a monastery but an entire city , our guide said that it would have covered nearly 60 hectares, with hundreds of farmers growing rice for the monks.A much quieter temple without the crowds, though best visited early morning.

The famous one from some film!. Expect the stories about film stars filming here, watch out for the roped off areas but even so it is a haunting place. And an ongoing archeological site which gives it an additional fascinating aspect.
Giant trees mix with stone. Other worldly, beautiful, exotic, mysterious. Have patience with crowds and your photos will be incredible. As will your memory

Very interesting temple complex. A very interesting temple with sections of it having collapsed and the large stones still in situ. The 'hall of mirrors' effect is very striking. The carvings and wall decorations are worth seeing. A large complex which wasn't crowded and the addition of the water around was very good.

A very interesting place to visit and vastly different from the other temples in Siem Reap. A great place to add to your itinerary so you are not only visiting traditional Khmer temples whilst in Siem Reap, a very interesting place and the experience of walking up to Preah Khan & being there itself makes for a very enjoyable experience.

Off the main tourist route. A huge temple in a beautiful setting.
Look closely and there are exquisite carvings everywhere.
Not to be missed.
Excellent place. A very haunting place. Many structures have collapsed and access is sometimes challenging. Go early to beat the crowd.

Impressive. This is one of the most impressive temples in Siem reap. It is spread out and has lots of corners and places to see and explore. Find a good guide who will not just show you the surface. make time to explore.
Beautiful. We went in early and had smaller crowds. Worth the trip in to see this amazing temple and then the sight of the water at the end was something I will never forget.

2nd largest complex around Angkor Wat. Very interesting complex, one of the top 6 for me. Unique 2-story building in a courtyard that almost looks Grecian. Definitely worth a look. Also, on the way there or from there, you might pass a wetland/reservoir that they are building up. Some great eerie pictures there of the swamp with bare trees sticking out that are slowly dying away as they drown in the reservoir.

Peaceful . After visiting the larger temples this one was a really pleasant surprise. Significantly smaller than the others but still has plenty to explore. Has hardly been restored so most of the temple has collapsed which is interesting to see in its raw form. Biggest upside is the peace and quiet here, being able to find somewhere that isn't completely overrun by tour groups.

Jungle-covered temple. Amazing to see how at one point the jungle took over the temples when they were abandoned. Some of the trees growing out of and on the temple structures are now actually holding them in place. A must see.

Beautiful. Another amazing piece to the jigsaw that is Angkor. The water looked lovely with the temple backdrop.It was great wandering around with an extremely knowledgeable guide. Not too much history, just enjoy your surroundings!!Must have time it right, hardly anyone there.
Beautiful. How can such a prosperous kingdom 700 yrs back existed .Brings and visualises memories how a prosperous land existed .

breathtakingly beautiful Phreah Khan. Phreah Khan is amazing. the temple itself is very unique in its own way and still in very condition. one of the best temple, my favourite... loved it so much
nad australia
2014

One of my favorites. I visited 7 temples; if I was ranking them, I would put this one after Ankgor Wat, Ankgor Thom, and Bantey Srie. I think those three are must-see. This one is tied with Ta Prohm, for me. It is right up there with the best temples. There are many places to explore, interesting carvings to look at, places where the collapsed parts of the temple were left in place. I was here on Saturday monring and it was not as crowded as the other major temples. I found a courtyard area that was fantastic for pictures and very few people. There were hallways and rooms to explore. I took lots of great pictures here. Excellent temple.

A mini and better Ta Prohm. It was a pleasant surprise. Impressive access with statues on each side and nice gate ( good sunlight at 2pm), then a bit like Ta proem but smaller and in a better shape: the surprise, on the right side, a "greek" temple with columns etc... Do not miss it. For us No 3 after Angkor Wat and Bayon.

ARCHITECTURE PAR EXCELLENCE. Built in Bayon style during the reign of JAYAVARMAN VII in late 12 c its a round columned with two storied building.in a serene and quiet place, trees on the sides to the entrance will add pleasant and cooling effect on a hot sunny day, visiting this gigantic temple ,which was once a BUDDHIST UNIVERSITY.The large sized tall SHIVA LINGA IS VERY ATTRCTIVE. HUGE TREES have grown on the walls of this temple (Inner portion) which is thretening the very existance of this monument .WONDERFUL. DO NOT MISS IT.
Absolutely Captivating!. Hugely detailed ruins, partially reconstructed, was not crowded, despite the other sites being mobbed with visitors. Well worth the visit.
One of the highlights of Angkor. This temple is not so crowded like some others and has a lot of atmosphere... We did spend 1 1/2 hours here and still did not see everything.

Our favorite of all the temples!. Even though this one had more ruins, it was situated in more of a natural setting. I felt more alone in this one than the masses of people rushing through all the other more known temples. Every corner found a new discovery. I had the opportunity to sit down and just enjoy being in the temple without the mad rush of people and tour groups. Occasionally one came through, but it wasn't as often. I loved the trees growing on and surrounding this temple.

Long Corridors and striking statues. This is a beautiful temple which is striking in its long corridors where one can see door after door going into the temple. there are many rooms connected to this temple, one can explore for a long time and barely see anybody else. I came upon an old lady making prayer ties and she blessed me with a beautiful red prayer tie which was quite a touching experience. I was practically in tears at the intensity if vibrations throughout this sacred place. There are many statues intact here, it requires at least a full morning to explore and if you are lucky enough to meet the beautiful old woman, give her a donation and take her blessings. This is a great place to meditate and contemplate.
Fantastic ruins. Although this one had a lot of ruins, it was one of my favorites. I really likes the roman column structure that stands- it's so different than all of the other temples.

LOVED this temple - must see for carvings. gorgeous and detailed temple with beautiful Hindu carvings - must see! we spent so much time here as every corner is an amazing photo opp!
Found out that the name means "sacred sword" and its full of beautiful carvings and passages, we spent way too much time here!

Beautiful Temple. This temple is the first temple outside the Angkor Thom which the TukTuks drivers take us to.On the way we have to pass away a small forest which is very cool and beautiful which cannot be seen in our country.Inside the temple you can also see the Big tree on the wall like Ta Prom temple.Inside the temple the ruin are every where some wall carving can be seen on the top of the entrance.
Great scenery. Sun took us to enter another gate where we could take awesome pictures with a bunch of 8 peoples. We had an awesome time there where we can jump, run and take pictures as we want :)

Impressive and not overrun. Huge temple that has some of the romantic part-overgrown feel of Ta Prohm but with much less in the way or ropes and barriers, so it feels more real and less of a theme park. Highly recommended.

Wow!. Preah Khan was built & dedicated by the Cambodian King Jayavarman VII to honour his father. Must have been a great Dad!A beautiful temple site displaying incredible stone carvings and clever architecture
Another lovely temple. One never tires of temples in Cambodia. The history is fabulous and the romance of the eventual rediscovery is amazing.

Not particularly interesting. We were recommended by our tuk tuk driver to go see the sunset here. The sunset itself was nice, but the hoards of tourists obstructing our view were not. So unless you like taking pictures of a sunset with people stretching their arms up high in the background, I suggest you go elsewhere for sunset viewing. The temple itself was fairly nice but not as interesting as some of the others.
Grand. This is a huge temple. There also was the amazing two floors' library building, and the dancing courtyard.....

Beautifully quiet :-). Preah Khan – (the Temple of the Sacred Sword) – eerily quiet save for the chatter of monkeys in the jungle, the chirp of cicadas and the birds way up in the trees. Left in their more jungle-engulfed condition they were fascinating and beautiful in an “Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom” kind of way. Amazing to think these wild and wonderful places exist in the world and have been pretty much untouched for more than a 1000 years…
Temple building gone mad. This complex is a crowded jumble of large and small galleries, towers, "libraries," and sanctuaries. Get lost!

Amazing !!!. This was different to the other temples it terms of 4 long wings and entrances. If you didn't remember which entrance you came in from you could be tracking back a forth a bit.
It was amazing and you wonder how it would have looked when first built as scale is so big. Loved this temple.

A peaceful place!. What a great temple complex, but best of all peaceful & with very few people around, so we were free to stroll around at our leisure, with our helpful guide showing us the way. Such a shame that some of the carvings are being stolen under the noses of the police!

GREAT for kids to clamber through. After a long day of temples the previous day, our younger kids were not super enthused about another day of more temples. We lightened the mood and pretended to be demon-fighters as we climbed in and out of each successive room, from one end of Preah Khan to the other. Preah Khan's just barely nudges Ta Prohm, in my book, as number one, because Preah Khan also has the huge trees growing in and around the temple stones, yet there is something eerily Indiana Jones-esque about slipping through an endless stream of rooms in one single direction. Though this was my favorite, I recommend saving it until after Angkor Wat and the others if you have kids with you.
Trees and roots are everywhere. Not many people come here, at least in December! It is different and has an atmosphere you can feel.
Better than Ta Prom. Preah Kahn is in the same style as Ta Prohm, with tree roots growing over the ruins.But less crowded and therefore more atmospheric.

Favourite temple in Angkor. Of all the temples I visited in the area this was my favourite. It was also almost deserted! Most tourists don't venture past Angkor Wat, "tomb raider" temple etc. which are nearer the main entrance to the complex.Definitely worth the extra 10 mins in a tuk tuk.

The Search for Enlightenment Part 6. Preah Khan. Remember this temple as the flat and very long Temple. Marvelous Greek like ruins and a few trees like the ones in the tomb raider temple can be outside the main temple. Inside this temple is fairly long passageway. Going through this narrow walkway, you will have the chance to get a photo opportunity. A local cop will offer to take a picture with you holding an imaginary light. It is actually a hole in the temple wall where sunlight passes though. Holding up your hand, it will appear that you are holding a ball of fire. He will then ask for a tip for taking your pictureThis is our 4th temple in the first day tour of Siem reap. It might leave one with temple overload. We must have walked 3-4 kilometers in total through 10th-13thcentury ruins. Tiring, but well worth it.
One of the Jewels of Angkor area. One of the less visited and eminently enjoyable attractions in Angkor area. We had a guide so we got excellent commentary.

One of the best temples away from the main tourist spots . Beautiful temple surrounded by Amazing Nature . Great morning light ! A must see for people who have enough time . Enter from one side and exit from the opposite side if possible

Amazing Sivalingams. Initially I was a little sceptical of this temple. However, when I stepped in it, I admit I was amazed by the abundance of shivalingams which symbolises shiva in Hinduism. They were everywhere but sadly in broken state. Nevertheless, there were 2 in good conditions. I would strongly recommend this temple to those who wish to ancient ruins of shiva temple. It goes without saying that Angkor Wat and East Mebon temples are equally and if not more breath taking. My trip was in December and due to the fact that it was a cooler season, every temple was packed with tourist. If you want to have a quiet moment to contemplate in the background of amazing temples, try Preah Ko. Very quiet in the morning. There was an old lady selling Cambodian scarfs, she sold me some scarfs for good price. I have no words to describe Angkor Wat. However, do visit the shops at the side of the Angkor Wat (within the complex). According to one shopkeeper, tourist does not venture into this area (perhaps duly instructed by their tour guides). You may be able to pick up a bargain because it is not frequented by tourist. Personally, I prefer to shop in temple areas rather than at Night Market. Night Market has very less variety for selection. But definitely good for food and drinks.

A great way to understand how Buddhism and Hinduism co-existed in one space. Preah Khan is a little more out of the way meaning that you get less people in a huge temple. It's a great place and it took me about an hour to fully explore (even then I must have left out loads of details). It's amazing seeing how a portion of the temple is steeped in Buddhist traditions (bigger doors) and the other Hinduism (lingas everywhere). I felt that this temple had more details and gave a clearer idea as to how the temples could have possibly looked (there was more carvings that hadn't been as touched). It's worth your time to also look through these little gates where the rubbles are to understand how the Apsara are doing their restoration work.

Favourite Temple. Preah Khan is so magical, it is my favourite temple.. not as crowded as the main temple.If you go alone, like other temples there will be locals wanting to show you around and expecting pay at the end, I gave $5 to the Cambodian that showed me around, totally worth it coming away with some amazing photos and load of information.Definitely worth the visit.

My Favourite Temple. It was great. I spent a week in Siem Reap and really feel that Preah Khan was my favourite place. It is more than a temple. I has a has the dimensions of a town. There are so many photo ops here. It is less crowded and therefore has more of a magical feel....

Temple of Buddhist and Hinduist. It is one of the Buddhist monastery built by Javarman 7 in the late 12 century. It combined Buddhist and Hinduist shrines, there are many beautiful sculptures hidden in the fallen piles of stones.

Playground of Ruins. This is by far one of my favorite ruin complexes in the world. The main corridor is open and walkable, but once you go down any of the side halls you end up on a massive ruined temples that not only scare off 99% of the tourist, but is incredibly exhilarating to explore.

Out of the way less touristy. I liked getting out of the area to see this temple. It was pretty quite when we were there so I liked that as well. It is interesting to see the construction here it has a large "avenue" approaching the site with lion statues which I felt was really interesting. This definitely was worth the drive.

Glorified State of Ruin. This is a temple where you can experience the glorified state of ruin that time and nature have brought about to this temple that dates to the 12th century. Here they have been both cautious and respectful with restoration efforts. They prefer to maintain things "as is" as opposed to making mistakes in restoration that might not be accurate. Here your imagination can run wild with your spiritual search!

My personal favorite. A good example of how the temples would look like if it was left to nature as most parts were largely unrestored. The temples had at least 3 entrances and it took me a good 15 minutes trying to figure out my way back to the west entrance. This temple is a maze for people with no sense of direction.

My Favourite. To me there is absolutely nothing to dislike about this temple. Similar to Ta Prohm, yet so different in many ways. This is my third visit to Preah Khan; although this time I had a very specific reason.In one of the walk ways sits a wonderful old lady, very wrinkled with twinkling eyes and a gorgeous toothless smile. She sits with her basket of wool ready to "bless" you by tying several strands around your wrist for good luck. This is her way of contributing to the family by way of tourist donations.I'll be returning in 2015 and I sincerely hope she is there.

Unusual lay out. The layout of this temple is somewhat unusual but when you are told what the rooms were used for you can just about imagine for example the Aspara type dancing for the king in the hall or the solitude of the like the grand national course as you need to climb over large pieces of stone to enter the next chamber!Some intricate carvings on the internal stone walls . worth a visit

Second only to Angkor Wat!. Personally I enjoyed this temple the most of them all in our three day trip, but the shear size of Angkor Wat cannot be matched. This temple is much bigger than anticipated, has amazing entrances and the growing fig trees crumbling the walls.

Wow. This was the last temple I visited in the Angkor area. I thought I was a bit jaded after Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom, Ta Prohm, Ta Som, Banteay Srei and Beng Mealea, but this temple still blew me away. It is extensive, beautiful bas reliefs and carvings. There are elements of the jungle temples with some areas overgrown but a lot of it is in remarkable condition. Even though it got crowded at times as a tour group passed by, it was also possible to wander alone through room after room. A magical experience!
A long atmospheric walk. This was great. Again seen early in the morning . Only a few people around. Fantastic atmosphere in endless corridors. Attractive pools at beginning and endRecommended

Excellent. Again the Cambodia parks score big. Affordable and close to the other major antiquities. Do the long haul much to see in the siem reaparea. This park again done almost to nice. Good feel. Enjoy

Most enjoyable. I visited all the major and most of the minor temples in the vinicity of Angkor Wat, Bayon, Ta Prohn, Pre Rup, etc. Preah Khan is not the biggest, ornate, nor most exotic. But after much research and three solid days of touring, I found it to be my favorite. It is the complete temple experience without the crowds. Parts are well preserved and others are in complete ruin. Many intact Apsaras and even a completely out of place two story structure that appears to be of Greek design. Visit all the big ones, wear yourself out, and then visit Preah Khan about 3PM. I entered from the west and exited via the east gate...best route for afternoon pics!

Another of my favourites. Another temple that was different in its own way yet amazing all the same. While the majority of the temple is in ruin the central walkway is deceptively long and gives you a good idea of the scale this temple once was.

Do visit if you can. Angkor Wat is of course the most impressing site in Angkor, but Preah Kahn together with Prasat Bayon are the next in line when your time is limited. This temple has one more plus: it needs less climbing and descending steep stairs, so go there e.g., at the end of the day. Ta Prohm is equally 'flat' and is very interesting too.

Another temple not to be missed. Every temple at Angkor archeological park is just unique in their own way. They all have interesting histories behind.This one is not so crowded so we could take nice photos and spent peaceful time imaging back to its ancient time!
A smaller edition of Ta Prohm. A beautiful, less visited temple with a bit of the same mood and feel as Ta Prohm. Has a couple of giant trees with no queues (when we were there) to take pictures.
Small Temple very well preserved. This one is one of the better preserved temples as it was discovered of ankor complex, is small and you can tour it in about an hour, so go for it.

" A lonely place for visit late in the afternoon. ". It's a stunning temple but when we got there about 4:30pm it was almost deserted. Nice place for
photo ops though.

So much to see, so few people. This temple has it all: a stunning bridge at the entrance, well preserved structures but also jungle claiming its area back, long hallways, lots of carvings and statues, but surprisingly few tourists. Maybe it was the a bit separate location or time of the year, early November. Maybe it was time of the day, noon, I don't know, but we got the temple to ourselves.My tip would be to visit the temples during the temples during the lunch hours. If you can stand the heat, you don't have to stand others.

Also very beautiful. It is maybe repetitive to say but in fact most temples are great. If you take the 3 days visit (which I strongly recommend) you will be able to see a variety of them and they might seem similar but they are not and each one has a history behind. Preah Khan is worth!

My favorite temple. We arrived around noon and entered from the east gate. No one was there. This was my favorite temple because the bas reliefs are in good shape, the property is large but over grown with jungle. We really had a chance to feel the mystery and timelessness of the Khmer ruins here.

Another stunning temple in Angkor. Preah Khan is again, a must visit temple in Siem Reap. It is less crowded with tourists and combines the beautiful architecture of other Angkor temples with a forest like feel of Ta Prohm because of the gigantic silk cotton trees around the temple. Really enjoyed this one and would recommend it happily.

Best Temple in Siem Reap. This temple hits the sweet spot between restored and natural. Parts of it have been restored and are busy and other parts are very hard to get to, allowing you to be alone and explore the harder to reach areas.

Great views and some well preserved structures. This was a temple that we spent a great deal of time in. There is a lot to see and like many others mentioned the lighting is great in this location. There are well preserved shrines and courtyards and it is very easy to walk through.The locals will hang out here and will walk you through if you would like a more guided experience for a tip.
Best of the best. Visit before sunrise as the light is the best for photos and there were less crowd. Between 2-4 PM. BEST smaller temple.

My favourite temple in Siem Reap. My sister and I visited beautiful Preah Khan on our bucket list trip to Cambodia and it is my absolute favourite temple in Siem Reap (yes, I loved it even more than Angkor Wat).From our fabulous guide I learnt that this amazing temple was built in 1191 by the wonderful Jayarvarman VII, who later built Angkor Wat, and it is dedicated to his father Dharanindravarman. It was originally home to 15,000 people and I've read that it was a centre for medicine and medical research where practitioners of Khmer, Chinese and Ayurvedic medicine joined together. It was incredibly progressive for it's time.The temple is entered by walking along the causeway across a moat, past the balustrades decorated with giants and Nagas. The complex is surrounded by high walls, and although many of them are crumbling there are some incredible carvings remaining. In particular, to the left of the entry towers is a beautiful Garuda, and there are many beautiful Apsaras and other carvings/reliefs to enjoy.From the very first glimpse of the entry towers I was enthralled. Preah Khan is crumbling, with many walls down and galleries ruined. But it is just beautiful. Preah Khan is so peaceful and calm and you can feel its history around you. I found that this place just touched my heart and my soul in a way I can't even describe. The history is palpable.The central temple contains two Srei Krup Leak, two special reliefs of Jarayajadevi and Indradevi who were the wives of Jayarvarman VII, the builder. These two reliefs hold a special place for many in Cambodia and people from across the country visit them to pray for fertility. We took a moment to visit here, and we were taught by our wonderful guide that we should always ask permission to approach special carvings/reliefs and statues by holding our hands in a prayer (or wai) position and ask silently for their blessing. Although I'm not religious, I think this is a beautiful way to pay homage to these incredible works of art and the long-departed artisans who created them.In the central part of the temple there is an old Buddhist Nun who spends her days there praying and giving blessings to all who visit. She speaks no English but I felt that I connected to her instantly. We took some time to sit with her and enjoyed finding out more about her through our wonderful guide. She spends her days there offering blessings to visitors and the donations given she uses to support monks in her small local temple. She gave us blessings, tied a small Buddhist blessing around our wrists, and touched my heart. It was one of those wonderful moments that find you when you travel, and stay in your memory forever.As you make your way around the complex, be sure to look around you as there are many beautiful things to see - views through doorways and windows, carvings hidden in shade, glimpses of the sky through damaged parts of the roof, and many, many carvings. Take your time to really wander around - you will not regret it.Things to remember when visiting:-* Be sure to book a private guide so you can move at your own pace. Make sure you get one that really knows their stuff as hearing the stories and legends around each temple was far more interesting than just hearing the facts. (If you need a guide then feel free to PM me - I'm more than happy to give you a recommendation!)* Wear sunblock and a hat. It is HOT.* Go early to avoid the majority of the tourist buses.* Be sure to take the time to just sit quietly and drink it all in. Bus loads of tourist will come along but they're gone soon enough so be patient. * Please remember to dress respectfully. Yes, you're on holiday and yes, it's hot but this is a temple.Enjoy! :)

Worth the effort.. My wife and I came here as a part of our self organised tour. We originally didn't have this temple in our itinerary but our hotel talked us into it. I certainly don't regret going here. It was a fantastic temple. It was very long and straight. In some parts, you can see people through the doors about 150mt away. We were lucky enough to witness a monk and some worshipers praying here in a room off the main corridor. People were just walking around them and they didn't care. This also seemed (well, appeared) to be a more sacred temple too as there was quite a few police around - more than the others. I'm not sure what they were policing exactly but one looked to be guarding an cylindrical artefact in one of the rooms. Certainly go here if you can. It is outside of Angkor Thom but it's worth the effort.

Definitely worth visiting. This is less visited and thus quieter than many of the temple areas in this region. There are some very special places here, and fabulous photo opportunities. Our guide had a child at home very sick while we were on tour so we sent him back to his family and explored Preah Khan on our own using just the blue planet guide book which we found excellent.We actually enjoyed this part of our tour most of all, as much of the time we were the only two people "there" as we moved around the site and we could let the history of the place just seep into our bones as we admired the wonderful carvings and workmanship.Would definitely recommend it

The best photo ops here. I loved taking photos here and even went back on my second day to do more at a different time of the day. It is far less crowded than Angkor Wat and also still has jungle around it in many places. It also has less restoration too.Also outside the main gate there are some stalls and a great little open air restaurant.I definitely recommend this temple over the more mainstream and popular places.
Photography Early for. We are working in Seam Reap on photography and this is a must stop. Recommed you go very early. You can get close so use the wide angle for details.

Picturesque Preah Khan!. Preah Khan, temple of the Sacred Sword, is undoubtedly one of my favorite Angkor temple. Gorgeously beautiful. The temple structures were mostly intact. The intricate carvings and color of stones rivals that of Banteay Srei. I found that every corner and most walls were picturesque in themselves and excellent photo backgrounds. I went picture crazy here and spent my most number of photos that I lost battery on my iPhone. Good thing my friend had a backup iPad 5 - the pictures were fantastic! Picture perfect Preah Khan!

Interesting and huge. After seeing Angkor Wat and several other nearby temples, I assumed that this temple would be more of the same, but no, every temple we went to was unique and impressive. This temple is very extensive, but it is less restored than some of the others. It was fun to wander through it on our own.

Explored this on our own. My husband and I explored this temple on our own. Like Wat, to go to the top level, you must wear sleeves and long shorts or pants. But what at trip to the top. Smallish temple, but not crowded at all - be prepared to climb a LOT of steps - worth every step!

My favourite. This was my most favourite temple in Siem Reap, maybe because of the timing of visit. We visited this one very early in the morning just after watching sun rise at Angkor Wat. We were the only ones when we reached and had the whole place to ourselves albeit 2-3 more tourists. The architecture of the temple is really interesting. As you enter the temple, you will realise the door entrances in front of you get bigger and bigger and when you look back you see how the entrance doors get smaller and smaller. We spent considerable time exploring the temple and the ruins; the silence enveloping us coupled with the rays from the morning sun inside the temple had a very calming effect and clearly made this my favourite. temple.

my favourite site - quiet & nice. This is probably not one of the one day trip in Siem Reap. However, I recommend you to go as there are less tourists. The site itself is very nice too. It is like mini Angkor Wat. You also have a big lake for sightseeing afterwards.

One of my favorite temples . We really enjoyed the visit to this temple. It's a little different to the other temples. We visited late afternoon so it wasn't as busy and we could get some good photos. Bring water and insect replant. When you leave the grounds of the temple you will get plenty of hassle from locals trying to sell you things.
A lovely surprise. Enjoyed this one very much, far less crowded but equally beautiful as the other, bigger sites. Definitely worth visiting.
Nature. large temple with tree which make our trip impress to this temple. the causeway to the centre of the temple was very special view.

as good as ta prohm. built by jayavarma who also built ta prohm, preah khan is a great site with trees, ruins and atmosphere.
a photographer's delight.

Secluded and Peaceful. If you want to escape the crowds and just casually explore a temple in the Angkor Wat complex then head to Preah Khan. The temple is ruined but this makes it fun to explore and discover some unbelievable architecture, with symbols and figures still present on the wall. The temple is a little out of the way, so it could be quite a walk/cycle but certainly worth it if you are in a vehicle.

The best by far!. This was one of the last temples we visited and it was by far the best! The architecture, the feel, the serenity far exceeded the rest. Even Angkor wat in our opinion! Do yourself a favour and don't leave this off your list. It is on the large tour of the temples!

Preferred this one to Angkor Wat. I visited this temple early in the morning before the crowds. Beautiful carvings, colours, trees growing through walls. Statues etc. A bit wilder than Angkor. Good photo opportunities if you get there early.

Another beauty not to be missed. Worth a visit. Again a stunning Khmer temple complex. Trees crawling over the walls make the picture complete an othyer beauty. It was raining (pity) during our visit so not many other tourists.

Get to imagine its ONCE greatness! :). Though greeted by headless statues (ruined through the passage of time due to various causes, I guess) lining on both sides of the gate, I could not help being impressed by the long, long corridor (it could LITERALLY very well be about a kilometer from one end to the other!) inside this ancient palace building and also could not help imagining how awesome this corridor (and the rooms and areas it leads to on both sides which are now pretty much like heaps of rubble) must have looked in the time of the Jayarvarman kings who resided in this palace and also built the Angkor temples nearby during the heydays of the Khmer Empire.There's also a big bell about halfway along the corridor, and the bell has like a tall cone on top of it, and the wall above the doorway right behind the bell has two openings which can be "aligned" with the cone on the bell when you take a picture, and it will SURE look like a "candle" on the bell (my photo 3 as an example :) )!There's like a courtyard too on the left when you get to the end of the corridor with some of its own buildings and where you can relax a bit before walking back on the long corridor the same way you came in (I wished there was a way out at the end like at Ta Prohm and Banteay Kadei, but that wasn't the case with Preah Khan, only one way for both in and out).Preah Khan was the third stop on my Angkor circuit tour starting at Angkor Wat, then Angkor Thom, then Preah Khan, then Ta Keo, then Ta Prohom, then Banteay Kadei and Sras Srang reservoir, then Phnom Bakheng the temple on a mountain. If you're coming by minibus from Poipet, and if you see the tour operator named Vara when you get off in Siem Reap, I highly recommend his services - honest, timely pickups and no hidden charges except some small tip to your driver at day's end after the tour.Also, an important reminder is to have your ticket that you obtained at the main entrance (before getting to Angkor Wat) at all times during the tour since they check those tickets at each subsequent stop, not just at Angkor Wat.
Moving and incredible!. Preach Khan is very worth a visit - in the top three in my opinion! Quiet and on its own in all it's glory!
Another excellant temple. As excellent as the rest, smaller than Angkor Wat but great architecture and photo opportunities of the many carved reliefs

A Privilege to see this place.. Siem Reap is not short of a temple, they are astonishing to see and my admiration goes out to the people holding them upright. For me, however, Preah Khan is utterly magnificent, why it "beats" the others I cannot say for sure. The quiet perhaps, the feel, the beauty? I do not know I would just suggest you go and marvel in your own way.
Unbelievable. All the Angkor's temples is incrediable. I have never experience any like this in my life. Will be back for more exploring!
Great place. One of the temples to visit. It has great views and a great place to take pictures. I would recommend to visit this temple.

Undisturbed beauty...one of the top 5 temples in Angkor. Preah Khan is one of the best temples for exploring and photography, especially if you can go in the morning when there are less people. Similar to Ta Promh, there are trees growing into the walls, on top of the roof, etc and given how much the rock walls are shifting, I don't think that people will be able to explore through all the walkways for many more years like you can today...at some point, it will become unsafe or they will rope it off or put scaffolding up. I highly recommend going to this temple (similar to many others) with a guide who can take you to "off the beaten path" places which are best for photography, especially if you don't want people scattered all over your photos.

In my top two temples to see!. An excellent place in Angkor Wat - the others being Bayon and Ta Phrom. IF YOU HAVE LIMITED TIME (or don't want to spend $40 on a two-day pass), just visit these three and maybe Angkor Wat itself if time permits. There are excellent areas with trees wrapped around the temple and great green areas for photos – don’t be afraid to get in the grass to go to a place that looks like it will make a great photo in the back (North) of the temple- less tourists here made it more enjoyable. If it is rainy, keep you pass in your wallet – or bring an ID card holder with a strap to put around your neck – every temple you need to show your pass…
Early morning is best. The temple was serene and peaceful in the early morning. We went at about 0800 and almost had the place to ourselves. Lovely forest setting and tranquil atmosphere. Very nice.
Best one. I liked this temple temple best of all. You could really explore so many nooks and crannies. So good.

H U G E - Lots to see. Toured in late afternoon. Not many people there. The temple is large and it takes some time to walk through. It is interesting to see what nature has done to this site. Wear comfortable shoes and take water. I was amazed at the strength of the structure. The construction must have been something to accomplish. Although not as well known, I really liked it. You should plan to see. Budget enough b time as there is a lot to see.

you won't be miss it.. Preah Khan, another gem of this beautiful archaeological area, I visited Angkor Thom just moving in clockwise direction, it is a short distance from the immense Bayon temple. Preah Khan is a minor temple, but in my opinion not to be missed, not crowded and a perfect backdrop for photos and different among all the other temples. It was for me a visit of about 15 minutes, enough time to fully enjoy this fantastic place.

How the hell did they make this place back then?. Big, impressive and an architectural marvel. Certainly a must see. Early morning clearly the best time before it heats up too much. Don't let the scammers with the incense sticks get you on the way in and guild you into paying $20 which goes straight into their pockets. I noticed that they were conspicuously absent on the way out of the main Wat.I think the stairs to the highest level only opens for business at 8am so plan for that if you want to go right to the top.This place is beautiful, stunning an simply amazing.

Love this temple! . Quite big and it's very long. Consist of few segments and part. Very nice. Spend quite times here. Thank god my Tuktuk driver willing to wait. Very peaceful since not many people. Seems like the temple is belongs to you only. Love this temple!

Must see. This is one of the best places to see in Siem Reap. Don't miss it!
Best time to visit is early morning and then you can avoid the crowds.

Simply amazing. This temple was probably the least busy temple we visited during our entire stay. It is huge though and takes a long time to walk through. I would recommend a guide to tell you about the temple and its history as it will increase your experience.

Huge!. This temple just keeps going and going! Maybe it was the size, but it felt empty when we visited. We didn't see a lot of other people while we were here. Because of the size and the lack of other visitors touring this temple seems very Tomb Raider/Indiana Jones. Lots of areas to explore and poke your head into. I definitely recommend a visit to this temple for some at-your-own pace exploring. Lots of shade also keeps this temple cooler.

Candlelight Image. In the ruins of one of the temple buildings is what seems to be a shrine. If you angle your camera with the crack in the roof it appears to be a flame above the shrine. Simply amazing!

My favorite of the ruins we visited.. With limited time we did all the "biggies" Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom, the tomb raider ruin with the big trees and Preah Khan. Preah Khan was my favorite. It's on the North side of the park, which to me was the most beautiful side. The moss and forest has taken over that side making everything look like a green wonderland. Preah Khan is in ruins, no pun intended. The trees have uprooted much of the foundation making it broken in the most wonderful beautiful way. It's smaller than some of the other ruins and has a lot of long hallways with stupas and Buddha statues at many of the cross sections. It has beautiful views through every "window" you pass by. The broken foundation, moss covered stone and forest landscape makes it the most magical of the sites we visited to me.

Loved the back part of it. From what I remember, Preah Khan was huge but repetitive. The only parts I really enjoyed were the colonnade and pond in the back, which were beautiful. We also saw Preah Khan towards the end of our Angkor trip, so it could have just been us tiring of temple-touring.

Quiet, peaceful and stunning. A good temple to start at if you wish to avoid the sunrise crowds at Angkor Wat. Quite different to many of the other temples so remains interesting even after a full day of temples.

Temple of sacred sword. Our personal favourite this time around, the temple was built by King Jayavarman VII as a dedication to his father. Originally built as a Buddhist monastery and school, it was also the King's residence for a short period of time.The cylindrical columns on the building next to the main temple is really extraordinary. This temple is huge and is full of passages and carvings. Lots of photo ops.
Small and interesting. Interesting architecture. NIce to see it as it is, no renovation. Can get beautiful picture of the stupa in the middle--not like a candle as a guy there kept telling you.

Amazing. Yes, I added this temple when doing the itinerary, and it didn't dissappoint, i took my time, it is quite large, and a real delight to wander and soak up the ambiance, I went during a quiet time of the day and the area wasn't overloaded with people which provided great photo opportunities!

Amazing. Yes, I added this temple when doing the itinerary, and it didn't dissappoint, i took my time, it is quite large, and a real delight to wander and soak up the ambiance, I went during a quiet time of the day and the area wasn't overloaded with people which provided great photo opportunities!

A lovely temple in piles of rubble. This is a larger temple, and it's got great atmosphere. When we were there, in the mid-afternoon, there were very few visitors, and we could really enjoy the temple. There's a bit of a walk from the tuk tuk drop-off area, but the forest surrounding it adds to the ancient feeling. Do some reading about it in a guide book beforehand; it really helps to imagine it as it was!

Spectacular. This one is a the top of my list for recommendations in Siem Reap. We came here by request, otherwise I don't think our guide would have brought us. This may be why it is so much emptier when compared to some of the other main attractions. This is the "father" temple and the "mother" temple is also nearby (Ta Prohm).There is a very long corridor which takes you from one end of the temple to the other. You can wander off down hallways to find yourself completely alone in very quiet and serene settings. I really enjoyed the temples that weren't flooded with people, so this was big plus for me. We encountered a policeman (at least, he was dressed as one) who took some pictures for us and led us around to some sights. I gave him a few dollars for his help.At the far end of the temple is an enormous tree draped over crumbling wall. Just to see it is worth the journey.

Surprisingly breathtaking!. Before I visit here, I never know there is another very beautiful temple other than Bayon, Ta Prohm & Angkor Wat. Finding this temple in the middle of the forest, truly is a rough diamond in the hidden forest. This temple really reminds me of the legendary adventurous game of Tomb Raider, Lara Croft. Walking around here surely makes me feel like I'm Lara, enjoying my moments within the mysterious tomb and temple, feel the ancient thrills running down my spine through all the carvings, all the rooms, hallways, if you love ancient ruins, everything here is magical, simply breathtaking!Feels like it's Lara Croft's playground.. No wonder she loves to stroll around in places like these, hahahaI will definitely coming back here, definitely!

Like Ta Prohm only quieter. This temple is very similar to Ta Prohm (the Tomb Raider Temple) but is less touristy and is not always on the big circuit of Temples for visitors with a short stay in Siem Reap. The combination of colours of the stone, jungle, and mosses is beautiful.
Beautiful. Definately worth visiting. Not as touristic as the other temples so we can take our time enjoying this amazing temple.

The temple of mirroring doors anon a jungle setting. This temple is amazing as it has very long alleys which door after door in a seemingly endless way as if one holds a mirror reflecting in another mirror. The temple has also some amazing trees growing over it. When we went on our way back from Banta Srey in the early afternoon, there were hardly any people there, great for photography!
best temple. preah khan temple it is very nice temple , it is very big temple and it is have a lot of caving on the wall and in side , it far siem reap town about 16km. it is i like it .

Amazing, all part of the Main Temple Circuit. Wicked, awesome ruins. Felt very privileged to be there and loads of photography moments. Truly awesome sights. After 3 day pass of the temple complex, it was all incredible and enough if I might add wi out being temples out and the excessive heat and sweat loss from our bodies.....take loads of water! Be warned a cloth to mop your brow to!
Worth seeing. Much of this temple is in ruins, but the Hall of Dancers, with the deep relief motif, is a highlight. Other temples have more priority but if you have time, this is worth seeing.
Absolutely stunning. Preah Khan has been left largely unrestored, with numerous trees and other vegetation growing among the ruins. Loved the Guards by the entrance of Preah Khan :-)

Beautiful Mess. Will have you hushed, relaxed and contemplative if you're the type who likes discovering hidden gems, and lost treasures.
I'd love to go back there, sit down under one of the beautiful Teak trees and just soak in the magic of what has been, and what is left beautifully.

Don't miss this temple - the only Angkor Temple built as a buddhist temple.. I loved Preah Khan - it was the only temple with a small historical museum-type exhibit at the entrance. There was a lot of information about the temple and the restoration. Truly beautiful, and I learned how it differed from the other Angkor temples that were built as Hindu temples. Many people are desperate for work and will want to be your guide. Sometimes they'll start following you around and acting as your guide even if you didn't hire them, and then they want to be paid. Best to tell them you really don't want a guide if you don't. Otherwise settle on a price right away.

Enormous and enigmatic - well worth a visit. Preah Khan doesn't get the attention is deserves from the visiting public, but it is well recognised as evidenced by the restoration works still being done by the World Monuments Fund (WMF). Its quietness is a welcome change from some of the more popular temples, and one can usually wander this huge edifice in peace, exploring its many wonders. Don't miss the mysterious two storey building near the East gate...
Exploring History.. This is a great site to visit and take in all the sculptures and history that surrounds this location. Very well worth the visit.

The less-visited jungle temple.. Amazing sculpture, loads of corridors to explore, atmospheric tree-roots climbing over the walls, and far fewer tourists than the more central temples. Get your tuk-tuk driver to drop you at one entrance and pick you up at the far end, to avoid having to walk all the way back. This is a big site!
Underrated. i really liked this one, nice and quiet and easy to miss as it is just outside Thom, you will know you are there as there are food stalls on the opposite side of the road

Beautiful site ruined by noise of video games. Great and interesting site. One of my favourites and large enough to explore. Was there around 8am and lots of guides hanging around playing loud games and pop music on their phones. Somewhat ruined the atmosphere.

Quiet temple in the jungle . Great temple, less tourists than the other big three and a quiet location really get that first time explorer feeling, just one thing annoying is the police officers who "help take photos" of the stupa and demand money! Otherwise all great!!

Beautiful, less crowds. We had this place to ourselves, which makes the experience so much better. We used a guide, please feel free to message me for his details, he was wonderful. We arrived early, it was so peaceful, amazing, wear some sneaks so you can scamble about. Its beautiful. amazing photo's, Beat the crowds get a 3 day pass and put this one on your list.

Absolutely Worth a Visit!. This temple was the least crowded and least visited, probably the reasons why we found it the most charming. The entrance has a beautiful, hidden lake (that we termed the 'Notebook' lake, because it resembles the lake in which Ryan Gosling takes Rachel McAdams in a boat amongst the swans). There is a wooden bridge overlooking the lake (where we also found rare "four clover leaves"). The temple itself (dedicated to the father of Rajvarman the VIIth) was grand with beautiful carvings of Lord Shiva and Buddha on opposite walls (signifying the amalgamation of religions and cultures at that time). The walls and the floor had holes in them that were previously filled with gem stones. This temple took us back 10 centuries engulfing us with the aura of celebrated royalty.
An adventure. This is a much quieter version of Ta Prohm. Less tourists and better photo opportunities.A lot of steps and uneven surfaces to negotiate so wear proper shoes and take care!
Good statue. The statue here is very beautiful, i walk into the temple I will amazing for me.Really love this place!
a beautiful view. This place has a very beautiful surrounding makes you feel peacefull and calm the river has crystal clear water and a good place for photography.

Great Temple and very peaceful.. Not many people visit this temple and that makes it perfect for exploring and getting some good photos.It is similar to Ta Prohm and is a sprawling complex so take your time to explore it.Well recommend this temple.

Best temple in Angkor Complex for photographers. We visited all the major temples in the area, and Preah Khan was the best from my standpoint as a photographer. As most others mentioned this is less touristy than many of the more famous temples and as a result has (thus far) avoided the deluge of tour buses offloading tourists by the dozen. There are many intricate doorways and passages to take photos of and they have not been extensively restored, preserving some of the mystique of the olden times. I especially enjoyed taking photos of the local priestesses on premise - the juxtaposition with the grey walls was something special. You can also get your fill of the "overgrown trees" photo opps without wrestling others like you have to at Ta Prohm.

Less touristy than Ta Prohm. Preah Khan (meaning ‘Sacred Sword’) is a sprawling monastic complex, that lends itself to the adventurous type of explorer, and if often compared to Ta Prohm. However, Preah Khan is much less touristy than its more famous cousin. Noted for its use of round columns, which is unusual from the Angkor Empire, it is full of passages and little nooks and crannies to explore within the jungle, with many ample photo opportunities along the way. Originally, Preah Khan was a Buddhist monastery, but during the reconstruction of Angkor Thom, King Jayavarman VII also used it as his place of residence. Interestingly, the King dedicated Preah Khan to his father, and the architecturally-similar Ta Prohm to his mother. Many of Preah Khan’s Buddhist representations were destroyed by Hindu invaders in later years, and as such Bodhisattvas are now carved over the original images of Buddha in the stone. I was surprised at how much I enjoyed it here at Preah Khan, but it takes much longer to get here from Siem Reap downtown, than say Ta Prohm.

Heritage Building. Awesome stories you can learn from every details of structure carving. You will be amazed on how ancient people built the temple with scratch hand. More like thinking, architecture vs nature. Plus, trees are so dino-ages. Nothing more like Preah Khan.

Perhaps better than Ta Prohm. Perhaps better than Ta Prohm because it's less crowded quieter.Like every other temple, it's falling to bits. But I really prefer if they hold back on some of the restorations. Some of them look pretty bad and poor quality.
Another amazing temple. Positive points: 1- not too crowded. 2- amazing architecture. 3- not fully restored thus it gives off a more authentic feel to the ruins.

Still impressive yet not too restored. Great place to get some perspective. The bass reliefs are still in reasonable detail and although some areas have been restored the place still gives you that first explorer or tomb raider type experience. Watch out for the locals who pretend to be a helpful guide and then demand stupid money. We had one chap try and tell us about the temple and then demand $20. To put that into perspective $20 gets you a tuk tuk for the whole day including a grande or petit tour of the temples of Angkor

Another must do if visiting Seim Reap.. These temple structure around Seim Reap are amazing and Preah Khan is no different. A Buddhist temple constructed late 12 th century by King Jayavarman v11. It is full of carvings and some fantastic photos to be shot. Trees have anchored themselves on several structure that lend to some fascinating photos. Wear sensible shoes and take a spare camera battery with you as you will probably need it, the grounds are uneven and there are steps to be climbed. Please don't touch the carvings as the sweat and acid from your hands will only deteriorate the sand stone and with the volume of people that pass though these structures, they must be preserved for the Cambodian people's heritage. I personally totally loved the whole Angkor experience and recommend that a visit is a must if in Seim Reap. This is not an attraction for wheel chair bound guests as the ground is uneven and there are too many steps to be negotiated.
Another amazing temple. Be sure to explore more than Ta Prohm, Bayon and Angkor Wat. This temple was different than the rest and worth visiting.

Nice temple. This temple also was worth a visit. Not as stringing as a couple of the main temples but has merit on its own as well.had quite a few tourists when I was there but enough room to move.Also involved a nice walk.

Really amazing jungle temple. This was the second temple we visited during our stay in Cambodia. Due to Khmer New Year on the 14-16th of April the roads around other Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom were extremely busy and it took us nearly an hour by Tuk-Tuk from Siem Reap. This temple was probably the least busy temple we visited during our entire stay. It is huge though and takes a long time to walk through. I would recommend a guide to tell you about the temple and its history as it will increase your experience. Just remember that it is dry, hot and dusty. We opted for a 3 day pass and did 2 temples a day on two different days and stayed for about 2 hours at each temple. Don't forget to bring plenty of water and protection against the sun.

A fascinating temple site. A ruined, but highly atmospheric melange of tree roots and crumbling stone structures. A visit to this site makes for an interesting contrast with the more imposing Angkor Wat. Currently being restored by the World Monument Fund and in places is in remarkably good condition.

One of the best temple sites. We visited Preah Khan after a sunrise visit to Angkor Wat and found there were only two other people on site as it was fairly early and the sun was just coming up behind the ruins. This was by far one of my favourite areas to visit. There were some tangled trees giving the feeling of Ta Prohm and plenty of marks and carvings to keep you busy for hours. I found only one seller at the back of the ruins and we were left to ourselves the whole time to wander around. Perhaps purchase a proper guide book (this goes for all the temples!) but we did bump into a local who told us some fascinating history about the site and the urns held inside. Definitely try to put this site on your tour even just for the drive up there and the scenery leading up to the temples.

A very interesting large site.. We enjoyed our visit to Preah Kahn very much. It's fairly large and spread out but has much to offer. In addition to the temple complex, there are some bas reliefs of apsaras that are very beautiful.

Nice temple with a bit Ta Phrom feeling. The temple is quite big and was not crowded when we visited before noon. It has some ruins and it was really nice to walk between the ruins. At the end of the temple there is a huge tree growing on the wall which make a similar feeling like in Ta Phrom.
Beautiful temple. I would recommend that you don't miss this temple, the setting is great and there are some fantastic photo opportunities and wonderful carvings.

Intricate stone work, tree-covered parts of temple. Another of my favorite temples at Angkor Wat. A smaller temple that has a lot to offer, especially for photographers. I likes the intricate stone work and was shooting away with my camera (got some amazing shots). And it also has trees that have overgrown the temple many ages ago. you can walk through (just like at Ta Prohm), enter on one side and exit on the other (make sure your tuk tuk driver rally awaits you on the other side!).

Wonderful. Rode here on bicycle as part of the 30k Temple circuit. All the Temples were amazing.Very hot day. Great time sitting in the shade watching the sights and wondering what it would have been like there when it was first built.
Great. All the temples are really great, you can't go to Siem Reap without seeing them as that's what everyone does. They can get busy in the late morning but we found them to be quite quiet really.

Less crowded alternative to Ta Prohm. This temple complex is less popular than Ta Prohm, but in my opinion has just as many photo opportunities with overgrown wall trees, is much less crowded, and is much larger and has more opportunity for climbing and exploration.
absolutely gorgeous. practise your pose so that you can tak hundreds of photos. Wear comfy shoes, wear sunnies and cap and bring enough water.

Relatively quiet temple. This temple, built by Jayavarman VII, is horizontally laid out and is a vast maze of corridor after corridor, courtyard after courtyard. Unlike Angkor Wat, there's no upward climb, as there is really no elevated central temple, making Preah Khan easier to navigate. But beware - one can easily get lost in all of those eerie, narrow hallways!I entered Preah Khan through the East Gate - the historical entrance. After a few corridors was a courtyard, to the right of which is the curious "Grecian-style" two-story building noted in Lonely Planet's "Cambodia". The unique style of this building - utilizing round, rather than square, columns and with two stories, makes it easily the most interesting part of Preah Khan. Iti is even, for me, the main attraction.My guide Mr. Sophan then led me to the central Prasat, with it's holed roof. There were holes in the wall, allegedly once full of gemstones. A few more turns and we ended up in a small chamber with a statue of the King's mother, here venerated as a goddess who grants wishes. Mr. Sophan said that even high-ranking politicians come here to pray. The small chamber was filled with incense smoke wafting upwards, and the shaft of light to the left made for a spiritual, surreal image. The carvings are exquisite, though parts of the temple have fallen into ruin and are impassable. Preah Khan is best explored with a guide as it is very easy to get lost - on my return trip three days later I did get lost and had to ask random tour guides for a way out.Highly recommended!

Smaller temple with much to see. This temple is one of the smaller temples in Angkor. Great carvings. You could definitely benefit from a guide here, but it is a great place to explore on your own as well.
huge and beautiful. this is I believe the biggest single temple in the area. It is really beautiful and worth the visit in my opinion, don't miss it.

Quietish temple. Our guide advised us to visit this temple late in the afternoon because of the light making for good photos and he was quite rightPit is a bit out on a limb but well worth the effortWe went from Siem Reap by tuk tuk which took about 45minutes each way at $8 return,your driver will wait whilst you wonder around,we were there about 90 minutes and it was beautiful

Beautiful and not on all tour lists. This is a substantially sized temple that has all the elements: beautiful sculptures, lichen covered walls, intricate passageways and surrounded by large and some intruding trees. I loved it!

One of my favourite temples. It's one of the temples, where trees seem to have embodied themselves in the ancient architecture. We visited in the heat of midday, when there weren't too many other tourists.

Tranquil temple a little way out. The setting of this temple is very tranquil set among the small lakes full of dragonflies and lotus plants. It is being restored and is a little way out of the main city. Enroute, you get to pass small villages with houses stil built on stilts.

Beautiful... no tourists.. I'd reccomend getting there around 3pm, so one can enjoy the late afternoon sunlight and serenity of the place.
Oh, there is quiet a cool Khmer Rouge bunker at the very very end! This was their last stand.

Top of your list. This temple, while further away is a must see and rivals Bayon in regards to wonder. Pay close attention to the changing door sizes as you near the centre. Also be sure to explore the ENTIRE complex as you will come across some surprises such as various trees (look like an elephant trunk) growing over the wall and at the one altar you'll also note that it looks like a lit candle due to the cracks in the rock allowing light through. Don't rush through this one.

My second favorirte. I loved the symmetry of the squares inside it. It also has the entrance similar to Angkor Wat. I am amazed on the how the architecture and i still cant imagine how they plan on the architecture despite that they don't have tools that we have right now.

Unexpected. This temple isr eally beautiful and not so crowded. Extense corridors, falling stones, linga statues... Carvings are beatufil but eroded, trees inside... I was surprised!It's worth a visit

worth a visit. I really liked exploring this area. The only negative thing I would have to say about the place is the tourist police. One of them approached us and starting making small talk (should have been our first hint). Then he started telling us stuff about the temple and its history. When he was finished with an area, he asked us for money because he took a picture of us and told us some history. Other than spending 10 minutes with this guy, we had a great time.

Worth Visiting. Preah Khan is big and I recommend hiring a guide to understand this beauty.I found Preah Khan really beautiful and in pretty good shape. There are some big trees that unlike nearby Ta Prohm, have been cut down to save the structure. We visited in the afternoon and there were very few tourists around. The temple has some really fine and unique carvings and an interesting architecture. It's easy to lose yourself in the atmosphere of Preah Khan.

Very good. I walk from the North Gate of Angkor Thom (around 2km), very nice walk. I got there early in the morning so not a lot of people in the temple. In some places I was all alone. Great atmosphere. Great place. Not to be missed!!!!!
Unique. The round columned 2 story building makes this ruin unique. Nice selection of Asuras on the naga bridges.

A must on your sightseeing list. Extensive, evocative ruins left largely unrestored, with trees and other vegetation growing among the stones. Very atmospheric where one can lose oneself while wandering through.

One of Angkor's Must Sees!. The charm of Preah Khan Iies in its slightly ruinous state. A nice balance between safely restored, and naturally crumbling beauty has been reached here. My favourite visit here, found 3 Khmer children skipping through the ruins singing songs, and I managed to get a beautiful photograph of them perched on stone blocks. My tip, if you like Preah Khan, you'd love Beng Mealea! It's a bit further out of Siem Reap, but it is unrestored and you truly get that Tomb Raider feeling lol. My tuk tuk driver, Navuth from angkordriverprivatetour.com took me there, and it was my favourite part of my visit to Siem Reap.

My favorite temple. While other Angkor temples are all amazing, this is personally my most favorite one, probably because of its unrestored condition that created mysterious feeling. The temple is not as crowded as other big ones, and it feels so great walking though the rumbles. I imagined I was in a maze and how complex, how large, how beautiful this temple used to be. Recommended to visit at around 4.30 - 5 pm to truly feel its serenity.

Another Wonder of Angkor. Another truly amazing relic in amongst the jungle - made even more mysterious and unique with the encroaching vegetation within and around it. The contrasting light and shadows in doorways and the ruins of this temple certainly make it worth visiting. Angkor certainly shows how closely the Buddhist and Hindu images are aligned.
A must place. Every temple is great and every temple is worth visiting. A definite place off my bucket list! From Angkor Wat to Preah Kahn, the place just amazes you
Rumble in the Jungle. Smaller than Ta Phrom but also impressive and with less people. Just relaxing and somehow "not real".

Buddhist Temple for over 1000 monks!!. The temple complex starts with a 300mtr long terrace lined with carved markers before you enter the buildings. Full of carvings and walkways there is plenty of photo opportunities here. There is even a separate building with "Roman" collums, very strange indeed. This building was dedicated to Jayavarman's father
Unrestored temple. This has had very little restoration - just enough to make it safe for visitors, and it was good to see a temple "in the raw". A very restful place, well worth a visit

A treasure! A gem! Most definitely! . My favorite in Siem Riep, this complex is similar to the much more crowded Ta Prohm.... But not much restoration work has been done to this place. But that adds to it's charm! By the time we got there (evening) the crowd had emptied out, and the place, oh so quiet so serene! Enormous trees snake through the rumbles and much of the temple, and with the sunset as a backdrop, it's definitely going to steal your heart! A must see!

Most beautiful place on earth!. Unlike the other temples, this one has had far less restoration work. This is not in any way a bad thing, the temple has become a part of the jungle and is definitely the most peaceful serene place I have been in my entire life. I spent hours here exploring. If you're going to the temples please don't miss this one. You'll regret it.

Haunting, light-filled, tree-covered treasure. All of the temples in Siem Reap amazed us, but Preah Khan somehow had the most character, and also, somehow, felt the most imbued with living history, though it also feels so much like a real ruin. It's fascinating and worth lingering explorations…

The Father temple. This temple is a gem. Dedicated to the king's father, the temple housed the sacred sword (hence the name). A long west/east oriented temple, we came in over the lovely (and quiet) western causeway. Much of the temple is in a ruinous state but much is intact enough to evoke a great deal of atmosphere and interest. The building which housed the sacred sword is notable for its circular supporting columns and there are lots of quite detailed apsara and other carvings still viewable. A guide is useful here in order to understand much of the design (including variable doorway heights) - but if you don't have one, the Tourist Police will enthusiastically relieve you of your money and provide a narrative for you! Best viewed early morning when it's quiet and at its tranquil best

Untouched and beautiful. Far from all all touristy spots, this temple is just untouched. You can peacefully explore this large complex which offers both jungles and ruins. Similar to Ta Prohm and Beng Mealea, it has trees and roots scattered everywhere. Photographers can go here to take pictures of the architectural beauty without any tourist disturbance. Walking through the vast and empty corridors of this temple was hauntingly beautiful. The fusion of Hinduism and Buddhism in Cambodian temples is best brought out in this one.

You need to visit here. This was a great temple to walk around and take another "billion' photos. As I keep saying, having a guide really was great due to the information provided, giving you a better understanding of the temples.
Incredibly peaceful. Preah Khan is a gorgeous temple to visit, and it was an incredibly peaceful place to spend a few hours, even during the high season.

worth a visit. Large site in the jungle with trees growing out of the walls but not as busy as Tar Prom. Get a blessing from the elderly lady sitting well inside the temple by donating a $1. She isn't just a photo object people. If you want a photo make a donation. And it will make you feel good.

Certainly worth a visit.. A big temple with countless passages and carvings. Although it is in quite bad state, it certainly is among my top temples to see. It is simply stunning.Take plenty of time to wonder around and enjoy its beauty.

Great to explore, go early or late. Preah Kahn was one of my favourites in the Angkor area. It doesn't have iconic views like others (except maybe the odd building with round columns) and it is a lot of fun to explore. The corridors are small and open into tiny courtyards where you can escape the crowds and discover carvings, statues, views through windows... and that's just the main building. There are several!It also features a huge tree encroaching the East outer wall, like its famous cousin Ta Prohm.Go early in the morning around 7 and you'll be able to enjoy it without almost anybody, especially the huge tree on the East side and the Hall of Dancers. It was also good in the afternoon around 4:30.

Giant trees. It's huge, full of carvings, passages and places to take pictures. In some cases, the trees cannot be cut because they are actually preventing the walls from collapsing. Amazing place to take pictures. We went early -7am. There were people but it was not a problem to explore and take pics

Less crowded but complete temple. Slightly less visited than Angkor Wat or Bayon but it's a very large temple that have a lot of charms. Some big trees on the ruins, specific sworded statues, broad causeways and striking Garuda's along the wall and it's own Baray on the East. Definitively a must see.

Worth making the effort. It was good to get beyond the main tour sites and see a temple that was not fully resorted, yet all the more interesting for it.
Easy to "self guide" and just explore and let the imagination work..

Beautiful but get there before 10:30 or after 2pm to see the Pink Colour best!. This one is small and crowded but it was one of my favourite. Even though our guide didn't get us there during the best viewing time the carvings here are the best we've seen at all the temples.

The least preserved of all the temples we saw. This was temple number one and it was probably the least crowded- the stucco walls would have had gemstones - wow imagine that ! This temple made an impression on me yet when I went to see others I realised that this one has maybe the least amount of detail - only in comparison.It is well worth visiting and makes a great starter to the trecking ahead with all the other temples you may want to visit.. Much has been laid to ruins due to humidity, the hindu/buddhist wars, looters and all the other wars that poor Cambodia has suffered- you can see bullet holes in some of the stones.
