Try to imagine what life was like for the people then- their trade in beehives,rice,gemstones,there was much trade with the Romans who came to Cambodia by boat. A lovely temple and a treasured memory
Great temple with fewer visitors. A grand temple with fewer visitors, so that you can have more time to look in every details. The elephant trunk is amazing.

A top 3 temple with a bit of everything.... don't miss it!. One of my top 3 temples. We visited early morning and essentially had the place to ourselves. Has a bit of everything : trees growing out of the temple, plenty of basic reliefs, rubble for scrambling over and plenty of hidden hallways to explore. The morning sun on the large stragglers fig at the east entrance was gorgeous. Don't miss it!
Must see!. Not many people come here, at least in November! It is different and has an atmophere you can feel. Trees and roots are everywhere.
A real gem. This is not one of the most visited temples but it was my favourite, the further in you walk the more delightful it gets.

One of My Favorites. Preah Khan is a large, flat temple that sits just to the north of the Angkor Thom complex. The architecture is very appealing, and the encroaching jungle gives it a feel similar to Ta Prohm. It is just far enough away from the center of town that it is much less heavily traveled than many of the temples closer in. There is much to explore -- I would plan on at least 2 hours if you want to see it all properly. Preah Khan my second favorite temple (after Ta Prohm) and I definitely recommend putting it on your list of must-see temples -- you won't be disappointed.

Favourite temple site. Not one of the major tourist sites but our favourite.highlite being the delightful old nun .the temple has ruins,overgrown trees,restore d areas,great sculptures and wall carvings although many damaged centuries ago.but still overall we'll worth a visit

Best Temple. You should visit!. Not crowded, beautiful architecture, semi-ruined. It has it all.The carvings are beautiful as in Banteay Srei. Temple is on a green area, with lots of trees. Some of them are entangled with the blocks, like Ta Phom. The structure is highly simmetric and concetric. As big as Angkor Wat. Combine all of this with the semi-ruined state, good lightining and few tourists, and it will be the best temple to take good photos. At least it was for me.
A less visited temple - but my favourite!. A mix of all that the other temples offer and the bonus of the 76 year old nun in the centre, who will give you a blessing for a donation.

Hidden treasure. This was the first temple I decided to visit. It was so peaceful as I feel others head straight for the well known temples. You begin by walking through a narrow garden lined with individual figures and then over a small bridge. There was a beautiful building outside of the main temple, very imposing yet mysterious. Inside the temple, as stated below, lots of structures have collapsed but many still remain. Th perfect temple for exploring. Although I had bought a guide book, I was very lucky as a local young boy started walking around and explaining a lot of features and showing me others (which I would have missed!). He also took some great photos and I gave him a small fee afterwards.

I m not sure if it is a scam. A 21 yr old boy approached me and started talking to me about the site, and kept following me around. I was aware that I would be needed to give him tips and maybe that is how he supported himself. He said he studied at night, but when I asked more questions,it seems he could not understand, so I m not sure if he is really a student or just memorizing the words he said.He asked for 7 to 10 USD , and I happened not have small change. So in the end stupidly gave 10. Actually a friend of mine who have been there think they r really working hard to guide ppl. But I m really not sure if I m cheated. But I would suggest u bring along snack or small change to give them, as they really did a good job explaining

Way Cool. This temple had much to offer. It was in a ruinous state but was also uniqueness; such as the bridge & moat leading up to it. There some structures that were still in pretty good shape while others were crumbling in addition to the jungle re-claiming some structures like Ta Promh. This was not a busy site with tourist so that was a major plus.

Massive Unrestored Ruins - Guide Or Research A Necessity. Preah Khan has had very little restoration done. Between the size of the complex and the disrepair of the ruins, it is very easy to miss key portions of the temple. When we visited, a Cambodian police officer was working to earn a little money on the side by giving tours. It was a relatively short tour but he showed us at least a half dozen areas we would have missed. It was also his lucky day as a $5 bill was the smallest we had! Of all the temples we visited this is one of the only ones I would like to come back and spend more time exploring.
Our favourite temple. This was my wife and my favourite temple, Most probably because we viewed it at 6:30 in the morning and the solitude and silence made it magic!

Marriage. My friend recently got married here, and what a lovely experience that was. We arrived for the ceremony around 6:30 and there were hardly any tourists around so if you want a little one on one time with Prea Khan, an early morning start may be the way to go.

my favorite angkor temple. this place is awesome. part in ruin. some trees growing out through the ruins. enough in place to give you a proper temple experience. enough passageways and corridors for you to get lost in. and best of all, enough places to hide from large tour groups as they flow past. simply amazing, and everything i wanted to experience in the angkor temple complex.

A beautiful temple . We bought a 3 day pass to the temple area. On our first day we did the 'small circuit' and saw the obvious big hitters (bayon, Ta Prohm, and Angkor wat). We saw this stunning temple on our second day of temple exploration, as part of the 'big circuit'. The huge advantage of doing the big circuit is that it's much less crowded and this was one of my favourite temples of this circuit. Much less crowded than Ta Prohm but has many similar features, with huge trees growing on top of walls. A beautiful place to visit and a must see temple in my opinion.We found someone selling stunning paintings inside the grounds of this temple, which we considered were of much better quality than any other we have spotted elsewhere. The guy who had painted them was lovely as well. A real added bonus to a beautiful temple visit!

Not crowded, but very interesting. Not many tourists make it to this temple. This makes it nice, because you are not falling all over people.It is quite rustic, but very interesting. The design is a bit difference from many of the more popular temples. It is worth it to pay a guide to tell you the full story. If you enter from the north, be sure to go all the way to the east end, or vice-versa.It may add a little time to your temple-viewing day, but well worth your time.

Interesting temple. On the short list.. This temple has seminal Angkor architecture and should be seen. Absolutely book the best guide you can find to accompany you. There is too much to learn about these sites without having professional input along the way.There are a large number of temples in the Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom, and outlying areas as well. Don't feel you have to see them all. Three full days of touring are important to do this world-class venue justice but these are the Don't Miss sites, in this order of priority: Angkor Wat, of course, the stellar, Number One site; Bayon; Terrace of the Elephants and Terrace of the Leper King; Ta Prohm; Bandrey Srei; Preah Kahn; Pre Rup; Neak Prean.Give yourself time to visit your three favorites a second time within your three day itinerary. Many are so overwhelming in their interest, architecture, and artistry that you must see them at least twice to begin to appreciate them. We had to see the Churning of the River of Milk at Angkor Wat three times, as it was so artistically stunning, and is comparable to the greatest carvings anywhere in the World.

High Indiana Jones factor. This was my second-favorite Angkor Wat experience, after Ta Prohm. Another great splendid ruin, a mix of restored and ruined temple, with the jungle encroaching and intermixed. Do not miss this.

Dont skip this hidden treasure in Temple Town. Generally left as an afterthought for most since they are consumed with the bigger temples..but Preah Khan is one I would def recommend. Was made in honour of the Kings father and if translated is the temple of the Sacred Sword..the actual structure at the back of the temple is so narrow that it does seem that it was built to encase something small and precious such as a sacred sword. Also unlike most of the architecture of that time, the pillars of this structure are round unlike the sharp square cornered pillars you see...which in Khmer culture was avoided as they thought that round pilars would attract and house spirits. Possibly the round pillars in teh Preah Khan structure were meant to have spirits guarding something like the "sacred sword" ...hmmmmm...who knows!

Mix of Buddhist and Hindu images. Preah Khan integrates the Hindu and Buddhist images in a single site. It is very interesting to note how the different positions of the hands reflect the two teachings. Like Ta Prohm, this temple is be overrun by trees, making a very interesting contrast between the dark stone temples and the white roots tearing down its wall.

Worth a trip!. Approximately 1 km north Angkor Thom, this amazing temple is part of angkor's "big circuit. However, while cycling the small circuit, we made this detour and it was really worthwhile! The place is a complex, dedicated to the emperors father, and has 4 wings: 3 dedicated to the 3 hindu gods (vishnu, shiva, bramma) and 1 to budda, so a great mixture of buddhism and hinduism!

A Wow at every turn. Preah Khan is absolutely stunning and gives the feeling that you have gone back in time. We visited early in the day when there were very few people and the photo ops were incredible! Large ficus trees have overgrown much of the temple buildings which add to the ambiance and uniqueness of Preah Khan. The green moss added a natural beauty to the beautiful carvings and engraved lintels. Not to be missed.

The jungle entwined in the temple. I loved this temple with the giant ficus trees sprouting from temple walls. We were really lucky the day we visited here as it was very quiet....unheard of in the Temples around Angkor Wat.

An Unexpected Experience. I knew nothing about Preah Khan before visiting as part of the long tour that most Tuk Tuk drivers follow. It is not as well preserved (or restored) as the more important temples but it's scale and setting and the variety of rooms and corridors make this a very rewarding temple to explore.It's layout is founded on four long unobstructed corridors orientated east, west, north and south which you can look down and photograph making for an interesting perspective. There are some interesting inscriptions on the walls and pillars particularly in the hall of dancers. Unfortunately many of the ceilings and walls have collapsed lending a rather dilapidated air to the place. Like Ta Phrom, the are several instances of giant trees destroying parts of the building make for spectacular photo opportunities.I also experienced the unrequested attentions of the tour guide as mentioned by other Trip Advisor reviewers although I manage to get away with 'only' paying $3 despite his request for $10. He was rather knowledgable, however, and was able to answer a range of questions that had built up over a number of temple visits. If you are approached by some one who begins talking about the temple right from the beginning be very clear that his attention is not appreciated if you don't want to find yourself in a situation at the end where he obligates you to pay for his time.All in all I really enjoyed the temple and would put it in the bracket of the most unexpected experience of my Siem Reap stay.

Hidden gem. This has to be one of my favourite temples in Siem Reap. After the crowds of Angkor Wat and Bayon this was a pleasant surprise.There are many areas to explore and the temple gives you the best of the both temples but with the feel of Ta Prohm.

A smaller, blended version of Angkor Wat and Ta Prohm. We were really taken by the serene setting of Preah Kahn and became our third favorite temple behind Ta Prohm and Bayon. The approach over the moat and partial jungle reclamation reminded us of both Angkor Wat and Ta Prohm on a smaller scale. The crowd was light just past noon and we lingered there for about an hour.Sequentially, sunrise at Angkor Wat, the South Gate and greater Angkor Thom including Bayon, and Preah Kahn make for a full morning itinerary while minimizing travel distance in between.Of course, I would recommend Preah Kahn on your must-see list.

One of my favourites. We went to Preah Khan straight after sunrise at Angkor Wat and were quite taken with this temple. It is really beautiful and so peaceful at that time of the morning, I felt like I was in a lost paradise. I would say everyone should definitely try to get to this one.

Beautiful!. This is a great temple, but one you can skip if time is limited. I loved the ruined library best. The strangler fig roots are also impressive and add a lot of character here, as with Ta Prohm.

4th time lucky. I am lucky enough to have visited Cambodia four times and it was only on my most recent visit did I go to Preah Khan. I can't believe that I hadn't gone before now. It is an immense and mesmerizing temple with some very special features like the two-storied building with round columns (the only round columns in the Anchor complex our guide told us). Our 'guide' was one of the local Police who said he had been guarding the temple since 1996. He attached himself to us once he realised we were English speaking and gave us an insiders tour taking us places we wouldn't have gone. He did ask for $10 at the end of the tour and although we were reasonably happy to pay we thought it was a little steep (we weren't going to argue with the police however).

Similar to Ta Prohm and fewer Tourists. This one is another beautiful temple that has been only partially restored. More like only partially defended against the onslaught of nature's reclamation. So it has a good deal of lovely trees growing on and around the walls and buildings of the temple.It's a large complex, and there is plenty to see if you wander off the main path through the center of the temple. There were a lot of fake guides here trying to earn a buck, but they are able to show you somewhat secret nooks and crannies you might not stumble onto on your own.

Quiet look at fading grandeur. This complex is huge,but pleasurably explorable monastic complex. Full of carvings,passages and photo opportunities. originally it engaged over 1000 monks . Architectural styles abound and even people not trained in its history will enjoy exploring without the surge of humanity in front and behind you. Its lovely in late afternoon and after rain.
Yet another great temple complex. This place has amazing strangler fig and temple picture opportunities so you must visit this place while you are in the Angkor park region

This temple is different from others. I found this temple quite different from many of the others, and really enjoyed it. It was very serene! Make sure you take your guide book.As Katie B said, at most of the temples you will get hassled by children or people wanting to sell you something. I found that if I only took my guide book and camera, as soon as I showed them I didn't have a wallet or money they quickly took off! Made it much more pleasant!

Great temple to visit. Another one built by Jayavarman VII, that is really worth visiting, fascinated by its mixture of nature and human built structures.There is a beatifull two storeys building of unknown nature (maybe a library ?) with round columns.Intricate and gorgeous carvings can be found everywhere.Nice spot are the Chinese looking eyes apsara and trees willing to devour parts of the complex.

Begging children ruin it. The amount of harassment we dealt with from poor Cambodian children ruined the visit for us. They followed us nonstop starting from where we parked our bicycles (at the East Gate) and all the way up the (long) walkway to the temple. Once inside the temple, we were bothered by 3 more people trying to get money by telling us things like "here is a nice spot for a picture" about a spot two feet from us that we could SEE from where we were. Maybe a different gate would have less begging out front, but you'll still face it inside the temple. We left after barely any exploration it was such a pain to deal with.

Magical in the morning. Preah Kahn is one of the biggest temples, still mostly in ruins and thus very special. Remember to go before the crowds find it at noon and you will be rewarded with a unique visit.

Amazing view of the east gate. Preah Khan Temple were built in region of King Jayavaraman VII in 12th century. The uniqueness of this temple is there is a 2 storied building with round column, the purpose of building this is unknown. In front of the East gate of this temple there is a big water reservoir, and a man made island located in the middle of the temple. You also can hire a boat from the community or a jungle trek from the east gate. it's very awesome!

Make it a point to visit. This is a great temple to visit as it is less crowded and also the state of restoration is slower so you get to see the ruins of falling stone blocks amidst apsaras and bas-reliefs. Walk all the way through the temple and you will see how the roots and trunk of a hugh cotton has grown and merge into the walls of the temple
good place. it is one of the best wat in Angkor which is quite similar to Ta phrom temple. The gates inside look likes layer after layer...

Huge interesting complex. A large complex full of passages and Buddha carvings, this temple provides lots of photo opportunities. Interesting to see how parts of the temple are now held together by the roots of the banyan tree. Spend some time to soak in the peace and quiet of the temple.

another area left to ruin.... With conservation efforts focused primarily on "maintaining the ruin" rather than restoration, this is another area where you can get some great shots of roots growing through and on top of the ruins.

Stunning. I think this is the Tomb Raider temple (to be honest I've forgotten which one is which!!), assuming it is (!!), this is very different to any of the others as it literally has tress growing out of it. It’s amazing how the structure stays together when there are such big trees growing through the gaps in between the stones…..well worth a visit and very interesting to see something slightly different

The temple with a long corridor.. This temple was one of the last one I went in as I saw that all the temples looks alike but have diffferent history. We went in to find that it has a long passage way right to the end. On both sides of the temples we found that tall trees with big roots has grown on to them.

beautiful. Probably the most beautiful temple I saw in Siem Reap, although much smaller than the others. I could have spent much more time than we had. I wanted to take a picture at virtually every step. The only problem was the local police officer trying to hawk trinkets - just ignore him and he'll go away.

Like you discovered it yourself.... Our guide took us to Preah Khan from the back. We walked through the jungle on a path. There were large stones and bits of temples laying around as we made our was to Preah Khan. When we reached the outer gate there was not another person around and it felt as if we had stumbled on the ruins all by ourselves. It was awesome. This temple has not received as much restoration (although they are working on it) and it gives you a feel for what the temples were like when they were discovered (minus the jungle growing over them of course). We toured this temple in the early afternoon and there were only a few other people there.

Preah Khan is definitely underrated as one of Siem Reap's temples. This was actually a wonderful thing because while the masses are building at places like Angkor Wat (my least favorite temple) or at Ta Promh, you can enjoy a little free space at Preah Khan.

Take water and camera and batteries. Set your camera on panarama this is one of the best temples Banyon trees are devouring it but that only adds to the charm! Take water and camera and batteries -you dont want to run out of power.

Inspiring. Preah Khan was one of our favorite temples in the Angkor area. Our driver dropped us at one end of the temple and we walked through to the other side where he picked us up. The temple is partially ruined which adds to its mystique.

Extensive, explorable temple complex with a fraction of the visitors of Angkor Wat. This is one of my top 2 temples to visit at Angkor (my other favorite is the Bayon). It's quite a large temple so you can explore for as long as you care to, and every time I've visited it's been practically deserted, so it feels like you have the place all to yourself. There are some pretty spectacular trees growing in and out of the ruins especially at the back of the complex, so make sure to venture all the way through for excellent photo opportunities. Be aware of off-duty police officers (in uniform) who will ask if you'd like to hear information about the temples but then will expect to be paid.

most architctural experience. GREAT RUINS. im an architecture phtoographer it hink this is the most place tha makes wont go out.all the composition and window square proportionnss it is a very good composition even they dying as frozen ruins.

amazing!. this temple was just amazing! the structure and the way the tree roots just dominated the entire area just made for one hell of a scary yet enchanting sight. Iwas a little spooked out by it though i must say, because there is a feel of loneliness and forgottenness when you enter this place. Maybe its also due to the fact that there werent as many tourists here as there were other places. There is a huge lingga here, so most Hindus would recognize that this is a temple for Lord Shiva. It is just amazing how the tree roots have dominated and broken down some sturctures.

Many local kids approaching to sell stuff. Give some donation or walk away or give them sweets. Nice temple, the time that I visit (by accident I come 2 times), there are not many people, so I enjoy the quietness & big tree on the temple & a long walkway, just a short while before I proceed to next temple.

Remote Buddhist Ruins. Preah Khan is another site where the jungle has been succeeding at reclaiming the temple. The middle of the site is a Buddhist sanctuary, but there are many Hindu carvings outside the central structure. I love the pictures of trees and ruins together. This temple is less crowded because its farther than the other temples from Siem Reap.

Must See. This is one of the smaller temples but very beautiful because of the unique way the trees have grown over the buildings in a few locations. There are so many temples you just cant imagine the scope of Siem Reap until you go there.I have read complaints about the hawkers mobbing you from out of the forest and yes it is true. They are a bit relentless yet as is the custom in Cambodia they are always polite. On the other side to this coin it is worth considering that some people are extremely poor by western standards and so your one or two dollars spent at a temple on a fridge magnet you don't really want will mean a great deal to the seller. Take a few one dollar notes with you when you go to the temples and you will get back kindness and goodwill in spades.You will not forget this gorgeous location or the people.

Simply beautiful. It would be hard to talk about Preah Khan without comparing it to the nearby Ta Prohm. Like Ta Prohm, this place was built by the same Khmer king and has been left largely unrestored, so you will find large trees growing atop and among the temple ruins.However, I prefer Preah Khan to Ta Prohm because it is less touristy, as Ta Prohm was featured in the movie Tomb Raider. This made the visit to Preah Khan a much more scenic experience for me.

Unique on its own. Preah Khan is my favourite temple. Unique in it's own way. My partner and i I visited the temple around 4ish in the afternoon and it was pouring heavily. We literally have the whole place to ourselves; along with a group of 3 ppl and another couple. We came across a local man dressed in uniform who was in the temple; he showed and explained to us a big "candle lamp" look alike thing when taken with your camera at a certain angle combined with a hole on the wall; creates a lit candle. Picturesque indeed. He kept offering to hold my camera and help me take pictures but because we're well aware of scams; we just kindly denied his offer. Just to be cautious. Nevertheless exploring Preah Khan in the rain is one of a kind experience. Despite the rain, the temple and the surroundings is just absolutely beautiful!
King's Place of Worship. Very near Angkor Thom, again with magnificent walls surrounding the area with giant tree roots still amongst it.
Not the best. Off course you also need to visit this place, but again it depend of the time you have here in Angkor.

Huge temple. The entire temple area of Preah Khan is quite big.
The temple is located in the jungle and you can hear the birds singing and the wind brushing through the trees.
The place is superb!
The artwork of pillars and statues is very impressive!
Unfortunately a lot ares of the temple are destructed.

beautiful. We saw this site on our own and I think I comprehended the history of the building. There was a security guard/policeman that provided some interpretation of the carvings, but then asked for a donation. This site also had a large tree growing thru the wall.

excellent temple away from the worst crush of crowds. This temple is a bit more far-flung than some go to, so we had several occasions where we were the only people among the stone galleries and walks. Sections are crumbling into the jungle and are only just preserved, so it retains the hint of adventure rather than being restored and revamped.

The best temple ruin in the world. So it is a bit removed from Angkor, and lesser known, hence it is quiet, and you can almost have it for yourself. It is mesmerising with the wilderness and the ancient architecture intertwined and living in harmony. It is a photographers delight, and the best part is it is far removed from the touristy attractions.

Slightly-isolated jungle temple. It's beautiful, beautiful, beautiful! Along with Beng Milea, this was my favourite of the Siem Reap temples. You walk through a small part of forest to get to the entrance. There were some very cute Cambodian children who came up to talk to us or were just playing and dancing near the temple. It is in ruins and needs some restoration as some of the walls looked like they would collapse any moment! The colours of the stones, a combination of time and moss, are a treat! The carvings are intact in many places and are just breathtaking! At the end there are trees growing on the stones. Overall, the isolated, quiet, jungle atmosphere really sets this one apart!
Another Beautiful temple. This is one of the temple that you must not miss when you go to siem reap. It's the only one that has a column structure which is the library.

Beautiful stone wall labyrinth. It surely was not a disappointment to visit this temple, it was beautiful though there are still lot's of stone piles so you should mind your steps and choose which way you go, it shows that it is not fully restored yet. It makes me feel like we were in a beautiful stone wall labyrinth. Some part of the temples are still being "hugged" by the huge trees, but some of it has been cut and left with it's roots still hugging the temple.

diamonds. this temple gets me every time, I am led to believe that the holes in the wall were made to hold diamonds so as they reflected the light into the central chamber were there is a monument, which I am told was made in memory of a loved one , the door ways all lined up make a brilliant photo. I am told they had all the different ways in to the temple for different levels of society. so if you were a commoner you would come in from one entrance and if you were a minister you would use another entrance. my tuk tuk driver from bayon tour.com was most helpful in explaining this to me. even as I stood and gazed at the alignment of the doors I could not quite grasp how they had the ingenuity to work it all out in those days.oh and the library that is quite an amazing piece of engineering, not sure it would hold many book thoughgo and have a look. if you know anything more or see some thing I have missed let me know

Well worth exploring. This temple has four main gates that lead to the temple complex. Your tour/tuk-tuk driver might drop you off at one gate, and pick you up at another one. The temple is basically a big cross and well worth exploring. There are many nooks and crannies to check out, and some big tree roots squeezing the temple walls. A great place to poke around and not all that many people around.
Loved it!. We really enjoyed this temple first thing in the morning. It was quiet as there were very few people there. There was information posted telling about the temple and the restoration.

Exotic Temple. Ta Prohm like Preah Khan are cool to see because different from others where were made works to get better and consequently cleaning from vegetation, they choose these two sites to leave exactly the way the french found it more than 100 years ago.Therefore the atmosphere is quite exotic and feel like and adventurer or for those that watched Indiana Jones or Tomb Raider like such protagonists.

The only temple with circular columns. I have taken a look at the photos that previous reviewers have attached for this temple and none of them contain images of the circular columns. According to our tour guide, this is the only temple with circular columns (see my photos). Also, as others have stated, there are massive trees that are similar to those in Ta Prohm.
One of the beautiful temple. Preah Khan has been left largely unrestored, with numerous trees and other vegetation growing among the ruins. There is a stupa inside with direct sunlight

Peaceful Shady Place in a Beautiful Complex. This large temple is located on the 'big circuit' outside the inner cities. It was built in the late 12th century by Jayavarman VII. It is not only a temple but funtioned as a monastery and Buddhist teaching centre. It is a wonderful place to explore with surprises around many corners that make you feel like an explorer finding an undiscovered temple. Some of the complex is in ruins, some is restored, some has large trees growing through the stonework (a la Ta Phrom).There is a long walkway through a forested area to get to the entrance and you can continue to walk through a covered gallery right through to the other side, or explore various side corridors which can lead to some beautiful statues and carvings. There is also a wonderful 2 storey library at the side, which it looks like a columned building from ancient Rome. It is also lovely to find a quiet spot to sit and listen to the sounds of the jungle. This is easy to do as the temple does not appear to be on the intineraries of tour groups (I suspect it would lake them too long to get through it). A Highly recommended experience.

Serene and calm temple. We visited this temple around 10.30am and noticed that there wasn't a crowd, hence we got to explore the temple at our own pace and serenely. I guess Preah Khan is not a top crowd favourite. The temple has elements of Ta Phrom, Bayon and I particularly liked their archways. Recommended :)

Amazing peacefull place. This temple is much quieter than the other big temples as most of the big tour groups don't come here,like Ta prohm it has lots of trees growing through the ruins and lots of areas that have collapsed.the two story library is a unique feature of this temple.I found this temple so peaceful and calming I could sit there quiet for hours at a time,the south gate is worth a look,not many people go there.I enjoyed Preah Khan so much I went there three times in three days.It is by far my favourite temple in the whole area,dont miss it.

Beautiful experience. Preah Khan temple is one of top 3 favourites of the 7 temples we had time to experience with 3 young children. My wife stopped shortly after entry to sit and draw with the kids while I explored the amazing temple complex without wonderful guide Mr Hang Borey. Well worth a visit

Favourite tempel for us as well. This temple is on the "bigger tour" that some tour companies offer and as a result, it's much quieter. We were here early in the morning around 8 and there were not many people. There are lots of trees grown around the buildings and unlike the other one which is similar (ta prohm I believe) this one has not got building works at the back.

My favourite temple complex. An old Buddhist temple situated in a walled enclosure, which was once a busy city and surrounded by a moat. Perhaps it was just the compact design or the amazing carvings and statues that are everywhere. The massive structure, the terraces and the remaining galleries give such a regal appearance, the whole complex still seems alive.You enter the complex over the ornate bridge lined with statues, go through the gateway the across the enclosure before entering the temple building. Walk through and come out the other side and walk onto the southern gate where hopefully, if you had a smart tuk-tuk man, your ride will be there to pick you up.Like Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom and Ta Prohm, Preah Khan is so much more than the temple itself. These sites are the remains of a city complex and have to be seen in that context.Make the effort to put Preah Khan on your list, you will really enjoy it!

Lovely temple a lot quieter than some others. Really nice spot.Also has some of the jungle trees strangling the temple but wihtout the hoards of tourists trying to get the Lara Croft type photos.Slowly being rebuilt a lot of rubble but a really nice temple to see all the same

Our favorite in Angkor. This is a must-see temple - ideally earlier in the morning before the heat and the crowds (although the light in the afternoons is great for photos also). Ask your tuk-tuk driver to pick you up on the other side so you can walk all the way through (it's a long walk). The temple has a very special feel to it, and there are many places to explore. Bring your camera - you can easily get 100 great pictures here.

My favorite. Preah Khan was my favorite temple the first time I visited, and again the second time! Sure was hard with a stroller though. I love how remote it feels, really in the jungle. Don't miss this temple.

Favorite temple by far. This temple is very similar to Ta Prohm (the "Tomb Raider Temple"), with many untouched ruins and giant trees snaking their roots around the stone structures. It seemed less popular than Ta Prohm, which meant it was less crowded and felt a lot like I was actually an explorer discovering these ruins for the first time. My friends and I agreed that this was by far our favorite temple in the Angor Wat complex!

Beautiful temple and not visited much. We went to this temple via tuc tuc and we were not disappointed. It's not one of the ones that everybody does so it was very manageable in terms of crowds. It's very long with passageways and at one point you get to a 2 storey construction that is great for pics. You can have a good look and take gorgeous pics without having to queue up. its in a lovely jungle setting so that adds to the ambience. We loved it and are glad we visited.we suggest you go there if you have the time.

Another fabulous temple, #4 on my list of temples. This is the best temple on the long/big circuit in my opinion, and my 4th favourite of the temples of angkor. If I only had 1 day, I'd skip the long circuit and do instead the shorts circuit, which has my top 3 on it---Bayon, Ta Prohm, Angkor Wat. If you love temples and can't get enough after doing the short circuit (and the sun hasn't fried you by that point), then do the long circuit and spend most of your time here at Preah Khan, the best of the long circuit. It is extensive, with many components to it.Long circuit tuk-tuk fare: $10-15 for the day.You can also rent bikes, but don't do it in March-April, as the heat is murderous.

1st impression on roots conquering the building. Facinated with the big roots conquering the building. Our tour guide said you would see more the next day when he took us to Ta Promth. Very excited to see more ........

Beautiful!. Preah Khan was constructed in the late 12th Century and is 2 kilometers northeast of Angkor Thom. There is also a very good visitor centre here with lots of information, plus before and after photos of the ongoing reconstruction.This complex was built as a monastery and centre for learning by King Jayavarman VII. For a short time it was also the residence of the King while his permanent residence was being reconstructed.  Preah Khan means "Sacred Sword" and this has a long tradition in Khmer history as Preah Khan was built on a former battle site where King Jayavarman defeated the Chams. Huge trees have played a major part in the destruction of this complex and also play a part in supporting some of the structures. Thousands of Buddha images were defaced here during the centuries by trying to transform the Buddhist complex into a Hindu temple. Phrea Khan is beautiful and one of my favorites, there is lots to explore here so allow yourself 2 hours.

Best temple of the bunch.. Preah Khan is definitely underrated as one of Siem Reap's temples. This was actually a wonderful thing because while the masses are building at places like Angkor Wat (my least favorite temple) or at Ta Promh, you can enjoy a little free space at Preah Khan. It has the spectacular places to get that photo with overgrown trees growing from the ruins that every traveller wants. Plus, this location does not rope off the tree areas unlike in Ta Promh. You are less likely to have hundreds of tourists in your photos too. There are multiple entry points so do try to get your bearings when you enter the temple so you can find your driver afterwards. If possible, get their cell number in case you can't find them. The rubble, trees, and enclosed passages make this place absolutely stunning and worth a visit. Bonus points for having many covered spots for some much needed reprieve from the blistering Cambodian sun.

One not to miss!. My favourite temple! Not so crowded as some of the others, lots to explore, and so many sculptures! If you arrive by tuk-tuk, arrange for your driver to pick you up at the far side, as it it a long walk to cover the whole site. Very atmospheric, don't miss it!
Not many tourist and beautiful.. A must go. Dang those tree for ruining the buildings. This is one of my favorite temples as not many tourist and beautiful.

Quiet temple. We visited here with our guide after a break at the hotel pool in the hottest part of the day. Also needed to recharge camera batteries after taking so many photos inthe morning! We headed out at 3pm did not see too many other tourists here. Or our guide avoided them. There are the massive roots of the 'Spung' tree growing over parts of the ruined temple as there are at Ta Prohm. Good to have a guide to explain things.
Trees Galore. The trees growing through the ruins were fantastic and gave a eerie feeling to the whole place. The walk to the temple was through some local people playing instruments badly.

Preah Khan... gives one a meditative experience. Part of the expanse of the Angkor Wat tour, the Preah Khan gives one a light spirit. The stome embelishments, carved faces and doors of stones, different carvings and a line of more carvings can leave one's imagination flow as of how truly these stone carvers made a great contribution to Cambodias tourism now and cultural dimension. History of Cambodia is finely imprinted here , I am truly awed.
jungle ruins. A very atmospheric temple with beautiful carvings and picturesque ruins and jungle canopy. It is possible to escape the tour groups and pretend briefly that you have it all to yourself

Quiet and peaceful - my favorite temple in Angkor. This temple was like being inside a huge maze. You can frequently feel like you are the only one there. I highly recommend going around to the forgotten south entrance. It has not been restored and there is nobody there. It is a great contrast to the throngs in Ta Prohm.
the best site to see. a little more out of the way but really beautiful.When visiting these temples try to get outside and walk the outside.Its so much quieter and really beautiful.

One of my favourites. This smaller temple together with Angkor Wat was my favourite. The main reason possibly was that we visited early morning straight after taking photos of the sunrise at Angkor Wat so there weren't many people around, the air was still fresh and coolish. We walked all the way to the lake and then back, wonderful place.

Ambience is better. Visit this during the morning where there is less people. The atmosphere of this place is really good - solemn, mysterious and quiet. Unlike the popular Angkor Wat and Thom, really appreciate what tranquility this place offers.

Walking to Preah Khan. We decided to go early in the morning on foot taking a path crossing the jungle. It was fantastic exept the mosquitos! Wear long sleeves if you do the same thing.The Temple was not in very good condition and cannot be restored because trees mingle with the walls og the buildings. The gardians of the temple were decapitated and the so called libraries were just columns, on some exterior walls as bas reliefs there were some demons with an eagle like face. However, the silence the ruins the jungle created a mystic atmosphere. I iked it.

Better than Ta Prohm. We both found this place to be perhaps more impressive than Ta Prohm, it certainly had less visitors when we were there. It was probably our favourite of all the temples that we visited.
Another temple.. Another beautiful temple but not the biggest or best of the Angkor Temples. Worth passing through, however.

Another beautiful site.. Too many people, but not as bad as some of the other sites... The entire area was much nicer before naming it a "World Heritage Site." Now it is just over-crowded. It seems that the UN... in it's grand scheme of things... want to turn these "World Heritage Sites" into theme parks... makd money and ruin them.
an average temple. Preah Khan has a few interesting spots.The temple is in average condition,not a highlight for Angkor Wat site

A real favourite. Probably the temple in Angkor that's closest to my heart, it's a glorious ruin, overpowered with trees. A little less visited than its close cousin, Ta Prohm, it's well worth clambering about on.

Huge, rather empty temple complex. Huge, rare empty complex that has several areas to visit and explore. I spent about 30 mins exploring the east side without a soul in sight. Has some trees growing over the temples like Ta Prohm but without the crowds or wooden walkways.

Favorite ruin of all.. This place is incredible, and massive. One of the best things about the temples is that there are magical little surprises that happen in the different temples. The best for me happened in this temple, stumbling upon an ancient monk (male? female?) offering cleansing prayers in toothless Cambodian. There was no one else around, and this monk seemed to pop up out of the ground!

Lovely ruins. Another wonderful ruined temple that was a great deal quieter than some of the others we visited. Lots of walls collapsing, trees growing through and narrow passageways. Another great one to visit.
Wonderful. Like Ta Promh, a temple with jungle growing over it, but less famous, and therefore less crowded. Well worth the trip
Get that Iconic Photo. Wonderful ruins being overtaken by the jungle. Tis is the place to get that photo we've all seen of the ancient stone being overun by the fig tree roots.

Go in via the back way.. We went with our guide (Angkor Guide Services - see seperate review) and were taken in the back way through a forest. There was no-one there at the back and this added to the experience, but I would say a fairly average temple, which if time were a factor, could be missed.
Temples. Amazing site near the Thai border. Wonderful temple but a bit of hike from Siem Reap. Worth the trip and also interesting to see what life is like for soliders in this area.

Preah Khan is a good place to get lost in. Preah Khan is not as popular as other temples in the archaeological park hence the low traffic of tourists. The maze-like set-up makes it conducive for the curious and adventurous. The quiet nature of the ruins gives one the feeling that there are other people watching. I felt like an explorer of a lost tomb navigating the twists and turns of this ruin. I was on the last leg of my 3 day temple tour which made me less adventurous and at the brink of being templed out. I wish I stayed longer to explore the different sections of this ruin.

Found Vishnu. We were getting tired of temple crawling. By the time we got to Preah Khan I was templed out. But then got inspired by looking for Vishnu - found it and felt inspired again to continue temple crawling.

Beautiful to see, but felt very alone in this temple. I am glad I got to see this temple, but felt uneasy in it.It was such a long walk from the parking area and the maze like structure left me nervous I would get lost. There were 2 or 3 people along the way offering to give tours that really tried hard before i could get them to leave me alone. I just didn't like the combination of very low traffic from other tourists and high number of milling locals that seemed to want something.Nothing bad happened, but I was a bit frazzled by the time I left this temple and was glad to be leaving.

Wonderful temple, quite unique. We arrived just before lunch and whilst is was semi-busy, we did feel like explorers on our own. This was one of our favourite temples along with Bayon, Ta Prohm, Ta Som and Bantreay Srei

Don't miss it!!!. This is a vast, sprawling temple, a seemingly endless maze of corridors and ruins, where a new suprise is waiting for you at every other corner. You will feel like Indiana Jones, as there are much fewer tourists here than at more frequented temples.Don't miss it, and schedule at least an hour and a half to see it.

Our favorite temple in Angkor Wat. This temple doesn't have the height of other places, but it makes up for that with its maze like structure and intricate carvings. Very easy to get lost in this wonderful complex. It also has some of the amazing large trees with roots swallowing up stone like Ta Prohm. Crowds are less here and it's easy to find your spot for a picnic lunch.

Atmospheric ruin. Although this is mostly a ruin there has been some rebuilding, but it is beautiful because of the way the forest has reclaimed and trees and tree roots takn over the buildings. I hope they leave it as it is.
Worth visiting. A lot is in ruins but in a way this makes it particularly atmospheric. A must see temple if you have a couple of days in the area.

Unexpected and wonderful!. What a wonderful surprise - we LOVED Preah Khan! It is Huge - not a highTemple Mountain, but a big sprawling complex. All on its own. Perhaps because we had not yet visited Ta Prohm we were knocked out by Preah Khan.>

Great atmosphere!. We visit Preaj Khan before going to the most famous temples and this was a good decisition. This temple summarises in a smaller scala what the whole Angkor Complex is offering, but with the much less visitors.

The temple of the sacred sword
One if my favorites of them all. Preah khan was built by jayavarman vii after his victory over the chams . The temple isVery large and is worth a few hours of your time to explore all the walkways and various features and carvings,the temple is dedicated to Vishnu but yet there are some Buddhist designs by nature also ,even though there was a Buddhist revolt in which most were destroyed. The temple has been left mostly to nature as it would be complete guesswork to put the temple back together and makes if even more enjoyable, the temple is large with lots of walkways, there are trees growing out of the buildings,large libraries and also a two tower building which hasn't been seen before on the Angkor temples , but still a beautiful site,the causeways have large garudas on holding the snake over what used to be aMoat I believe which is now dried up but still makes a great photo . Just beware of the large cobwebs as the spiders are rather large - black with gold on , very beautiful though
Went back twice. One of our favorites of the temples of Angkor. We took our son back after he had missed the day before due to illness, as we knew he had to see it.Wonderful, atmospheric place!

The Long Temple. Be prepared for a long walk through the cool dark corridor that runs through the center of this mass of tumbled stones and cleared courtyards. Here the massive corbelling of Angkor's roofs can be clearly seen. From the crowds at the west entrance, half an hour takes you to the peace and quiet of the east entrance and the breeze coming over the waters of the Bareay.

Top site of the Angkor Temples. This place is really cool and full of tunnels to walk through and explore the temple carvings. The detail that went into these temples is amazing. We found that Preah Khan was not very busy and could explore it and feel like we was alone in there alot of the time. I enjoyed this place more than Angkor Wat. Its more in a ruined state which I feel gives it a more magical feeling!
The one to see. This temple is the one to see. An Indiana Jones feeling. We loved it as our tuk tuk driver brought us there during twilight. We were almost alone.
Great temple. While there are many temples to see I would make sure to add this one to the list. I visited so many temples while in Siem Reap that I got them confused but I do remember this one.

Our favorite temple. We just visited Siem reap for 4 days and made it to almost every temple. After each one we'd say "this is our favorite," but hands down Preah Khan was the best. It had all of the features we enjoyed elsewhere, but was quieter than the more famous temples.

Better than Ta Prohm. Gives the same feel as Ta Prohm used to - always less crowded.
Best to enter from the east to see the original way on entering the temple. Lots of great photo opportunties.

Worth the visit. This temple is great to explore, its less busy than the main temples (Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom, Ta Phrom), but it has just as much character/history. There's some great photo opportunities as you wander around. There's no barriers anywhere, so you can climb through the window openings and explore other parts of the ruins where tourists normally do not venture.Be careful of the tourist police, who will try and guide you around and then expect to be paid at the end!

Awesome place to climb around. My brother and I really like this temple. This one was the best because we got to climb on the rocks pretty darn high. It was one of the first temples we went to, but not too crowded--like Angkor Wat (lots of tourist there!). The detailed carvings were cool and we liked all the high walls and doorways. Definitely recommend taking the kids here! They'll love it! Hope you'll like it. This is coming from the kid travelers who travel through out the world having cool experiences.
Temples of Cambodia. All part of tour of temples within Cambodia - each temple had it's own charm and details, this was amongst the best visited.

Ta Prohm, but not as famous!. This is a stunning temple, and easily overlooked. Do not miss it, it will surprise you with its size, simplicity, and beauty. The trees are also reclaiming it (like Ta Prohm), slowly but surely, and some of the trees are just beautiful...take the time if you can.
A temple in the wilderness. This place is beautiful and largely unrestored. You can see roots growing through the rocks and huge rocks piled up as you walk through.
Deceptive. Absolutely fantastic temple. It looks deceptively small until you get up close and look inside and discover it is all hidden behind. Spectacular carvings.

Like a hall of mirrors. Despite the essentially simple '+' shape layout of Preah Khan its easy to get lost as each of the 4 long corridors looks the same and when you start wandering through the ruiuns its easy to forget just which way you came in. A little further out than the majority of the temples its worth paying your driver a couple of extra dollars to view this gem.

A Grand Temple. We enjoyed this temple, also built by Jayavarman VII, with a similar naga balustrade to Angkor Thom's South Gate. Another huge complex with the central corridor seemingly endless. You can see through it from the entrance right to the end in the far far distance. Some beautiful bas-reliefs and strangler figs like in Ta Prohm.
My personal fave. WoW! Love this place! I have been round pretty much all the Cambodian ancient temples and this is my fave, though I fully respect that others will prefer others.

Beautiful temple, worth a visit. This is a relatively less crowded temple. It also has some of the strangler trees that are there at Ta Prohm. We saw it late in the evening when the light was perfect, plus we got less crowds at this time. In fact, there were very few people at this time. Beware of the guard there, he took us around the temple "for some good photo ops" after most people had left and it was close to closing time and then asked for money.

Ancient City. Ancient City of Preah Khan has several impressive sites within it. A lot of this one has not been restored so you get a good impression of what the city was like and the many years of work ahead to reconstruct it fully

great temple with just enough overgrowth. Great manageable temple with atmospheric giant strangler figs. Worth visiting before restoration works (carried on in the back) prettify it to the point when you cannot imagine it in the jungle. One of the best temples in the Siem Reap region

You don't want to miss this!. Angkor-Wat is a must-go, and this one is a not-to-miss one! This could be my favorite among the temples I have visited back in Angkor Complex! It's very unique as it's the one and only temple built on round pillars. I suggest you come here by noon as it was almost nobody there so you could feel free to enjoy the atmosphere (and maybe try to communicate with the spirits if you wish!) There were 2 giant silk trees growing from the temple wall but unfortunately one was dead already (It had broken because of heavy storm I believe!)

surprisingly very good. This was a last minute recommendation by our tour guide...and it was great. We saw this site on our own and I think I comprehended the history of the building. There was a security guard/policeman that provided some interpretation of the carvings, but then asked for a donation. This site also had a large tree growing thru the wall. Pretty impressive.

Preah Khan is on the way to being restored by people who care. The trees invading the temple structures are amazing. The work being done to restore parts of this crumbling wonder is heartwarming and inspiring. The whole place is single story and seems to ramble on forever... we experienced a rain storm whilst we were two thirds of the way through and spent a not unpleasant half hour sheltering in one of the 'rooms' protected from the deluge, though having to avoid the trickles coming through the roof!
Great temple. Certainly worthwhile to visit and you will not be dissapointed.Just soak up the atmosphere and enjoy the location.

Don't miss. This is the temple you want to see! Not crowded midday. The trees and moss interacting with the ruins make it a standout. See the inscription from 1970s when used by soldiers during the war.

Absolutely amazing!. Chose to visit Preah Kahn this year by looking at a map of the ruin area and blindly picking the next destination! There are so many ruins it can be hard to know which to see on top of the main ones. I was sure glad we came to this place.. Preah Kahn was the temple experience I was expecting at Angkor and ta prohm but didn't find.. It is amazing to be able to walk around the crumbling ruins with no scaffolding or tourists! You really feel like your in the middle of nowhere. Such an untouched beauty surely won't last for long so make sure you see it to experience the real ruins. Word of warning, due to all the crumbled rock everywhere there is a lot of stepping up and down on uneven surfaces. I wouldn't recommend anyone who has difficulty ambulating venture far into these ruins.. Your better off sticking to Bayon and the likes where it is more accommodating. Preach Kahn is for the adventurous type who want to walk amongst the untouched Angkor ruins.

Might have been our favourite.. We did the grand circuit in reverse (definitely the way to go, so that you're heading in the opposite direction to the giant tour buses!) and came to Preah Khan towards the end of our day, with no preconceived notions of it. For some reason, we were there almost entirely alone for most of the time and it was magical. It seemed to have a little bit of what made the others great but all rolled in together with some unusual elements and an amazing atmosphere.
Don't miss this one!. Preah Khan is one of the highlights of the Angkor region. It is a fascinating temple, in quite good condition still. It should be on everyone's Angkor itinerary.

My favorite temple!. We visited Preah Khan as part of our KKO Bike Tour (which was amazing) and this was my favorite temple. It is less accessible than many of the other temples, so there were few other visitors there. The temple was originally built as a monastery and university and is now a beautiful moss covered monument. It was my absolute favorite temple and it was breathtakingly beautiful.

sunset at its best.... This is located in Angkor Thom and the most visited place for tourist who would like to witness the sunset at its best. The ponds creates a different colors and sparkles with the sun rays. Before you go to this place, better read more about this place so you will not be disappointed, a guide is an option. If sensitive with insects bites, have a repellant at hand, and of course bottled water.

An original temple - not renovated. This is a must see temple. It is about 4 km north of Angkor Thom. It is the last temple built by Jayavarma VII.It is quite a long walk from the front gate where you are dropped to the temple. There are suggestions that your driver can drop you off at one gate and pick you up at another. You walk up a long drawbridge like area lined with warrriors. Once at the front gate there is another walk ahead.It is however a very clean walk and shaded by trees. You will also pass a group of musicians. Please give them a donation. You will note that they are all land mine victims. Imagine yourself without limbs and facing the sort of life they are. Be generous. A decision has been made not to restore Preah Khan but to stabilise it. It is a delight to walk through. Some parts can be dark but is it clean - unlike Indian monuments there is no smell of urine or red sputum covering the walls and crannies. You do need to watch your step among the rubble and so obey the signs that say do not enter certain parts - they are there for good reason. Any displacement of the rubble could be dangerous both for yourself and the monument.There are beautiful carvings and a small "Grecian" temple. You will note that there are holes all over the walls. These, unlike many of the other temples are not bullet holes made by the Khmer Rouge in their target practice but holes that secured brass panels over the walls. You can just imagine the sheen and glow of these from candles and sunlight.Like Ta Phrom there are some spectacular silk cotton trees that have grown over walls and inner buildings.There is an effigy in the middle with an old woman who wants you to get a blessing by tying a string around your wrist. It is up to you whether you wish to do so.When you finally exit out the rear, take a walk around the outside along the path. If however, it has been raining and the path is flooded, retrace your steps and when in the centre, take the right hand passageway. Mind your head throughout your walk in this temple. The doorways become increasingly lower towards the centre to make people bow to the deity as they approach. When you exit you can then walk around the outside of the temple and see the vines and encroaching greenery. You will also see what they mean by stablising the monument. Be careful as the path can be slippery if it has been raining. You may encounter a man selling local ice cream on the way out. This ice cream comes in a long thick log which he cuts off and puts on a stick for you. Purchase the coconut ice cream. The chocolate is more like milo. It is only 50c each and helps the local economy.
The modern name, meaning "Holy Sword". Another jungle temple, like the nearby Ta Prohm, Preah Khan has been left largely unrestored, with numerous trees and other vegetation growing among the ruins.

For lovers of invading trees. If one of your favorite things about the Angkor experience is the interaction of nature with architecture, Preah Khan stands with Ta Prohm as one of the area's very greatest attractions. Try to go at a time when there aren't too many people. When I went, there were only about ten people in the area. It was a truly serene experience. I can't recommend this temple enough.

Large. What I liked best about the visit to Preah Khan is the special effects created by light and shadows in the waters of the ponds. Amazing! Red-orange patches are created on the water that seems more like big koi fish rather than shadows. Must be something to do with the soil below. The complex is interesting too
Good but least favorite. Some interesting sites but seemed like it had the least unique features of all we saw except perhaps Baphuon. Still good and interesting but there are better options.

A few jewels in a vast area.. This area you'll need a guide who knows the best about the place. Otherwise you cannot be satisfied. I recommend you to buy small book sold for 5USD to discover what to see, where to visit.

wonderful, add to your list and see all the buddhist pagodas on the way. yet another place to spend a morning exploring - you will not be disappointed, as before, take lots of water and small notes for the kids selling things at every venue

One of my favorites. This was one of my favorite temples. It's mostly unrestored and we went on a Monday, so we basically had it to ourselves. I loved walking over the huge blocks and imagining what it looked like in all it's glory.

Don't miss this temple!. Most people stay in Siem Reap in average about 3 or 4 days, and they sometimes run out of time and miss this beautiful temple, which is a shame. This temple is just as beautiful as the Bayon or Ta Phrom and is also very big. One little problem: this is one of the few temples in Angkor that do not have toilet facilities within walking distance.
remind me of ta prohm. The huge trees here remind me of Ta Prohm. There's one that looks like an elephant trunk. They say it is the next largest temple to Angkor Wat.
My favourite. Love this temple as consider not really repaired. Like the original look of it,can shot nice photo. :-)

My Most Intimate Temple Experience. On our second day, after having watched sunrise in Angkor Wat, we trekked the grand circuit temples. Preah Khan is the first temple we visited, followed by Neak Pean, East Mebon and Pre Rup which were all completed in the morning before lunch.I was expecting myself to be a little templed-out since it’s like we’ve seen the best temples in day 1 at the petite circuit but I was not. In fact, of all the flat temples or what they call “monastic complex”, Preah Khan is my favorite. My favorite photos of myself were mostly taken in Preah Khan. Perhaps it is the memorable intimate experience I had with Preah Khan. We were there as early as before 7 in the morning since we left Angkor Wat at 6:30 am. Having got there in the freshness of the day, we almost had the entire temple for ourselves! We were like the first visitors of the day! And that is why I guess I had the best photos taken in there. It was so peaceful and quiet; I had enough time to behold and feel all the mesmerizing carvings on the walls, pediments, all surfaces. Preah Khan almost have everything – lingas, Buddhas, apsaras, devatas, nagas, a stupa with direct sunlight on it, a garuda with oversized genital, trees growing on ruins, auxiliary buildings with an unknown purpose, a lake, name it. Indeed, I fell in love with Preah Khan, more than I did for Banteay Srei.

Another beautiful temple in Siem Reap. Named for a sacred sword, this temple is very unique. It is not squared but rectangular and that gives you the direction you have to go. At each step you will find a unique "room" with details that take you back to the past. Plan for 30-60 minutes in this unique temple.
average - dress conservative for entry. after viewing the Big 3, this is a let down. Its big, monolithic but lacks uniqueness ...Cover up or they wont let you inside

Another Jayavarman VII contribution - excellent. This temple was built in memory of his father. The place is completely in ruins, but one can imagine its majesty in its hay days. Preah Khan must have been an ancient monastery or a place of learning.

Outstanding. So much less crowded than Angkor Wat, such a beautiful temple. A must see!! We did it using a bycicle off road tour (KKO) which allowed us to do many temples during the same day. We left Angkor Wat for the afternoon and that was OK. Preah Khan had 4 alleyways converging in the core of the parking temple. Ancient, ruines but easy to imagine, big trees invading the stones. A must!

Beautiful temple beyond description. Set your camera on panarama this is one of the best temples Banyon trees are devouring it but that only adds to the charm! Take water and camera and batteries -you dont want to run out of power.

A Visual Attraction that Stands Out. The numerous trees and other vegetation growing among the ruins is very interesting. , and stands apart from many of the other attractions. Make sure to take time to see this attraction. It's hard to remember some of the smaller more personable sites after seeing the overwhelming Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom.

Quiet temple. This temple is quite and solemn. There is a certain serenity about the place. Maybe because of the timing when we got there. There were very few tourists, so we got to see and feel the place.

Expansive temple with interesting stories. Similar to Ta Prohm, Preah Khan is still largely unrestored - which can prove to be a lot more interesting to explore than some of the newly pristine temples. The name of the temple means Holy Sword and our guide told us a very interesting story of the sword to go along with our visit. This is a very expansive temple, but mostly only on ground level. There is a cool mysterious building on the grounds that no one knows the history behind - perhaps a library? Definitely worth a visit!

Very Interesting. Maybe 4th on the list of must-sees in Angkor (after Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom, and Ta Prohm). This was the last temple we saw after 2 days of touring. We were a bit "templed out" by then, but this place restored our enthusiasm. It has components of the other temples and isn't so packed.
Must visit. An amazing temple complex that you have to visit. We went in the morning at about 10am when there were few tourists and the light was good inside and outside the complexHighly recommended

Great, quiet and huge temple off the elephant route. This large temple complex is situated just outside the elephant route ("small circle") that the majority of tourists is doing at the beginning of the large circle. It's a huge temple site where you can just wander around finding ever new perspectives through the large corridor system of the temple. I recommend entering from the East entrance although it is the furthest away coming from Angkor Thom. It used to be the main entrance and hence the temple unfolds most impressively from this entrance.
still going great!. Seeing the stupendously huge octopus like tree sitting on the walls of this temple can leave one astound and in wonderful state of mind.

It 'a temple surrounded by nature. It 'a temple surrounded by nature, here, as in Ta Phrom, the trees have invaded and taken over with their roots columns, roofs of buildings. And 'fascinating precisely because of this nature that wildly trying to recover these treasures long hidden in the jungle

Spectacular!. Angkor's second largest temple building is much less crowded than Angkor Wat. It is a bit more of the Angkor essence of Nature overtaking man-made works as it is not as restored and put together as Angkor Wat. It was a great joy to explore around the Sacred Sword temple
Large scale and peaceful temple.. The serene large scale peaceful temple. Good to be there early in the morning and late afternoon.

Same same but different. Pretty cool and apparently used to look much like Ta Prohm in terms of jungle vegetation. Here they removed most of it which had quite a destructive effect on the temple. Interesting complex, again unique to the others and not as imposing in size.

Shouldn't be missed... unique setting. An intriguing ruin to visit, set amongst trees that are growing through the ruin. Less visited than the more famous sites but that adds to the charm of the visit. Requires one to be more nimble than other sites due to the presence of rocks and uneven surfaces. Visit strongly recommended while in Siem Reap.
A plethora of temples.... ...and this was one that I did, but any of them is worth the visit.

Favorite temple in Angkor area.. This was my favorite temple in the Angkor region. A mix of still standing buildings, jungle overtaking structures and ruins made this my favorite. Some of the trees growing out of buildings like Ta Prohm without the same crowds. The complex housed the university at the time, as well as the king's sword. Sprawling complex with both hindu and budhism reliefs. I went first thing in the morning, and it was very quiet and uncrowded.

"Sacred Sword" temple complex. Preah Khan (late 12th c Buddhist) is a huge complex which originally served as a Buddhist monastery and school, engaging over 1000 monks. For a short period it was also the residence of King Jayavarman VII. The name means “sacred sword” and the temple is dedicated to the King’s father. We approached the temple along a grand boulevard and bridge lined with gods and demons struggling, like the earlier bridge we’d seen into Angkor Thom. Here only one head remains; the rest had all been eroded away. Once inside we were greeted with grey, green, and red walls sculpted with bas reliefs of apsara, warriors, firefly-Tinker Bell-like women along the top edges of inside walls, and huge fig and silk-cotton trees growing out of and into the building’s stones. At the center of the main temple is a shrine dedicated to one of the Angkorian Queens.We visited Preah Khan as the last stop on a five temple Grand Circuit tuk-tuk tour of Angkor Thom, reaching it in the late afternoon. Since it was late in the day, there were few people here and the light was fantastic for photographs. I thought it was magnificent. See more information and pictures of our temple trips here: http://lmaclean.ca/2012/01/grand-tour-of-temples-around-angkor-thom-cambodia/and here: http://lmaclean.ca/2012/01/temple-tour-two-small-circuit-of-angkor-wat-and-angkor-thom/
Ta Prohm-like temple. Preah Khan is a very nice temple which reminds a bit of Ta Prohm due to the giant old trees. Also very picturesque.
Stunning. Built byu the same king who gave us Ta Prohm, Preah Khan doesn't get as many visitors. Great temple to explore & very photogenic.

Hauntingly Beautiful!. Wow - this place was amazing! You wonder how these buildings are still even standing with the trees and roots enveloping each and every stone! Very crowded - try to go first thing to get pictures with no one in them.
Must see. One of the nicest with it's overgrown walls, a bit like Ta Phrom but less crowded.

Sacred Sword. I love Preah Khan.The temple is unique and very large. I like the two stories building that different from other temples. Visit this temple in the morning and spend sometime inside of the temple. Bring enough drink with you.

Buddhist complex. Preah Khan is located north-east of Angkor Thom on the grand circuit. It is a Buddhist complex and built at the exact spot where Jayavarman VII finally defeated the Chams. Dedicated to his father It first served as a Buddhist monastery and a university. The temple is still largely unrestored. An interesting site to explore full of carvings and passages.

One of the oldest. The artificial moats created by the Hindu kings brought immeasurable prosperity to this generally dry region.This temple is supposed to be the 9th century temple with many Lion heads and very steep steps before one can reach the temple..where now a Budhdha statue is kept and worshipped.
Historic but ..... Much smaller and less grand than others given its vintage. Worth seeing for the record. Nice setting

Nice and quiet ... Away from mass crowds ... An amazing ruin to visit set amongst trees. Good thing is that it is nice and quiet away from the masses. Strongly recommend it. Lots of rocks to climb over so not really suitable if less mobile.

Another Excellent Temple. My first visit 2 years ago, I was the only visitor at this temple for nearly an hour. On this visit, that was not the case. I think I was there late afternnon - and was absolutely accosted by some very aggressive "picture" sellers. I actually had to tell one to leave me alone and to give me some space. There were also quite a few children there selling trickets as well. After I weeded my way through all of them - I was able to enjoy the beauty of this temple. This temple is very large and will take over an hour to really go through some of it. There are good photo ops with trees growing over and/or into parts of the temple. But there is still way less visitors here than at Ta Prohm. This temple complex is also larger so getting a good photo with no people in them can be done.

Like Ta Phrom, only much more quiet. If you want to avoid the crowds in Ta Phrom then Preah Khan is it. I was raining going to there from Bantay Srei and we were about to call it a day but due to our guides prodding we decided to continue with the last 2 temples on our list. Good thing we heeded our guides advice to still go. Do not forget to look for the tree devouring an area in this temple, you can find this almost at the end of the temple.

One of my favorites!. This is a maze of a temple with four main entrances/exits each facing north, east, south, west respectively. I immensely enjoyed wandering through its small and large hallways and "discovering" new courtyards and rooms. This temple is particularly known for its infinity door pictures, so that when you stand on one end and take a picture, you can see several door openings going onto what seems an infinity. Drivers normally drop you off at one end and pick up at another. Do not allow drivers to talk you into meeting them at the origin (they like to save on gas and cut corners at the inconvenience of the guest) because you will come out exhausted at the end having done a turnaround trip.

cambodia Preah Khan. Preah khan is about 15kilometers south west of the main temples of Angkor it consists of 6 towers in 2 rows and is between Bakong and LoleiWe went with a guide it was hot and I was glad to have water with us there was a lot of collapsed rubble and stones everywhereWe saw more carvings and roots seemed to be slowly taking over this place there where statues but without heads this time we were told they had been stolen some time ago It was an interesting tour with some good camera shots
No way to skip this mysterious temple. Our favorite even when you have visited all the other temples.
worth the visit. One of the smaller temples that we visited while in Siem Reap. It has been beautifully wall carvings and worth a visit.

One of my favorite temples to visit. This is the type of temple I envisioned when I would dream of the temples in Siem Reap. It was beautiful, large, lots of intricate carvings and not very crowded! The trees growing throughout were amazing to see. I highly recommend visiting this temple!

our rainy adventure.. it was raining hard when we were at this temple but i love the kindness and friendly nature of the cambodians....plus our guide was resourceful, we borrowed 3 umbrellas from the local kids and offered them a dollar ...so we were able to enjoy preah khan walking in the rain...

perfect. Among the least Angkor tourists, is a rare quiet place. Although you can see from the outside is not flashy, dense corridor and mystical relief was very attractive and get inside. Ceiling also collapsed, buildings that are likely to be erosion in the trees, stands sedately still feel when far beyond the will. I thought of sitting on the rock garden forever, and I want to heal the heart, was such a place.
A beautiful surprise. I wasn't expecting this temple to be so beautiful, it is defenitively on the top 5 for me!

Felt like stepping back in time. I personally loved this temple but may not be everyone's cup of tea. It is in a state of disrepair, with many of the corridors filled with fallen blocks.It has a real feel of something out of Indiana Jones and was fun to explore the corridors and wasn't at all crowded, so it did feel like we had the place to ourselves.The stories/legends around this temple are very interesting. It used to be buddhist university and the stand where the sacred sword was places is still there.With a bit of imagination, this temple can be a lot of fun.

Best temple in Siem Reap. Best temple in Siem Reap. A bit of everything, ruins, trees growing on ruins, a two-storey building, the only one in Angkor!, nice carvings (wonderful Dancer Hall!), and above all NOT TOO CROWDED. It sums up the best of Angkor. Crowds really ruin the experience in Ta Prohm and Angkor Wat. This one was just perfect! My favorite in Angkor. And if you want to visit the other temples, go EARLY (before 8 am).
Unexpected Delight. I was not aware of this temple prior to our trip to Cambodia, do not miss it, it is hidden in the jungle and has far fewer visitors than say Angkor Wat

Get there early!. It is a small temple and with a few coach loads of tourists arriving in convoy it makes it difficult to enjoy it! Walk round the exterior wall as well as through the temple, no one else bothers but you get a good view and it feels like you're there on your own which is pretty special
Yet an other great place. If you take the time you will see so much in these amazing places
