Visit early before the crowds. We visited this temple straight after sunrise at Angkor wat. this is a great time to go because you beat the crowds. Enter east side and you'll see the information centre on your left, very interesting read! This temple is very large and interesting.
great temple in the jungle not simple stone but historical stone.. only the expert tour guide can show the great of the Preah Khan temple .
Fantastic. Amazing temple complex, fantastic to walk around the corridors and grounds, make sure you go.
A famous temple. Love it, this is one of the must see, fantastic for photos
Loved it. Really beautiful. Lots to explore and has a different feel. This is another must see.

Beautiful temple away from the tour buses. My girlfriend and I really enjoyed visiting the Preah Khan temple.Previously we had visited the Angkor Thom and Angkor Wat. Preah Khan is smaller but just as magnificent and it is not swarmed by tour buses so you can walk around at your own leisure.We visited the temple at around 4pm. This is a good time to visit if you want to get good light for taking photographs.
Worth the trip. If you've got the trip time include this on your itinery you won't be disapointed
Asian‘s Rome. a place that to store a sword of the king. Dun forget to snap a photo in the temple, an experience guide will let you know where is the angle of shooting.
Buddhism temple. I like this temple because it simelar the taprum and bayon. I dont like because they build this temple for only their family.
Amazing !. Preah Khan was huge and totally amazing considered as temporary king resident. We were impressed and loved its natural state with trees growing on stones and rubble.
I Enjoyed It. Yes, like all of them there was something at this temple to make it worth visiting along with the others.

Make sure you see it. As all others have said, great place, not so many tourists and bus loads of groups, rivals ta promh for tree takeovers, a good quiet one to explore the ins and outs of without too much hassle.

My favorite spot at Angkor. Preah Khan has the beautiful strangler figs of Ta Phrom without the extra people. It is a beautiful maze and it's easy to get lost in the passageways and the history. Don't miss it.

Beautiful. We visited Preah Khan as the climax to day two of our three day ticket and it was a fitting finale to the day. Huge, with many beautiful carvings, some trees growing out of the walls to almost rival Ta Prohm and the jungle looking as if it is about to swallow the place up, this temple is a micro-version of all the others put together. It was also good that we had the place almost to ourselves - such a contrast to the first day at Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom.
A great place to visit. Definitely worth seeing. Different from the rest of the temples and not so busy.
Nice and well kept, great for pictures. This temple is great for pictures because it is not that busy at all. The only downside is that it is out of the way of all the other temples.
Excellent, in the forest. Probably my favorite temple -- on par with Bayon. Cut out of the jungle and not so crowded.

A Maze Ing. It was wonderful wondering around the temple and getting"lost" . The walls and enclosures , although in disrepair, allow you to imagine a day when thousands of scholars lived and studied here.
Huge and well worth a visit. A huge temple and maze of vaulted corridors with doorway after doorway as far as the eye can see.

Great experience and a good alternative to Ta Prohm. With all the construction going on in Ta Prohm, some of the more sought after scenes are roped off for safety. Preah Khan really made up for the picturesque shots I was not able to get..

Flabbergasting!. I couldn't imagine this place was a city 1000 years ago! It has several advanced projects (rain water harvesting, double-storeyed building etc.). I am sure there is a lot to uncover in the surrounding forests...and would be happy to!

worth a visit. preah khan is little out of the way but this should not stop you from seeing it if you're in siem reap. what sets this temple apart from the others is that its surrounded by a moat and you can only approach it during summer when the moat is dry. this is a very small temple surrounded by altars (the correct term escapes me) devoted to different deities. the path leading to the temple is scenic, good for having your picture taken.
Swort temple ( Preah Khan ). This temple is one the famous among hundred other, was build by hero king 7 and dedicated to his farther.

Fantastic Temple. I visited over 20 temples during my stay in Cambodia and I think Preah Khan was my favourite. When I visited there were very small crowds and maybe that added to the atmosphere because it was very quiet and serene-like. The carvings here are very good and the temple is just that little bit different to the others in it's construction and design. The temple of the Sacred Sword definately got my vote.

Impressive temple complex. This was the first temple we visited in the Angkor area and it is a good start, as it allows to experience the typical layout and arrangements of a temple of this period. It is well enough preserved (and restored) to make it an interesting visit. The double-story building (where the holy sword is said to have been kept) is unusual. There are also several outstanding sculptures, though they may be hard to find. Read the relevant sections in Claude Jacques' and Michael Freeman's "Ancient Angkor" guide first -- I had borrowed it from my local public library at home, but the book seems to be on sale for 1 or 2 US$, must be illegal copies...
Less touristy than the others. On my last day in Cambodia we took a trip here and I think it was my favourite temple tour. It was very quiet, the weather was lovely and we were not harassed by anyone
Photogenic. Not my favourite Angkor temple but it was very photogenic
Less crowds. This temple is unusual as it is the only site where you will see columns. They are in the building west of the main temple.

Amazing!. One of my favorite temple to visit when was in Cambodia. It's so beautiful, and really admire the architectural works and design. Maybe should put some info board like what they have in Bantey Sreay?
Another Temple. Similar to Ta Phrom but not as impressive.The name means 'sacred sword'. Has elements of both Buddhist and Hindu religions.
nice - not crowded. Go, walk through, enjoy. This temple complex is huge and not on the main track, so you won't be crowded. Beautiful site. Worth the trip.

A must see. Double storyed building towards the back is a sight to behold, very interesting structure, that is somehow still standing. The whole temple is huge so allow good time to travel around here. We got the best Mango and banana's off a local on a long path heading back to our tuk tuk.

Definitely include this temple in your itinerary you won't regret it. This temple is huge so in order to explore it properly allow at least a good hour, I could have spent a lot longer here. We entered from the west which has lovely carved boundary stones on either side of the road and then across the causeway there are gods etc a little like the south gate of Angkor Thom. This temple has a little bit of everything, beautiful carvings, silk cotton trees entwined in the ruins and also a wonderful two storey building with no stairs which is interesting unlike anything I saw at the other temples. The inner section of the temple is quite crowded, do have a good look around as this is where there were quite a few great carvings. This was one of my favourites and I would love to go back, there weren't as many people either which is always good. Definitely include this temple in your itinerary you won't regret it.

Sacred Sword. Another amazing temple that has ongoing resoration so is fairly easy to walk around. The carvings along the main walkways (especially the west side) are intact - unfortunately looters have chipped away most of the figures and faces in other areas.Got a fairly basic but good lunch at cafe Number 9 across from the entrance recommended by our tuk tuk driver Mr Seng.

Banyan Trees Rule. This temple has all but succombe to the ravishes of the jungle. However the destruction wrought by the mighty Banyan trees has its own appeal and shows how nature is never that far away from destoying even the mightiest work of man.

Quieter in the afternoon. We went towards the end of the day and loved this temple which is amazing as we had had a very busy day but it felt very special and we wandered around finding ourselves alone at times, lovely carvings, a special place.
Loved it. I really much preferred this temple to Ta Phrom although they were both built by the same king, this one is dedicated to his father and Ta Phrom to his mother.

Well worth a stop. This is an attractive temple. The crowds definitely thin out once you're north of Angkor Thom though Preah Khan is by no means quiet. Mic you want a much more solitary temple you'll need to head further clockwise round the Great Circuit. But unless you're really Ina hurry this is definitely not somewhere to rush past. Isolated from Angkor Wat or Angkor Thom it would be a greatbworldmsite by itself.
Size and grandeur. I really loved this lesser known temple with is large scale and fewer crowds. majestic.

excellent. If I remember rightly we approached this temple from the forest trail which was brilliant as we were the only people around for what felt like miles, deep in the jungle, thanks to our guide. Could never have found it on our own. Walked through this tumbledown temple and only found more tourists when nearly at the other end. Great photos
Good Temple. A good temple to take the time to see. Not many people at this one, so you have it nearly to yourself!

Really huge temple. This one really huge. Make sure your tuk tuk will wait you on the other side... You will avoid to do it another time. It is interesting but not among my favorites. If you only have 2-3 days for visiting, don't waste your time to do this one. At the west entrance, you may find kids asking you if you have candies because they feel hungry. So make sure to have fruits with you to give to them

Gems. Like Ta :Prohm Mother nature has taken its toll on this area too. What is interesting is that you can see that there were lots of gems which were part of these temples. And all that remains today are the empty sockets created to hold these big semi-precious/precious stones.
Constructed in the late 12thc. Wonderful carvings and some fascinating passages, this was originally a Buddhist Monastery.

A little bit of all of them in one. This was the last one we saw. It was a nice mix of all of them. Big enough and not too crowded made it even more enjoyable. Some areas were in disarray (like a maze), some well preserved spots, some encroaching trees, good colors in the blocks, interesting carvings, entry gates and moat.
Very cool - like Ta Prohm but bigger. I think this was very nice. Not as crowded as at Ta Prohm due to the size. Very nice.

Nice temple but Ta Prohm is better. If you have visited the two key attractions in Siem Reap (Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom), then Preah Khan will not really offer anything new. Don't get me wrong. This temple is beautiful and the flooded forest just outside of the Victory Gate is fascinating. But, given that Ta Prohm is almost similar to Preah Khan in terms of construction and materials, I'll pick the former anytime.
Probably one of my favorite temples. It just went on and on. Clearly the USA (which is taking responsibility for supporting the restoration of this site) has alot to do but it took my breath away.

Great to end the day with. Visited this temple during the last of our 2nd day tour. It's just as amazing as Ta Phrom but without the heaps of tour buses. We reached here at about 430pm an hour before it closes and we had the whole temple to ourselves (in fact, we were the last to leave). You could explore the smaller rooms of in the temple to your own liking as long as it's not on the forbidden path (due to falling of rocks). A torch light will come in handy as we reached when the sunlight is no longer visible enough to guide us through the smaller rooms. It is said that there's a statue of the king's wife being worshipped in one of the smaller room and you need to explore for it. Unfortunately for us, as the sky was quite gloomy on that day, we didn't quite manage to explore the temple to the fullest even when we're armed with a torchlight. Overall a great experience and a good choice to wind down for the day. Less people and you may take your own sweet time.

Impressive. This was my first time visiting Preah Khan and I found it to be well worth the effort. It's huge; one can easily spend a couple of hours walking around exploring this site without getting tired or feeling that it's too much. There are many carved sections deep within that are pretty well preserved and therefore many special photos awaiting your camera. The combination of standing structures and fallen stones makes for a sometimes eerie experience as you think of what these stones must have witnessed over the centuries and what the place must have been like centuries ago.Another thing that I enjoyed is that there are fewer tourists here and that if you wanted some quiet time in an area of the temple, patience paid off as small groups moved on and you'd have a few moments before more people came through.

As beautiful as Ta Prohm but without all the tourists. Loved this place. It had the beauty of Ta Prohm (trees fused with the ruins) but it lacked the tourists that ultimately ruin Ta Prohm. Watch your step, I twisted my ankle pretty bad the first day and it took a month to heal. I met around half a dozen people with a similar story.
Epic Temple!. As cool or maybe better than To Prom. Must see! Went here on recommendation of our hotel and very glad we did. Less people than Ta Prom but very similar and really majestic.

Ruins + jungle = one hell of an atmosphere. Again, pretty similar to Ta Prohm, in that the jungle has been left a bit and not fully cleared like Angkor Wat. So you'll find a buddha head on a tree here, twines engulfing an entire wall there. Overall, a different but lovely experience.

A long, rather different, intriguing rectangular temple.. The long road between trees towards the west-entrance of the temple is very pleasant as you walk between (unfortunately by Red-Khmer-decapitated) -giant 'Ocean of milk stirrers, much like in Angkor Thom and at first you don't know what to expect, but once inside, the carvings around every corner and on fallen pieces surprise you, especially because the temple is almost 800 meters long! The view from the side on the rooftops give you a good idea of how it once was, it is a pity though that (real) policemen encourage you to go up there with them for the view (while it is actually not allowed) and afterwards ask a reward ($). Understandable, but a shame. The temple complex has an unusual additional 2-story building, looking strangely enough like a Greek temple. All-in-all, another, never boring and mysterious temple with over 800 years of age.
Crumbled Giant.. Preah Khan was a mass of crumbled stones surrounding a number of intact stupas and temples.

Felt like you were in the Tomb Raider game!. Interesting choice by the archeologists to leave this place more like it was found, with stones tumbling down and tree roots engulfing the temple itself. An interesting experience-kids will love it!

Preah Khan. The Hall of Dancers......A lot of decorative inscriptions but also a lot has tumbled down at the time we were there.Some parts no access.A policeman voluntary offered his service as a guide:make it clear from the very beginning if you want this or not.Most of them try to figure out first if you know something about the complex and if you have ever been there before:A bit of nonsense if you don;t know anything and they want ofcourse some money for that.There are real guides who can explain you much better.Or.....just buy that little book of "Ancient Angkor" from the kids.

One huge temple!. A real landmark moment in our trip. This one seriously interesting temple. There is a lot of damage from collpased stone work, but what is left standing is a true sight to be seen. One word of caution, the shaded areas of the temple grows this dark algae and it is more slippery than anything I have ever encountered. Please be very carefull. Oh and if you pay attention you might find graffiti left behind by Viet Kong soldiers or the Apsara dancer with 6 toes, or the most beautifull (& most worshipped) Apsara in all of the Angkor area.
Water, please. The complex is really big but the ruins will amaze you. It has silk trees like Ta Prohm and very intricate wall carvings like Bayon so the long walk is definitely worth it.
nice architecture. we like the preah kan,no to buiy temple but verry nice architecture.

Ruins Worth Visiting for the Peace and Quiet Time. Preah Khan was my last stop in my Grand Circuit tour. It was already after 3pm when my tuk-tuk driver dropped me off at the East entrance. It was a very quiet and peaceful walk all the way to the entrance, until some children tried selling some magnets and drinks. All the figures holding the Naga on the bridge across the moat are headless, said to have been stolen. There is much greenery around the moat. There are also interesting huge sculptures of Garuda (at 5m height) along the walls. At the East entrance you can see an ingrown tree on the wall to the left.This monastery is pretty much a ruin. It's very quiet except for some local boys who'd want to make some tips from guiding you. There are also many photo opportunities. I spent an hour here just taking photos and enjoying the views and the peaceful moments.Worth a visit just to bask in the peaceful moments.
So large!. The combination of semi ruin and massive size really affected me.I keep thinking of the extraordinary view from the centre down the four arms with arch after arch after arch.
Love this site!. Challenging, confusing, stunning, very good place to explore

My favourite. Good design but unreconstructed and with fewer tourists than Ta Prohm.. I sat for half an hour in a courtyard full of huge blocks, gazing at the stonework and the trees growing out of doorways (just like at Ta Prohm) and didn't anyone else except for a soldier who walked past and apologised for disturbing me.

The temple with a thousand doors, literally, it is very easy to get lost here, but this is a must see temple!. This temple has so many doors it will make your head spin, but it is one of the best temples in Angkor Park. I would highly recommend visiting this temple, it is one of the main temples in Angkor and definitely worth seeing.Preah Khan was built in the late 12th century and is of Bayon style. You will need probably 45 minutes to 1.5 hours depending on your interest. There are some good photo opportunities here.This temple seems to have been used at some point as a university also.If you need a great guide, check here: http://www.tripadvisor.com/Attraction_Review-g297390-d2178241-Reviews-Thoeunson_Private_Tour-Siem_Reap.htmlWe used him for the time we were in Siem Reap, he is great and very knowledgeable due to his previous work, and we booked him in advance because he is really able to show Angkor unlike other guides.Your Angkor pass will get you into here.

Don't Miss. While not one of the more popular temples, this one is not to be missed. It's huge and significantly less crowded than Ta Prohm and Angkor Wat but still quite impressive. It has some of the features of Ta Prohm and has that "Temple of Doom" feel that other reviews mention. We even found a few bats flying around in one corner of the temple after shining a flashlight in a dark corridor. Make sure you check out this temple!

A great site that you should not miss. Firstly, I have to admit that, Preah Khan is a highly unrestored site, compared to many sites in Angkor. However, through my study, it was a temple that held many records:1. First temple that dedicated to many gods and deities.2. First temple with round pillars on a two stories "mystical building",3. A rare temple with a wide spread of one storey complex.The temple really showed me the meaning of "ruins"- badly damaged by natural forces. But the grandness of the temple could be seen afar before the main entrance, from the two rows of pillars set beside the mainroad that lead to the entrance. The whole temple covers an area of 700 x 800 m, enclosed by 100 m wide moat. It is believed that the temple once consisted of more than 100 towers with more than 100,000 people living at the surrounding area.Preah Khan located 2 km northward from Bayon, around 5 minutes by car. It is a quiet site comparatively. A visiting route from west to east is highly recommended, which will start from the road flanked by two rows of pillars, into the main entrance, right through the center of the temple with a stupa, and end at the east side of the temple, with a big kapok overgrown the wall of the temple. It is a site that highly recommended by me. A pre-visit study about the history and information of the site is essential, in order to treasure what we see in the temple. For more of my experience in Siem Reap and Angkor Archaeological site, pls visit my blog at:http://bettyandlingshing.blogspot.com/2010/12/preah-khan-and-ta-prohm.html

jungletastic Preah Khan. The 'sacred sword' temple. It's a Buddhist temple, and used to be home to over 1000 Buddhist teachers, although it has sections devoted to Hindu gods Shiva and Vishnu. It also has a stupa and a linga. The sheer scale of the site is impressive; it's set in 56 hectares of jungle, so we spent alot of time exploring and getting lost in the ruins. The most striking thing about Preah Khan though was the way the jungle has taken over - humongous silk-cotton and fig tree trunks rise out of the old temple walls, which their giant roots have pushed through and split apart over the centuries.

Reminded me of the temple of doom. One of the guides at this temple told me that this place was 700meters by 800meters. When one enters it, it is like looking down a tunnel. You literally go from structure to structure and there is very little open area. The open areas that existed were filled with huge stones. From side to side are rooms and this goes on for the full length both ways. This reminded me of the movie Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom.

One of my favourites too. As stated in previous reviews, here you can escape the crowds. I don't know why not many people visit as it is no further than most of the other temples within or around the Angkor Thom vicinity. Perhaps, as we were told by our guide, the more 'famous' Ta Phrom (or 'Tomb Raider' temple) is similar i.e. overgrown trees engulfing the temple structures.However, at the Tomb Raider temple, during the high season and if you are unlucky enough to visit during the peak times, you can hardly get the opportunity to get a photo shot without someone walking into your path. And, you have to walk one way as turning back against traffic can be difficult at times.Here at Preah Khan, you get the same sights minus the crowd. The long, long corridors are fascinating. If you are slightly more sure footed, try walking around on the outside of the main structure, hoping from fallen stone to stone - gives you the explorer feel! Also, look out for the 'out of place' building within the grounds of the temple - suddenly, there is this 2 storey building that looks nothing like any Ankorian structure that I have seen. Our guide told us it was a library but some guide books say that its purpose is unknown. Photography? Snap away and take your own sweet time here.By going to this site, you would most probably pass through the North gate of Angkor Thom as well, where the surroundings are more green and makes a much better photo than the South gate.Having said that, I am not at all suggesting that you do not visit Ta Phrom/'Tomb Raider temple. However, this site gave me the 'authentic' feel.

Amazing, grand and peaceful place - with very few tourists!. We went to Preah Khan after 2 days visiting the 'main' sights. Our tour guide told us that we'd seen everything worthwhile and really pushed us to visit Tonle Sap lake. I kept saying that I would like to visit some less popular temples but he kept insisting on the lake! Sensing a hidden agenda (and getting annoyed!) I cancelled our third day with him and instead we took off in a tuk tuk without a guide. We enjoyed this much more!!We had our children, aged 7 and 8 with us and they really loved Preah Khan. It is really huge but really peaceful. Whilst there we heard only the noises of the jungle and saw about 10 other people. The air is perfumed with wild flowers and hundreds of butterflies dance like the Apsara dancers on the reliefs. Very magical.It helped having had a guide to explain the motifs and layouts of Angkor Watt, Bayon and Ta Prohm so we understood what we saw and what part of the temple we were in. However, it was so much cooler to just be by ourselves wandering round this amazing temple. Oh and there are some huge trees growing out of some of the buildings towards the East gate too so it felt like a (much) quieter version of Ta Prohm!Amazing place, you must go!!
